Ultracell  Networks  Ltd  has  prepared  this  document  for  DESNZ  as  evidentiary  information  of achievement of key milestones and objectives relating to the deliverables of the third quarter of 2023 for  the  Cellular  Passive  Optical  Networks  (C-PON)  platform  of  the  Energy-efficient  Cellular  Optical Interconnects for Clouds and Edge-processing (ECOICE) project.

We are confident that we have understood and met the objectives and are providing a high quality, value-based report that meets the requirements as defined in the project. In summary:

- We achieved the technical deliverable DT15 within WP3 which is a final report summarising joint  tests  of  C-PON  card,  optical  line  manager  (OLM),  backplane,  C-PON  cell  and  control software and trials at BT and Vodafone network test sites. We give an update on optimisation and refinement of the C-PON testbed. Thereafter, we report the outcomes of the joint test of the of the refined C-PON testbed. We also conduct resilience test in the C-PON testbed for the first time and we report the results of the resilience and power consumption tests.
- We achieved the technical deliverable DFT3 within WP7 which is a C-PON full-feature field trial. We give an overview of selected application (i.e., AR/VR application) and use cases for the CPON full-feature trial. We also give a progress update on AR/VR use case demonstration and outline the next steps for the full feature trial of the C-PON technology.
- We discussed some of the challenges and lessons learned during the ECOICE project.

This  document forms a detailed report  on the  work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 1st July 2023 to 29th September 2023, focused on a technical deliverable and a field trial deliverable. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section 2 reviews the ECOICE project from inception till date.
- Section 3 reports outcomes of the joint tests of all components of the C-PON platform i.e., CPON card, optical line manager (OLM), backplane, C-PON cell and control software.
- Section 4 gives a progress update on the C-PON full-feature field trial.
- Section 5 outlines ECOICE project challenges and lessons learned.

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs)  with  effective,  resilient  and  energy  efficient  computing  for  various  applications.  The  C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL)  3  to  TRL6  where  a  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  will  be  fitted  with  monitoring  and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including.

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The engineers in Ultracell Networks Ltd are involved in the development of the key C-PON components which include:

- C-PON NIC card.
- OLM.
- Optical back plane.
- Control software.
- C-PON cell development.

Several industrial collaborators are involved with the use-case development and validation of components, systems, and subsystems of the C-PON platform, including:

- Vodafone (wireless networks, IoT, and cloud and fog DCs).
- BT (wired network, cloud DCs and fog computing).

This ECOICE project report focuses on the deliverables of Milestone 8 (MS8) which covers the third quarter of 2023 (Q3 2023). Table 1 provides a summary of the deliverables and work packages of the ECOICE project and highlights the current deliverables. The Q3 2023 deliverables include a technical deliverable (DT15), which relates to work package (WP3) and a field trial deliverable (DFT3), which relates to work package (WP7).

<!-- image -->

Prior  to  the  ECOICE  project,  the  C-PON  technology  was  implemented  as  a  lab-based demonstrator at low TRL3 where essential software was implemented in servers. Furthermore, the optical  line  manager  (OLM)  control  functions  were  also  implemented  in  servers.  The  backplane  of proposed  C-PON  architecture  was  implemented  by  electronic  switches  and  thus,  several  optical electrical optical conversions was required in the lab-based demonstrator. Consequently, the lab-based demonstrator was not in production form and was characterised by high power consumption and slow operation.

The ECOICE project set out to develop the C-PON technology from TRL3 to TRL6 to make the CPON technology attractive  for  exploitation  and  venture  funding.  To  achieve  this,  the  scope  of  the ECOICE project includes both technical and commercial deliverables. The technical deliverables include technical  development  activities  to  construct  key  components  of  the  C-PON  architecture  into commercial product form. Such components include C-PON network interface card (NIC) card, OLM, the optical backplane, and the control software. Technical development activities of the project also include  the  integration  of  all  essential  C-PON  components  to  create  a  functional  C-PON  cell.  The technical development activities of the ECOICE project are complemented by commercial deliverables which aim to engage and collaborate with industrial partners to identify potential use cases and their corresponding requirements which will inform and focus the technical development activities of the project.

Both technical development activities and commercial engagements are expected to lead to the construction of a testbed (i.e., C-PON demonstration prototype) where key performance indicators (i.e., latency, power consumption and resilience) of the C-PON platform can be monitored, measured, and  optimised  in  lab  environment  and  in  field  trial  test  sites  of  industrial  partners.  The  testbed  is expected to demonstrate reduction in power consumption, reduction in latency and greater resilience. The  testbed  should  provide  an  agile,  flexible,  and  scalable  platform  which  can  efficiently  utilise resources to satisfy dynamic demand patterns.

Achieving both technical and commercial deliverables of the ECOICE project is expected to de-risk the C-PON technology for venture funds (by advancing the C-PON technology from TRL3 to  TRL6). Hence,  the  ECOICE  project  will  provide  a  prototype  that  will  enable  third  parties  to  validate  both business and technical propositions of the C-PON technology.

Prior  to  this  quarter,  several  milestones  have  been  achieved  in  the  ECOICE  project.  These milestones have delivered a range of technical and commercial deliverables which can contributed to technical and commercial achievements. These achievements of the ECOICE project in past milestone reports are reviewed in this sub-section.



The focus of the technical development activities of the ECOICE project is the development of the  key  components,  systems,  and subsystems  of C-PON  which  include  C-PON  card,  the  OLM,  the optical backplane, the control software and a functional C-PON cell.

The C-PON card performs networking functions which include interfacing with physical media, parsing  of  packets,  temporary  storage  of  packets  and  forwarding  of  packets.  These  functions  are performed by a range of physical sub-components of the C-PON card. These physical sub-components comprise network interfaces, forwarding engines, buffers, and traffic managers. The Xilinx U25 smart NIC was adopted to develop the C-PON card.

The development of the C-PON card entails its specification and the programming of the FPGA in a smart NIC to implement certain networking functions which include, but is not limited to, interfacing with physical media, parsing of packets, packet processing decision making, storage of packets and forwarding of packets. Following initial specification of the C-PON card in DT1 and the advancement of the specification of the C-PON card in DT5, the development of the C-PON card on the Xilinx U25 smart NIC has been completed.

The optical backplane is essential for enabling connectivity between servers in the same rack in the C-PON platform. Thus, optical backplanes provide an exclusive intra-rack fabric between servers in the same rack. Several options considered to implement the backplane include fiber Bragg grating, optical polymer backplanes, optical packet switches, and optical circuit switches.

DT7 gave advanced specification of candidates C-PON optical backplane to replace the electrical switch used in the TRL3 lab demonstrator of the C-PON technology. Furthermore, the implementation of a C-PON testbed as reported in DT14 adopts a fibre optic system to implement a full mesh optical backplane for the C-PON tested. This fibre optic system of a full mesh optical backplane mimics a smallscale optical polymer backplane. Consequently, OEO conversion and power consumption is reduced relative to the previously developed lab-based demonstrator of the C-PON technology which existed before the ECOICE project.

The  C-PON  control  software  is  a  logical  entity  that  governs  how  communication  is  performed within each C-PON cell and in a full-fledged C-PON platform. The control software comprises a range of algorithms, protocols and applications that dynamically assign and manage network resources. The C-PON control software computes, manages, and installs forwarding information into all data plane devices. The control software is also responsible for configuration and management of C-PON devices.

In DT6, the initial specification of the C-PON control software was given along with the simulation of ONOS controller which was been proposed to implement the C-PON control software. In DT12, ONOS was leveraged to implement a software defined network (SDN) controller (i.e., control software) for the C-PON testbed. Consequently, coordination of communication within the C-PON cell and between cells  in  the  C-PON  platform  is  attained  using  C-PON  control  protocols  and  an  open-source  SDN controller which can also be fully developed at commercial grade.

The optical line manager (OLM) is a physical hardware of the C-PON platform that supports intracell and inter-cell connectivity. The OLM performs a range of physical, packet forwarding and logical functions  in  the  C-PON  platform.  The  logical  functions  of  the  OLM  comprise  control  plane  and management  plane functions which provide the intelligence that dictates how  end-to-end communication is performed over physical connectivity in the C-PON platform.

The advanced specification of the OLM and its physical components was reported in DT5. In DT5, the design of the OLM leveraged the chassis of an x86 server to support the installation of multiple CPON cards and an open-source control software. Subsequently, joint tests of the C-PON card and OLM in the C-PON testbed was performed in DT13.

The C-PON cell is the smallest modular unit that can be operated alone. A C-PON cell is constructed by  integrating  C-PON functional  elements.  Such  elements  include  the  servers, racks,  the  OLM,  the control software, the C-PON fabric and the backplane.

The specification of a generic C-PON cell was given in DT16 along with an initial specification of CPON cell testbed. Subsequently, the C-PON cell testbed has been implemented and tested in DT13. The successful development of the C-PON cell provides a demonstration prototype which can be deployed in  field  trials  and  can  demonstrate  the  value  proposition  of  C-PON  to  attract  venture  funds.  The constructed  demonstrator  prototype  is  suitable  for  fog  and  edge  processing  context.  The  edge processing demonstrator has also been fitted with monitoring and measurement devices to collect important metrics such as latency and power consumption. Additionally, jitter and packet loss, which are two critical metrics for evaluating the quality of user experience, are also collected.

The technical activities of the ECOICE project, which have led to the development of the C-PON testbed, have captured and demonstrated the core functionalities of various elements of the C-PON platform. Although each component is not in its final size or form factor, the technical activities has enabled the construction of key components of the C-PON technology into independent products. By

achieving the set-out goals of the technical development activities, the objective of moving the C-PON technology from TRL3 to TRL6 has been achieved.

Commercial  deliverables  in  the  ECOICE  project  are  focused  on  use  cases  identification, development, and demonstration in collaboration with industry partners i.e., blue-chip partners. The outcomes  of  commercial  engagements  and  use  case  development  with  industrial  partners  are expected  to  inform  and  focus  technical  development  activities  and  to  prepare  for  use  case demonstration in the form of a field trial.

During the ECOICE project, commercial engagements were conducted in parallel with technical development. These commercial engagements focused on use cases development. This entails the identification of candidate applications and the selection of appropriate use cases of such applications where the C-PON technology can be deployed to demonstrate its value propositions. By collaborating with  Vodafone,  the  initial  and  advance  specifications  of  three  candidate  use  cases  for  C-PON deployment  were  captured  along  with  the  requirements  for  such  use  cases  in  DC1  and  DC2 respectively. These candidates use cases include edge processing use cases of smart manufacturing, smart  healthcare,  and  vehicular  communication.  In  DC3,  the  smart  manufacturing  use  case  was selected as the first use case to be considered for development. Furthermore, DC3 also reported the outcomes of commercial engagements with BT where the augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) applications and their adoption for events streaming in smart stadiums was introduced as the second use case to be considered of C-PON development. The advanced specification of AR/VR-assisted events streaming in smart stadiums was presented in DC5. DC7 outlined plans developed with BT to showcase the AR/VR-assisted viewing in smart stadiums as a use case of the C-PON technology in smart buildings.

Use case development activities in collaboration with BT and Vodafone has enabled the realisation of the ECOICE project goal of co-developing of the C-PON platform with blue chip partners. Both bluechip  organisations  have  suggested  exemplar  use  cases  that  the  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  is being optimised for. The suggested use cases require high data rates, low latency, or high resilience. Hence, providing ideal applications for evaluating C-PON technology whose key features include high data rate, low latency, and high resilience.

In DFT2, trial scenario and use-cases selections were performed based on the outcomes of use case  development  and  commercial  engagements  with  industrial  partners.  The  adoption  of  AR/VR application for enhanced event streaming in smart stadium was selected as the use case of choice for the C-PON field trial. The use-case (i.e., AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadium) selected in DFT2 has informed the testing, refinement, and optimisation of the C-PON demonstrator prototype implemented in DT13 in preparation for the field trial of the C-PON technology (as discussed later in

this report). The use case demonstration which will be conducted as a field trial provides an avenue for the validation of C-PON component, systems, and subsystem with industrial partners. Measurement and data collected during trial is also expected to inform the optimisation and adjustments of the design of the demonstrator prototype for selected use cases and applications.

Through commercial engagements with established blue-chip partners, use cases specific to the CPON  technology  have  been  identified  and  developed.  The  use  case  demonstration  which  will  be implemented as a field trial will promote deeper engagements with leading blue-chip organisations such as BT and Vodafone.

text: Over the last 24 months of the ECOICE project, 7 work packages (i.e., work packages WP1 to WP7) and  a  total  of  16  deliverables  including  5  commercial  deliverables,  2  field  trial  deliverables  and  9 technical deliverables have been completed. The work packages completed in the ECOICE project has taken  the  C-PON  technology  from  TRL3  to  TRL6  and  has  made  the  C-PON  technology  to  be  very attractive to private venture funds by providing a prototype that enables third parties to validate both business and technical propositions of the C-PON technology. While this section has summarised both technical development activities and commercial engagements performed in the ECOICE project prior to this quarter (i.e., Q3, 2023), the succeeding section of this report presents the result of the joint testing of all components of the C-PON demonstrator prototype which is at TRL6. Thereafter, the report presents updates on the full feature field trial of a selected use case of the candidate application which was identified in collaboration with our industry partners.

In this section, we provide detailed report on the joint tests of the fundamental components of the C-PON testbed. Initially, a brief review of the C-PON testbed is given before potential enhancements that can improve the performance of the C-PON testbed are outlined and discussed. Subsequently, we report the outcome of a range of tests that show the effectiveness of the refined C-PON testbed in handling traffic. Finally, we report on the reliability and resilience of the C-PON testbed and conduct a series of tests that show the reaction of the C-PON cell during a range of network failure scenarios.

This section briefly reviews the state of the C-PON testbed prior to this quarter. The C-PON testbed, as presented in Figure 1, is a primary technical achievement of the ECOICE project. At a high level, the C-PON testbed comprise the following physical components:

- Two Racks: Two steel frames are utilised to accommodate the servers, network devices, cables, and other equipment. Server are distributed over the two racks. The first rack contains three servers while the second rack consists of two servers.
- Five Servers: The servers within each rack in the C-PON testbed are divided into two categories i.e.,  relay  servers  and  normal  servers.  In  contrast  to  normal  servers,  relay  servers  have additional responsibility of forwarding traffic from adjacent servers within the rack to other servers in different racks or to the OLM. Each server is equipped with one or more U25 Xilinx smart NIC and optical transceivers.
- Optical Line Manager (OLM): The OLM is implemented by leveraging the chassis of a server as illustrated in Figure 1. However, a special software (i.e., the control software) is installed in server to coordinate the traffic exchange within the C-PON testbed. The OLM also has a direct link to one of relay server in each rack. Such link is responsible for conveying the regular traffic as well as in-band signalling for coordination and control.
- Optical  Fibre: Optical  fibre  provides  physical  media  that  are  employed  to  enable  inter-rack connectivity between servers in the C-PON testbed as well as server-to-OLM connectivity.
- Backplane: The backplane is an integral component of the C-PON cell that provides an exclusive intra-rack  fabric  between  the  servers  within  each  rack.  A  mesh  topology  of  optical  fibre  is utilised to represent a passive optical backplane in the C-PON testbed.

Figure 1: Physical Architecture of the C-PON Testbed.

<!-- image -->

The C-PON testbed was refined for enhanced performance. The initial refinement of the C-PON testbed focused on the optimisation of the C-PON card. The C-PON card is a programmable network interface card (NIC) that is attached to the servers to perform networking functions and is also a key component of the OLM. This section provides details of refinements performed to C-PON testbed via the optimisation of the C-PON cards.

Memory fine-tuning is a process that involves optimising memory settings to enhance network performance, efficiency, isolation, and resource utilisation. Such tuning in the configuration of the Xilinx U25 smart NICs improves the efficiency of the C-PON cards. The Xilinx U25 support two memory models, namely, shared memory model and per-port memory model.  A brief description of each model is provided as follows.

- Shared Memory Model : In the shared memory model, all ports on the SmartNIC concurrently share  a  memory  pool.  This  arrangement  simplifies  memory  management  by  centralising resources  and  allows  dynamic  allocation  of  the  resources  based  on  demand  and  hence, maximises resource utilisation. However, this model lacks isolation. This is noticeable if a single port requires intensive operations which can adversely affect the utilised resources of other ports. Additionally, when multiple ports access the shared memory simultaneously, a possibility of contention for resources arises which may potentially lead to inevitable bottlenecks.

- Per-Port Memory Model : In the per-port memory model, each port within the SmartNIC has its own dedicated memory resources which offers several advantages. Such dedicated resources provide  strong  isolation  which  ensures  that  each  port  operates  independently  within  its allocated memory space, and therefore enhances security and reliability. Moreover, this model facilitates  predictable  performance  since  each  port  operates  with  its  memory  resources, minimising contention, and leading to more consistent performance. However, applying this model may increase the complexity associated with managing memory resources for individual ports,  which  requires  careful  allocation  and  monitoring.  Furthermore,  there  is  a  risk  of inefficient resource utilisation if some ports do not fully utilise their dedicated memory, leading to resource wastage.

The implementation of the C-PON cards in previous ECOICE reports employed a shared memory model. However, in this report the per-port memory model is adopted. We utilise a per-port model in the refined  implementation  of  the  C-PON  testbed,  since  it  offers  high  security,  predictable performance,  and  robust  resource  allocation.  Additionally,  employing  per-port  model  leads  to separating the receiving (rx) queues into two queues. Such queues serve as dedicated pipelines for data moving out of the SmartNIC. The use of separate queues enhances control over data flow, facilitates efficient prioritisation of tasks, and enables the implementation of quality of service (QoS) features.

Furthermore,  selecting  an  appropriate  buffer  size  is  a  critical  aspect  of  memory  fine-tuning  in SmartNICs. Therefore, the size of the buffer is updated to be aligned with the per-port model. The buffer size is upgraded from 1024 bytes to 2048 bytes. This size is a balance between efficient memory utilisation and the ability to handle data bursts effectively.

Furthermore,  selecting  an  appropriate  buffer  size  is  a  critical  aspect  of  memory  fine-tuning  in SmartNICs. Therefore, the size of the buffer is updated to be aligned with the per-port model. The buffer size is upgraded from 1024 bytes to 2048 bytes. This size is a balance between efficient memory utilisation and the ability to handle data bursts effectively. Smaller buffers can reduce latency but might struggle to cope with sudden spikes in data volume, while larger buffers can efficiently manage bursts but may lead to excessive memory utilisation. The 2048-byte buffer size aims to provide a well-rounded solution suitable for various network conditions and requirements.

In previous setup of the C-PON testbed, the lookup process matches the packets based on all matching fields. However, a more efficient approach is applied to optimise the match-action lookup process and to speed up data handling. This approach involves matching mainly with IPv4 and MAC fields  and  disregarding  other  matching  fields.  By  concentrating  only  on  these  IPv4  and  MAC  fields, SmartNICs can expedite decision-making, reduce processing latency, and enhance overall operational efficiency. By exclusively considering IPv4 and MAC matches, SmartNICs can rapidly identify packets that require specific treatment based on these essential attributes. This approach proves particularly advantageous in scenarios where rapid packet classification and routing decisions are crucial, such as data centres, network accelerators, and appliances managing high volumes of network traffic. This optimisation  not  only  accelerates  decision-making  but  also  reduces  the  computational  load  on SmartNICs, resulting in lower processing overhead and decreased power consumption. Additionally, it enhances the scalability of SmartNIC-based packet processing systems,  allowing them to efficiently handle growing network workloads with minimal latency.

text: This  section  presents  the  results  obtained  when  joint  tests  are  conducted  after  applying  the proposed refinements to the C-PON cards. To show the efficacy of such refinements, the results are compared with the previously reported results (i.e., in MS7). The evaluation metrics include latency, jitter, and packet loss.
headers: 3.4 Joint Tests of C-PON Testbed: C-PON Card Refinement

text:
We evaluated the end-to-end delay of the C-PON testbed, considering the refinements introduced to the implemented C-PON card design. The results show a significant improvement in the overall endto-end delay across the traffic loads spanning from 5 Gbps to 25 Gbps as indicated by the blue-line (i.e., C-PON OP) in Figure 2. This improvement reflects a substantial 41% reduction in end-to-end delay from the previously reported results as outlined by the red-line (i.e., C-PON).

Figure 2: End-to-end delay of C-PON testbed.

We evaluated the C-PON testbed by focusing on the jitter metric as illustrated in Figure 3. This assessment evaluates the performance of the C-PON testbed after the C-PON card design was refined and compares it to the performance of the C-PON testbed before refinement. The obtained results indicate a considerable reduction in jitter for the 10 Gbps traffic load, highlighting the effectiveness of the applied per-port memory model and other enhancements in the action-match look-up process. For other traffic loads, the results reflect a minimal improvement from the previously reported jitter results before the refinements were performed.

CÂ­PON is a high resilient, highly reliable platform for cloud or edge data centres (DCs). Reliability and resilience  in  the  C-PON  platform  is  achieved  via  two  complementary  ways  i.e., via  the  control software and via the existence of multiple connection paths between servers. On the one hand, the control software of the C-PON platform is designed to effectively monitor network topology and to rapidly update forwarding tables to reflect and adjust to changes in the network topology. On the other hand, the reliability of the C-PON platform is facilitated by the existence of multiple routes between servers. This ensures seamless traffic transmission regardless of failure(s) in the network.

Network  failure  refers  to  breakdown  or  disruption  of  communication  within  the  networks. Mitigation of the effects of network failures is crucial to ensure continuous and reliable communication. Network failures can be divided into two main types: node failures and link failures. Each type is briefly described as follows.

- -Node  Failure: In  the  C-PON  platform,  this  entails  the  failure  of  servers,  the  OLM,  or  the backplane.
- o Server Failure: The impact of a server failure on the network depends on the type of server. There are two types of servers in the C-PON testbed i.e., normal servers and relay servers.
- Normal Server: The impact of the failure of a normal server is minimal since such a  failure  can  be  isolated  to  the  failed  normal  server.  This  is  because  normal servers have no direct links with other servers or with the OLM.
- Relay Server: Relay servers have direct connections with the OLM or with servers in adjacent racks. Therefore, the failure of a relay server has a direct impact on other elements of the cell. If a relay server goes down, all links directly attached to the failed relay server are directly impacted.  However,  the  physical architecture of the C-PON platform enables communication to be maintained using alternative routes.
- o OLM Failure: OLM is the brain of the C-PON cell. Therefore, an OLM failure affects all cells that are connected to that OLM. An OLM failure leads to the failure of all links connecting that OLM to servers in affected cells. Furthermore, the forwarding tables of network  nodes  will  not  be  updated  when  changes  occur  in  the  network  topology. Likewise, servers impacted by an OLM failure cannot interact with servers in other cells or send traffic to the internet. However, communication between servers within the same cell can be maintained via alternative routes provided that no other components has  failed.  To  further  improve  the  C-PON  platform  in  the  future,  a  consideration  of additional backup OLM can be introduced. Alternatively, a replica (or replicas) of the control  software  can  be  embedded  into  one  (or  more  than  one)  of  the  servers  to maintain the network in case of the failure of the main control software.
- o Backplane Failure: The backplane is an essential component that connect servers within the same rack. Backplane failure leads to the loss of communication between the servers in the same rack.

We evaluate the reliability/resilience of the C-PON platform via several test scenarios that show the impact of the link failures on communication within the C-PON cell. The failure scenarios considered include intra-rack link failure, inter-rack link failure and combination of intra-rack and inter-rack link failure. These scenarios are selected to demonstrate the ability of the C-PON platform to recalculate and adjust network routes to changes in the network topology.
headers: 3.6 Joint Tests of C-PON Testbed: Resilience

text:
This scenario aims to demonstrate the resilience of the C-PON platform when link failure occurs in one or more intra-rack link i.e., links that interconnect servers in the same rack. A range of intra-rack link failure scenarios are possible in a large deployment of the C-PON platform. However, only two (i.e., single and two) intra-rack link failure scenarios are considered for the constructed C-PON testbed. The test steps for both failure scenarios are as follows:

- The traffic generator is connected to the C-PON testbed to send traffic load during the test. The input port of the traffic generator is attached to (a port of the C-PON card) in S4 and the output port is connected to (a port of the C-PON in) S6 as illustrated in Figure 2.
- Subsequently, traffic is sent from the input of the traffic generator to the output port via the C-PON testbed.
- Traffic exchange (between the input and output ports of the traffic generator) via the C-PON tested is verified and the communication path through the C-PON testbed is identified.
- The dedicated direct link(s) between intra-rack servers is(are) physically disconnected to introduce link failure in rack 2.
- Traffic exchange via the C-PON tested is verified and the new communication path via the C-PON testbed is identified.

This scenario shows the impact of a single link failure on the functionalities of the C-PON cell. The link connecting S4 and S6 is disconnected to introduce a single link failure as illustrated in Figure 2. Testing of the single link failure scenario is conducted while sending traffic load between the two ports of the traffic generator.

Figure 5: Single link failure test scenario in C-PON testbed (S4-S6).

<!-- image -->

Figure 6: Single link failure test scenario in C-PON testbed (S5-S6).

<!-- image -->

Our observations revealed that upon detection of the disconnected link by the control software using the Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) discovery packets, it seamlessly steered the traffic through an indirect backup link between S4 and S6 (i.e., S4-S5-S6). This action did not affect the

flow connection. Furthermore, the control software did not recompute a different forwarding route between S4 and S6 or insert new match-action table entries into the interconnected C-PON cards. This  dynamic  adjustment  ensured  the  seamless  redirection  of  traffic  along  the  backup  path between servers S4 and S6. The same behaviour has been observed when we repeated the single link failure test by disconnecting the link between S5 and S6 as shown in Figure 3 and Figure 5. Instead of the communication path in Figure 4, the C-PON card directed the traffic back to the primary direct link between S4 and S6 (i.e., link S4-S6) as illustrated in Figure 5.

Figure 7: Communication path via C-PON testbed as detected by the control software before single link (i.e., S5-S6) failure.

<!-- image -->

Figure 8: Communication path via C-PON testbed as detected by the control software after single link (i.e., S5-S6) failure.

<!-- image -->

Additionally, we monitored the input and output throughput of the injected traffic flow across two  traffic  loads  (i.e.,  2.5  Gbps  and  25  Gbps).  The  obtained  results  show  stable  throughput performance and minimal effect of the single link failure (faulty link) as shown in Figure 6 and Figure 7. Thus, demonstrating the resilience of the C-PON platform to single link failure with little or no performance degradation.

Figure 9: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 2.5 Gbps traffic load after single link failure.

<!-- image -->

Figure 10: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 25 Gbps traffic load after single link failure.

<!-- image -->

The demonstration of two links failure in the same rack in the current C-PON testbed is only feasible in the second rack (rack 2) as illustrated in Figure 8. Similar observation to the single link failure scenario can be made i.e., alternative route may imply higher number of hops as shown in Figure 9. Additionally, if both links connecting S4 and S5, and S5 and S6 are down, this will lead to S5 being completely disconnected from the network.

Figure 11: Two links failure test scenario in C-PON testbed (i.e., S4-S6 and S5-S6 failed).

<!-- image -->

Figure 12: Communication path via C-PON testbed as detected by the control software after two links (i.e., S4-S6 and S5-S6) failure.

<!-- image -->

The outcomes of the conducted intra-rack two links failure scenario of two traffic loads (2.5 Gbps and 25 Gbps) between the endpoints S4 and S6 are demonstrated in Figure 10 and Figure 11. Under 2.5  Gbps  traffic  load,  the  traffic  was  rerouted  through  the  inter-rack  route  (S4-S3-S1-S2-S6)  as alternative  route.  The  traffic  between  S4  and  S6  minimally  affected  by  the  links  failure  and  as  the connection was seamlessly restored as shown in Figure 10.

However, when higher traffic load (i.e., 25 Gbps) is considered under the two links failure scenario, considerable fall in the throughput is observed, as shown in Figure 11. The sharp fall in the throughput of 25 Gbps traffic load can be imputed to the large number of packets that in-transient during the control  software  alternative  route  computation  process  and  updating  the  flow  entries  of  the interconnected C-PON cards.

Figure 13: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 2.5 Gbps traffic load after two intrarack links failure.

<!-- image -->

Figure 14: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 25 Gbps traffic load after two intra-rack links failure.

<!-- image -->

This section demonstrates the resilience of the C-PON platform when inter-rack link failure occurs. Two inter-rack link failure scenarios (i.e., single link failure and two links failure) are considered for the C-PON testbed.

This scenario shows the impact of a single (inter-rack) link failure. The link that connects S1 to the OLM is disconnected to implement the single (inter-rack) link failure as illustrated in Figure 12. Such failure results to the selection of an alternative path for communication between S1 and other servers (or the OLM). A single inter-rack link failure can also occur when the dedicated link that connects two relay servers is severed. To demonstrate the resilience of the C-PON testbed under single inter-rack link failure, the test scenario illustrated in Figure 12 is implemented.

Figure 15: Single (inter-rack) link failure test scenario in C-PON testbed.

<!-- image -->

In this assessment, we initiated a controlled traffic load between two ports of the traffic generator. Specifically, we connected the input port of the traffic generator to one of the ports on the C-PON card located on server S1, while the output port was linked to the fourth port on the C-PON card of server S6. Subsequently, we verified the seamless flow of traffic between these input and output ports of the traffic  generator.  After  that,  we  physically  disconnected  the  link  between  server  S1  and  server  S3, denoted as the S1-S3 link, to introduce a single inter-rack link failure as illustrated in Figure 12.

Our observations demonstrated that as soon as the control software detected the severed link using  LLDP  discovery  packets,  it  promptly  recomputed  the  alternative  routes  between  the  two endpoints  and  initiated  updates  to  the  match-action  table  entries  on  the  active  C-PON  cards.  This dynamic adjustment ensured the rerouting of traffic along a newly established path between servers S1  and  S6.  The  newly  computed  route  is  visually  represented  in  Figure  13.  Importantly,  the disconnected  link  was  seamlessly  removed  from  the  reconstructed  flows  topology,  leading  to  a successful recovery of the inter-rack connection.

Figure 16: Communication path via C-PON testbed as detected by the control software after single inter-rack link (i.e., S1-S3) failure.

<!-- image -->

Additionally, we monitored the input and output traffic throughput across two traffic loads (i.e., 2.5 Gbps and 25 Gbps) applied during the test scenario as illustrated in Figure 14 and Figure 15. Our obtained  results  highlight  an  average  recovery  time  of  25  milliseconds  for  the  control  software  to compute and push updates to the C-PON cards, thereby restoring the flow connection.

Figure 17: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 2.5 Gbps traffic load after single interrack link failure.

<!-- image -->

Figure 18: Throughput of traffic sent via the C-PON testbed at 25 Gbps traffic load after single interrack link failure.

<!-- image -->

The implementation of two inter-rack links failure is not feasible in the current C-PON testbed. This is because such a setup will prevent the C-PON testbed's ability to maintain the connectivity between all servers within the cell. For example, Rack 1 is completely isolated when link S1-S3 and link S2-S3 are severed. Even worse, the OLM is isolated when link S1-S3 and link S3-S4 are severed. However, a scaled architecture may be able to endure the failure of two or more inter-rack links.

This scenario investigates CPON's resilience during the combined occurrence of intra-rack link and inter-rack link failures. Using the constructed C-PON testbed, failure of one inter-rack link (S2-S6) and an intra-rack  link  (S4-S6)  was  implemented as illustrated in  Figure  16.  The  outcome  of  the  test,  as illustrated in Figure 17, demonstrates C-PON ' s resilience under the combined occurrence of intra-rack and inter-rack link failure. However, it is important to highlight that under other scenarios where both intra-rack and inter-rack links fail concurrently, the testbed may become non-functional.

In this scenario, the input link of the traffic generator is connected to S2 port, and the output link is connected to the S6 port. Then we applied the traffic loads of 2.5 Gbps and 25 Gbps in C-PON testbed for the intra-rack and inter-rack links failure test scenario.  When the connection is initiated in the first

place between the endpoints S2 and S6, the traffic seamlessly flows through the direct link (S2-S6). Subsequently, we physically detached the direct inter-rack link (S2-S6) and the intra-rack link (S4-S6).

We noticed that the flows of both applied traffic loads are redirected through an indirect route (S2S1-S3-S4-S5-S6) when the control software detected the failed links. The resulting throughput of traffic sent  under  both  traffic  loads  (i.e.,  2.5  Gbps  and  25  Gbps)  are  illustrated  in  Figures  18  and  19, respectively.

Under both applied traffic loads, we observed that the recovery time gap is slightly higher than the inter-rack and intra-rack single link failure scenarios. This can be attributed to the centralised decision process of the control software that requires coordination between all interconnected C-PON cards across all active servers in both racks. However, the two-links failure scenario across different racks is an extreme resilience use case and it has shown that the C-PON architecture is capable to recover from failure and efficiently maintain the traffic flows within C-PON cell.

Figure 19: Combination of intra-rack and inter-rack link failures scenarios in C-PON testbed.

<!-- image -->

Figure 20: Communication path via C-PON testbed as detected by the control software after a combined failure of intra-rack and inter-rack links.

This section presents the measured power consumption of the C-PON testbed. The section also compares the measured power consumption of the C-PON setup (or testbed) with that of another setup which adopts the spine and leaf data centre network topology. The measured values highlight the superior performance of the C-PON setup over the spine and leaf setup. The measurements are taken under two scenarios, namely, inter-rack communication and intra-rack communication.

In the case of C-PON setup, the power consumption measurements encompass both the actively communicating servers  and  the  idle  servers  within  the  C-PON  cell.  On  the  other  hand,  the  power consumption of the spine and leaf setup include the spine switches, leaf switches, and the servers. The comparative  analysis  is  performed  under  varying  traffic  loads,  to  obtain  the  power  consumption measurements under different conditions.

Furthermore,  we  consider  different  utilisation  levels  for  the  spine  and  leaf  switches.  Such considerations  are  grounded  on  the  efficiency  of  these  switches  to  handle  substantial  volumes  of network traffic. It is important to note that the current setup comprises only of three servers in each rack  as shown in  Figure  21. Nevertheless, each leaf switch is designed to support and manage the network traffic of up to 48 active servers concurrently.

Figure 23: Spine and leaf setup.

<!-- image -->

The  power  consumption  values  of  the  servers  in  both  setups  are  obtained  through  XClarity controller  (XCC).  XCC  is  an  integrated  service  processor  found  in  Lenovo  ThinkSystem  servers.  It provides  advanced  service-processor  control, monitoring,  and  alerting  functions.  Amongst  its monitoring capabilities is the precise measurement of server power consumption. This feature enables real-time  insight  of  the  power  consumption  values  to  effectively  manage  and  optimise  the  energy efficiency of the servers.

The power consumption of the switches is acquired from the Junos operating system. To retrieve this  information,  a  command  is  employed  to  display  a  comprehensive  profile  of  the  hardware components within Juniper switches. Such information includes information about the installed power supply units including their type, status, load, and power usage.

Amongst others, a critical objective of the ECOICE project is the selection and demonstration of exemplar use cases for where the C-PON technology can be deployed. This section briefly reviews the selected exemplar application and the preferred use case of that application based on the outcomes of the commercial engagements with industry partners of the ECOICE project. The section also reports progress on the demonstration of selected use case of the AV/VR application in the anticipated fullfeature trial of the C-PON technology in network test sites of industry partners.

AR/VR applications comprise a group of applications that enable immersive experiences. These group of applications include augment reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) and 360/immersive video streaming. AR/VR applications are highly versatile applications with a wide range of use cases across multiple sectors such as retail  and  real  estate,  education  and  maintenance,  manufacturing, entertainment,  and  sport.  AR/VR  applications  deliver  convenient,  personalised,  enhanced,  and engaging  experiences  to  the  users  across  these  sectors.  Based  on  interactions  with  the  blue-chip partners of the ECOICE project, AR/VR applications and their use cases in stadium of the future and factory of the future provide excellent use cases to demonstrate the value propositions of the C-PON technology.

Next  generation  stadiums  are  expected  to  improve  fans  experience  by  creating  personalised services. Such improved experience can be achieved using AR and VR technologies which provide new ways of experiencing live sports events via AR/VR-assisted events viewing. The AR/VR-assisted event viewing in stadiums aims to deliver a memorable user-centric immersive experience of events. AR/VRassisted event viewing adopts extended reality (XR) technology to process captured contents from live events. These processed contents are subsequently sent back to fans at the location of the event to deliver memorable immersive experiences.

The architectural setup of AR/VR-assisted event viewing in stadiums, as illustrated in Figure 20, begins with distributed sensors (including IoT devices and cameras) which capture and encode video and  data  streams.  Subsequently,  the  ecosystem  leverages  network  infrastructure  to  transmit  the captured streams to a remote processing location at the edge of the network. In the edge computing pod, the captured and encoded content is decoded and stored prior to transformation of the collected data into insights by data analytics software and/or the rendering of video graphics by XR rendering software.  Furthermore,  a  multimedia  stitching  software  can  be  used  to  combine  processed  video, audio,  and  data  streams.  The  output  of  multimedia  stitching  is  subsequently  retransmitted  for presentation on smart end devices in the event arena to deliver enhanced experience to users (fans) in the stadium.

The  identification  and  selection  of  this  use  case  of  the  AR/VR  application  is  an  outcome  of commercial engagements with BT. The goal of demonstrating this AR/VR application in stadium of the future is the adoption of C-PON technology to provide edge computing capacity for AR/VR applications that enable enhanced experiences in the stadium of the future.

Likewise,  smart  glasses  and  similar  devices  can  optimise  fault diagnosis and maintenance and repairs tasks being undertaking by technician within factory premises. In  showcasing  the  AR/VR  use  case  within  our  C-PON  testbed,  we  conducted  a  comprehensive analysis of network traffic packet capture (PCAP) files for three distinct AR/VR applications. These PCAP files  contain the traced traffic between a single AR/VR headset (i.e., OCULUS Quest) and an AR/VR rendering server. Through the statistical analysis using Wireshark packet analyser, we observed that the AR/VR communicated traffic consists of UDP packets and 98% of these packets are encapsulated within frames ranging in size from 64 to 1280 bytes.

Next,  we  utilised  the  integrated  test  automation  tool  of  the  Xena  Valkyrie  traffic  generator  to replicate a customised traffic behaviour similar to the examined AR/VR network traffic. The replicated traffic behaviour is applied to the C-PON and spine and leaf testbeds to facilitate series of performance tests involving throughput, delay, jitter, and packet loss. These performance tests were conducted at both 50% and 100% link rates.

In this section, we present the obtained average delay results of the replicated AR/VR traffic in both C-PON, and spine-and-leaf testbeds and conduct a detailed comparative analysis at link rates of 50% and 100%, as illustrated in Figure 29 and Figure 30, respectively.

At  50%  link  rate,  relative  to  the  C-PON  testbed,  it  is  evident  that  the  spine-and-leaf  testbed demonstrated superior performance across all frame sizes. Specifically, the average delay in the spineand-leaf testbed was 2.7 microseconds, whereas the C-PON testbed exhibited an average delay of 30 microseconds.

At  100% link rate, we observed that the average delay of the spine-and-leaf testbed increased considerably across all frame sizes with average delay of 18 microseconds. At 64-byte frame size, the average delay of the C-PON is 16.9 microseconds which is lower than the average delay of the spineand-leaf testbed at the same frame size. However, as the frame sizes increased, there is a proportional increase in the average delay measured in C-PON testbed, as illustrated in Figure 30.

Despite the significant average delay margin between the C-PON and the spine-and-leaf testbeds, the C-PON testbed successfully met the RFC 2544 test benchmarks for the delay metric. Nonetheless,

there  remains  room  for  further  enhancement  and  optimisation,  bearing  in  mind  the  constraints imposed by the design platform (i.e., Xilinx U25 smart NIC) and power consumption limitations. This suggests potential avenues to further refine the C-PON testbed's performance despite these specified constraints.

In this section, we present the obtained average jitter results of the replicated AR/VR traffic in both C-PON, and spine-and-leaf testbeds and conduct a detailed comparative analysis of different frame sizes at link rates of 50% and 100% as illustrated in Figure 31 and Figure 32, respectively.

At 50% and 100% link rates, the spine-and-leaf testbed demonstrated superior performance across all frame sizes compared to the C-PON testbed. However, it is noticed that as frame sizes increased, the C-PON testbed exhibited a proportional increase in the average jitter.

While there exists a substantial difference in average jitter between the C-PON and spine-and-leaf testbeds, the C-PON testbed managed to meet the RFC 2544 test benchmarks for the jitter metric. However,  there  is  still  potential  for  improvement  and  optimisation,  taking  into  consideration  the limitations set by the design platform (i.e., Xilinx U25 smart NIC) and power consumption limitations. This  suggests  potential  avenues  to  further  refine  the  C-PON  testbed's  performance  despite  these specified constraints.

Packet  loss  assessment  was  conducted  within  the  C-PON  and  spine-and-leaf  testbeds  while considering the generated AR/VR traffic under various frame sizes. The results in 34 and Figure 35 revealed that a substantial incidence of packet loss was detected within the C-PON setup when the 64byte frame size is considered. In contrast, the spine-and-leaf setup exhibited small packet loss in 64byte frames and no discernible packet loss across other tested frame sizes.

We investigated the considerable packet loss incidence in the C-PON testbed for the case of 64byte frames. The outcome  of the investigation showed that  the  64-byte frame size represents the minimum ethernet frame size that contains only headers without the necessary minimum data size of 46 bytes that is required to process the frame using the current C-PON card pipelines. The C-PON card pipelines design will be further optimised to allocate and process similar non-standardised ethernet frames.

text: Over the course of the ECOICE project some challenges were encountered and mitigated. Several lessons were also learned during the ECOICE which would inform and direct the development of the CPON technology to higher TRLs.

The  completion  of  all  tasks  and  deliverables  in  the  ECOICE  project  is  not  without  challenges. However,  the  team  of  engineers  on  the  project  were  able  to  mitigate  the  challenges  to  ensure successful completion of the ECOICE project. Some notable challenges are discussed as follows.

- Impact of COVID19 on Supply Chain: The purchase of hardware required to implement the project was delayed because of the impact of COVID19 pandemic on the supply chain. This caused over 6 months delay in the implementation timeline of the project. However, Ultracell 's implementation  engineers  were  able  to  mitigate  this  challenge  by  progressing  technical development activities via simulation and emulation of the expected architectural setup of the C-PON  technology.  This  approach  expedited  the  implementation  of  C-PON  technology  on physical hardware when purchased hardware eventually arrived.
- Cost  of  Hardware :  Cost  FPGA  NIC  cards  and  compatible  servers  was  higher  than  the  price quoted in project proposal. Consequently, we have had to reduce size of the demonstration prototype constructed as part of the ECOICE project to stay within the project ' s budget.
- Commercial  Availability  of  Implementation  Hardware: Optical  polymer  backplane  was  a leading  backplane  solution  desired  for  implementation  of  C-PON  technology.  However,  the optical polymer backplane is not commercially available. Hence, we had to resort to the use of a  full  mesh  fibre  optic  system  to  implement  a  makeshift  optical  backplane  for  the  C-PON demonstrator.  Additionally,  optical  circuit  switches  which  offers  an  alternative  backplane solution were also not readily available in the market.
- Availability of Xilinx U25 SmartNIC : During the ECOICE project, the Xilinx was acquired by AMD. The acquisition might have led to the production of the Xilinx U25 SmartNIC being discontinued. However, we were able to mitigate this situation  by working closely with  our partners and suppliers to stockpile the smart NIC cards in the required quantity.
- Timeline for Field Trials: The  timeline  proposed for  field  trials  with  commercial  partners  as proposed in the project proposal proved inadequate during the project implementation phase. This is because some commercial partners such as Vodafone wanted a trial period of six months (for the C-PON demonstration testbed in their network sites). Likewise, BT preferred that an academic journal article be completed to obtain much needed buy-in from BT engineers before

a  trial  can  be  initiated.  To  mitigate  these  challenges,  a  trial  is  being  conducted  at  Ultracell Networks lab. The trial mimics potential trial scenarios discussed with our commercial partners. This in-house trial has helped to provide data that will be reported in the journal paper being requested by BT and will help to obtain much needed buy-in for a field trial at a future date. Similarly, the same data will be presented to Vodafone to motivate further interest in trials which will be conducted after the current milestone of the project.

Several  invaluable  lessons  have  been  learned  in  the  development  of  C-PON  technology  in  the ECOICE project. These lessons are summarised as follows.

- Need to Refactor Development Hardware: FPGA capacity in C-PON card is over provisioned for required functions that the C-PON card performs in C-PON platform. Likewise, the adoption of a  x86  server  chassis  to  implement  an  OLM  comes  with  overheads.  Since,  several  intrinsic components  of  a  generic  server  are  not  required  to  implement  the  OLM.  Hence,  such development hardware needs to be refactored as the C-PON technology is developed into its final size for commercial deployment. Such refactoring would reduce power consumption and cost of the individual components of the C-PON technology and the collective cost and power consumption of C-PON platforms that are deployed at the edge and in the cloud.
- Leveraging of Open-Source Technologies: The development of the C-PON technology in the ECOICE project leveraged open-source technologies by adopting the P4 language and the ONOS. The P4 language, which is an open source, domain-specific programming language for network devices, was used to develop the C-PON cards which are placed in servers and in the OLM. In a similar manner, the ONOS which is an open-source SDN controller was leveraged to implement the control software for the C-PON platform. Both open-source technologies proved effective for  the  implementation  of  the  C-PON  technology  in  the  ECOICE  project.  Hence,  such technologies will be explored further as the C-PON technology development is advanced to higher TRLs.
- Prototyping in Software: The use of emulator and simulators to develop prototypes of the CPON testbed prior to implementation on physical hardware enabled seamless development of the C-PON platform. Emulators and simulators provide platforms for development and testing prior to implementation in physical hardware. As the C-PON technology development advances to higher TRLs, this approach will be maintained as much as possible.
- Strict  Procurement  Policy: Early  in  the  ECOICE  project,  a  procurement  policy  to  ensure compatibility between purchased components was put in place for the project. Strict adherence to this policy ensured that the servers (Lenovo ThinkSystem SR665 servers) purchased were compatible with Xilinx U25 SmartNIC. Furthermore, compatible optical transceivers, optical and

DAC cables were also purchased. This procurement policy ensures minimal  funds and timer wastage  during  the  ECOICE  project.  Consequently,  this  strict  procurement  policy  will  be sustained as C-PON technology is developed to higher TRLs.

We are confident that we have understood and met the objectives and are providing a high quality, value-based report that meets the requirements as defined in the project. In summary:

- We achieved the first technical deliverable (i.e., DT1 Within WP1) which is for the initial draft specification  of  the  C-PON  card  to  be  implemented  on  FPGA).  We  defined  the  required functional block to perform traffic forwarding in the C-PON platform. This is to be implemented through P4 FPGA programming to the C-PON card. We furthermore provide initial identification of the required functional blocks of the C-PON controller (i.e., the OLM) to perform routing and control  functions  and  identified  resilience  and  load  balancing  features  for  C-PON.  We  also defined a development plan with five stages to implement the C-PON platform progressively in the ECOICE project.
- We achieved the first commercial deliverable (i.e., DC1 Within WP6) which is for the Initial draft specification of the first use case with Vodafone or BT on edge processing for applications such as Ultra Reliable Low Latency (URLL) IoT or vehicular use cases. We engaged with Vodafone and identified  three  key  edge  processing  use  cases  for  C-PON  which  are  smart  factory,  smart healthcare and vehicular communication. We provide the initial descriptions of these use cases.

This  ambitious  programme  will  directly  contribute  towards  UK  becoming  a  low-carbon  economy enabling data center and network operators to manage their energy usage, reduce costs and reduce carbon emissions.  In this regard, it is of critical national importance.

This document forms a detailed report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 1 st October 2021 to 15 th   January 2022, focused on the first technical and commercial deliverables. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section 2 gives an overview of C-PON.
- Section 3 describes the deliverables of ECOICE.
- Section 4 discusses the first technical deliverable; specifically on developing a C-PON card.
- Section  5 provides  details  of  further  technical  progress  and  the  proposed    C-PON  platform development plan.
- Section 6 details the first commercial deliverable and focuses on developing the draft(s) of CPON platform use cases based on the initial interaction with Vodafone.

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that contains a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between servers in cloud and edge computing Data Centres (DCs).

The  C-PON  fabric  leverages  optical  communication,  passive  optical  devices,  and  smart  Network Interface Cards (NICs) to enable high bandwidth, low latency, and resilient communication between the servers in DCs.

The C-PON network fabric offers adaptable network services to support end-to-end communication between node pairs in the DC. Other features of the C-PON platform include load-balancing, resilience, control and orchestration, and a scalable cellular physical architecture, where the DC will be composed of several units, also known as cells. These cells can be used at different scales to serve different use cases of cloud and edge processing applications.
This section briefly introduces C-PON and lists the definitions of terminologies used in this report to describe different elements of C-PON.

Passive  Optical  Networks  (PONs)  provide  energy  efficiency,  high  capacity,  low  cost,  low  latency, scalability, and highly resilient and elastic connectivity.

C-PON is based on novel PON interconnects, proposed to support connectivity inside modern cloud DCs and in edge processing and fog computing implementations.

Today's DCs  typically  use  layers  of  expensive,  power  hungry  core  and  aggregation  switches;  by replacing  those  layers  with  C-PON  technology,  Ultracell  Networks  Ltd  aims  to  offer  the  same advantages as residential access PONs while adopting several enhancements specifically suited for DC environments. For example:

- Offering effective intra-rack connections between servers and inter-rack connections between servers in different racks.
- Multiple connections between different servers to reduce bottlenecks and increase resilience.
- C-PON utilises customised Medium Access Control (MAC) protocols to provide the symmetric link speeds demanded by server-to-server traffic in DCs.

C-PON platforms have a cellular structure where several racks are bundled as a C-PON cell, and several cells construct the C-PON platform.

Figure 1: C-PON Cell components.

<!-- image -->

Figure 1 shows an example of a C-PON cell with 4 racks and illustrates the components of the cell. In each  rack,  several  servers  are  connected  through  a  backplane.  Each  server  is  equipped  with  a programmable Network Interface Card (NIC), a.k.a. C-PON card, to enable the communications with the servers in the other racks through a C-PON fabric. The C-PON fabric allows multiple redundant, reconfigurable, direct, high-bandwidth routes between the servers.

The structure of the C-PON fabric allows the C-PON platform to be scaled-up efficiently to hundreds of thousands of servers while mostly using passive optical devices. The structure also enables on-demand addition of extra 'cells' enabling a 'pay -as-yougrow' model. Figure 2: C-PON cellular architecture and interconnection of  cells  via  the  OLM. shows a scaled-up C-PON platform with several C-PON cells interconnected through the C-PON fabrics of the cells.

Figure 2: C-PON cellular architecture and interconnection of cells via the OLM.

<!-- image -->

Controlling  the  traffic  flow  in  C-PON  platforms  is  performed  through  a  programmable  intelligent controller, a.k.a. the Optical Line Manager (OLM), connected to the C-PON cells. The OLM provides key functions such as load balancing, resilient routing, network and processing slicing while integrating the C-PON cells and interfacing the C-PON platform with high-speed optical core routers linking to cloud DCs and the Internet.

C-PON technology is patented [1]-[5] via:

1. UK  patent  number:  GB1421014.0,  27  November  2014  (GB1421014.0,  PCT/GB2015/053604, WO2016083812A1).
2. US patent number: US10498450B2, 3 December 2019 (US20170324480A1).
3. China patent number CN107210837B, 9 August 2019.
4. EU patent number EP3224972A1, 22 September 2021.
5. Japan patent number JP6675400B2, 1 April 2020.

The patent includes several designs for the intra-rack PON and the inter-rack PON (i.e., the C-PON fabric) as shown in Figure 3 .

The  different  designs  utilise  different  passive  devices  to  suit  different  operational  scenarios  and networking requirements. Intra-rack PON (i.e., the backplane) can be a star coupler, a Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) that reflects selected wavelengths between servers, or a multimode polymer waveguide that provides non-blocking full mesh connectivity with 10 Gb/s -100 Gb/s and beyond data rates per waveguide [1], as can be seen in Figure 3 (d), (e) and (f), respectively. An active programmable optical switch can be also used as a backplane.

The C-PON fabric can use one of three main designs as shown in Figure 3 . All three designs provide additional  passive  links  between  the  servers  and  hence  reduce the  need  to  forward  the  DC traffic through the OLM which reduces the power consumption and delay.

The design in Figure 3 (a) utilises direct links between the racks and utilises the C-PON cards to forward the traffic. This design is categorised as a servercentric design and is described as 'option 5' in the patent. The features this design offers are low-cost, low power consumption, and high-resilience due to the availability of several alternative routes between the servers in the C-PON cell.

The design in Figure 3 (b) utilises passive routing devices known as Arrayed Waveguide Grating Routers (AWGRs). An AWGR is a wavelength router that uses multiple wavelengths to interconnect its outputs and inputs by following a specific wavelength routing  pattern. This design, described as 'option 3' in the patent, offers the features of low power consumption, high-performance, high-throughput and low-latency due to having only passive hops between the servers in the C-PON cell and the OLM. This design requires tuneable transceivers in the C-PON card, which increases the costs and hence, this design suits the applications that involve high computational workloads and require high performance.

The third design in Figure 3 (c) , described as 'option 4' in the patent, is a hybrid design that uses AWGRs, gateway servers, and tuneable lasers only at the gateway servers. This design reduces the costs while offering an intermediate level of performance between the two other architectures.

text:
ECOICE has seven highly inter-related work packages to move from TRL3 to TRL6:

- WP1  Developing  the  C-PON  Card: focuses  on  programming  the  C-PON  cards  to  achieve communication in the C-PON cell. The communication software can be implemented in a Net-FPGA card or the recent Xilinx Smart NIC platform developed for Xilinx by Solarflare offering up to 100 Gb/s. Currently the C-PON communication and control software is implemented in the operating system of the servers in our lab. This is slow and is not the product to be sold. This activity requires programming of the FPGA chip in the C-PON card to offload networking functions from the servers.
- WP2 Developing the OLM : The Optical Line Manager (OLM) terminates signals from the cards in the different servers. FPGA and software development is needed. The OLM functions are implemented now in the operating system of the servers in the current demo. This workpackage aims to develop a complete control software for the OLM at commercial grade in one or more networked FPGA based NICs.
- WP3 C-PON cell development :  There are three main C-PON cell architectures and each requires different  FPGA  programming  of  the  card  and  the  OLM.  One  cell  architecture  provides  high performance and calls for fast tuneable transceivers and AWGRs, which are commercially available. The second cell architecture is a low-cost high resilience architecture. The third cell architecture is a compromise. Each architecture is better suited to a different use case. This work package focuses on customization of development activities for C-PON cards and OLM according to cell architecture chosen and use case parameters and requirements.
- WP4 Control  Software :  This  development  will  be  guided  by  the  use  cases.  The  software  in  its simplest form will provide interfaces between C-PON cards and OLM. More sophisticated versions will enable C-PON cells to be joined together through the OLM to enable processing to be moved (i.e., a heavily loaded C-PON cell borrows servers from nearby C-PON cells). Other features of the software  will  enable  slicing  and  will  allow  C-PONs  to  interface  with  BT  (and  other)  slicing  / virtualisation software.
- WP5 Optical Backplane Development : This will be built using Fibre Bragg Gratings (FBG) which are commercially available and transceivers whose wavelength is reflected by the FBG, with time slots added to enable different size flows to be supported. The software that controls the backplane will be embedded in the C-PON card FPGA. The current demo uses an electronic switch to provide the backplane in each rack.
- WP6 Commercial development :  This  will  be  sub-contracted; however, the subcontractor will be linked to our industrial collaborators and to our wider set of C-PON industrial contacts. The focus will be on the companies we have already engaged with so far including BT, Vodafone, Cisco, Orange, and othersÍ¾ to identify 1 -2 use cases that become the focus of the commercial customisation of CPON in ECOICE.

The development of C-PON card focuses on programming the FPGA in the smart NICs to implement certain functionalities and subsequently developing an Ultracell Networks C-PON card. However, the focus  of  this  technical  deliverable  is  the  initial  draft  specification  of  the  C-PON  card  which  will  be implemented on FPGA. C-PON card (i.e., the server NIC) development is being performed on Xilinx Smart NIC platform. The Xilinx smartNIC comprises of a programmable FPGA and network interfaces. Examples of Xilinx smart NICs are shown in Figure 6 .

text:
C-PON card functionalities includes the following.

- Transmission of traffic from source node to intermediate and/or destination nodes.
- Receiving traffic from intermediate and/or source node.
- Relaying of traffic at intermediate nodes.
- Additionally, the C-PON card may support control plane functionalities in the C-PON fabric by collecting control information and sending them to the centralised controller/orchestrator (i.e., the OLM) in the C-PON platform.

The primary functions of the C-PON card are implemented by the forwarding block of the C-PON fabric. Each  C-PON  card  implements an  instance  of  the  forwarding  block  of  the  C-PON  fabric.  A  practical implementation of the forwarding block ( Figure 7 ) can be achieved by programming the FPGA in the smart NIC using P4 language i.e., a programming language for controlling the forwarding plane in the router, switches and smart NICs. P4 language architecture described the following P4-programmable blocks that can be that can run on vendor specific compilers.

- Parser: This is a parsing engine that reads and decodes packet headers and extracts headers from packets.
- Lookup/Match pipeline: finds the appropriate instructions within the LUT (lookup table) for each packet according to the header information.
- Action pipeline: performs the appropriate action for the packet. It is a control block that can modify header and control data (or metadata).
- Deparser: This control block specifies the order that header should be deparsed back into the packet.

It is also important to note that metadata which includes control and signalling information such as link utilization and latency can be collected and/or updated as packets pass through the forwarding block.

text:
Three primary blocks are needed for effective communication and control in the C-PON fabric.

- Control Block.
- Routing Block.
- Forwarding Block.

Given specified inputs, each block performs specific functions and gives specific outputs to other blocks or subsystems in the C-PON fabric. The control and routing blocks are implemented in the OLM while the forwarding block is implemented in the C-PON cards as shown in Figure 9 . Possible implementations of the blocks using P4 programming are as follows:

Figure 9: Functional Blocks of the C-PON Card.

<!-- image -->
headers: 5.1.1 Primary Functional Blocks of the C-PON Fabric

text:
Functions: the function of the control block includes:

- Collection and processing of network telemetry.
- Issuance of network optimisation trigger to routing block (where traffic engineering, flow control, congestion control, load balancing and resilience policies are implemented).

Inputs: The primary input to the control block is the network state. The network state comprises:

- Link utilisation.
- Latency.
- Physical path followed by flows (switch ID, NIC ID).
- Queue occupancy.

Outputs: Output of the control block include the following ( Figure 9 ):

- Network  telemetry  and  measurement  data:  sent  to  network  reporting  and  monitoring system for visualisation.
- Network optimisation triggers: sent to the routing block. It is assumed that the routing block is  also  responsible  for  implementing  load  balancing  and resilience  policies  in  the  C-PON fabric. Such triggers would correct, optimize, and adjust the network to match pre-defined policies.

P4 supports inband network telemetry (INT). 'INT is a framework designed to allow the collection and reporting of network state by the data plane without requesting intervention of the control plane'. INT can be leveraged to obtain network state in C-PON, but a control plane must be implemented to process  network  telemetry  and  to  transmit  network  triggers  and  network  measurement  data  in appropriate format.

INT supports the collection of network state such as link utilisation, latency, physical path followed by flows (switch ID, NIC ID) and queue occupancy.

Additionally, the control plane of CPON can use 'P4Runtime API' to control the forwarding plane of smart NICs in the CPON fabric. 'The P4Runtime API is a control plane specification for controlling the data plane elements of a device defined or described by a P4 program'.

Functions: Functions of the routing block include:

- Routing protocol implementation.
- End to end path identification.
- Routing table estimation based on routing metrics (bandwidth/delay/hop count/cost).

- Network telemetry provided by control block.

- Network topology.
- Network metrics.

Outputs: the outputs of the routing block include routing/forwarding tables as illustrated in Figure 9 :

- The table will be created by either inputting static paths, or by advertisements to collate all the possible paths between a single source and destination nodes.
- The routing protocol implemented will identify any future changes to the architecture based on triggers received from the control block and will update the forwarding table in each smart NIC accordingly.

Support for designing a specific architecture model for a certain device was introduced in the P4\_16 language  specifications.  Architecture  models  implemented  by  a  P4  device  vendor  are  required  to include specific blocks such as:

- Ingress Control Block: This block defines the routing table, as well as the actions to either drop the packet, forward the packet, or take no action. If the action was to forward the packet, then it will select the output port based on destination, forward to next hop and decrement the time to-live (TTL).
- Egress Control Block: This block contains two table:
- o Switching  table:  this  table  identifies  the  destination  MAC  address  based  on  the information from the routing table.
- o MAC rewriting table:  this  table  rewrites  the  source  MAC  address  depending  on  the output port.

Functions: The forwarding block is to be loaded into the smart NICs of the servers within C-PON. This block receives the traffic and directs the packets. Packets can be directed either to the port that leads to the next hop on the packet's assigned path (as defined in the look-up table) or to the hosting server of the smart NIC. The function to achieve this, as described within the P4 architecture model, are:

- Parser: Separates the payload from the header and perform certain functions to the packet headers.
- Match  pipeline:  to  find  the  appropriate  instructions  within  the  LUT  for  each  packet according to the header information.
- Action pipeline: perform the appropriate action for the packet.
- Deparser: Merges the new header and the payload to be either forwarded to another port or to be sent to the hosting server.

Inputs: Input to the forwarding blocks include:

- Packets: network packets comprising header and payload.

- Metadata: intermediate data generated as P4 program is implemented in P4 programmable network devices. For example, metrics on selected routing path which is updated according to predefined policies.
- Forwarding table/LUT: received from the control plane of the routing block.

Outputs:  Output  of  the  Forwarding  block  are  the  packets  and  metadata,  for  example,  any  metric required by the OLM for monitoring and control as illustrated in Figure 9 .
