text:
It is assumed that the OLM is the centralised orchestrator and controller that enforces routing, load balancing and resilience policies in the C-PON platform. Based on defined routing, load balancing and resilience policies, the OLM can create forwarding tables for each smart NIC in each server within the C-PON cell. These forwarding tables guide end-to-end flow/packet routing in the C-PON fabric.

The  OLM  is  also  responsible  for  the  collection  of  network  state  in  the  C-PON  platform  which  is processed  and  analysed  to  provide  inputs  for  network  optimisation  and  to  enable  visualisation  of network state for monitoring and reporting purposes. A practical implementation of OLM in C-PON platform  may  comprise  DC-level  controller,  cell-level  controller,  and  control  agents.  The  generic functions of each are given as follows:

- DC-Level Controller: Orchestration and  centralised control of independent  cell-level controllers in the DC.
- Cell-level Controller: Orchestration and control of independent control agent in each cell.
- Control  Agent:  Each  smart  NIC  in  C-PON  is  a  control  agent,  they  are  responsible  for forwarding control information and network state to cell-level controllers periodically.

It is important to note that the OLM may be implemented as a single device with multiple cards in a common chassis. For example, a set of cards in a single OLM device may jointly implement the DC-level controller  functions.  Another  set  of  cards  in  the  single  OLM  device  may  implement  the  cell-level controller functions where one of such cards is responsible for a cell in the C-PON platform.

A  generic  control  protocol  is  proposed  for  a  cell-level  control  in  the  C-PON  platform.  The  control protocol  adopts  a  centralised  routing  architecture  where  best  routes  through  the  network  are preconfigured centrally and are sent to all smart NICs in the C-PON fabric. Given, physical connectivity within a cell in the C-PON fabric, the control protocol as illustrated in Figure 10 operates as follows:
headers: 5.1.2 Generic Cell-Level Control Protocol for the C-PON Platform

text:
Figure 10: Cell-Level Control Protocol for C-PON Fabric.

<!-- image -->

- Step 1: OLM sets up in-band control channels to support control information exchange via the C-PON fabric.
- Step 2: OLM computes end to end routes for required data paths using an appropriate routing protocol.  End  to  end  route  computation  must  consider  defined  traffic  engineering,  load balancing and resilience policies.
- Step 3: OLM updates forwarding table on each smart NIC in the cell to implement optimal end to end routing for network traffic.
- Step 4: Smart NICs forwards traffic to next hop on C-PON fabric based on installed forwarding table until it reaches the intended destination.
- Step 5: Each smart NIC in the cell periodically reports the network state (NIC state and utilization and link state and utilisation) to the OLM via established control channels. The control agent in each smart NIC implements this function.

text:
- Step 6: Flows/packets between node pairs in the C-PON fabric are forwarded as defined by OLM routing and load balancing policies until session is completed i.e., all flows have been sent or until link failure notification is received.
- Step 7: If link failure notification is received, the OLM computes new end-to-end communication path(s) for each impacted network flow/request on each failed link.

text: Generally, it is best practice to load balancing network flows rather than individual packets. Hence, flow-based load balancing is proposed for the C-PON fabric. A network flow (or traffic flow or packet flow) is a sequence of packets that belong to a certain request/application from a source node to a destination node in a packet switching network. Three options are proposed for load balancing in the C-PON fabric:
headers: 5.1.3 Load balancing options for C-PON Fabric

text:
Selection of relay server based on smart NIC utilisation and link utilisation is one way of achieving load balancing in C-PON. As illustrated in Figure 11 , to implement this option, each smart NIC should report the state of it resources and links to the controller i.e., the OLM. The OLM would then perform the task of load balancing traffic based on the state of resources and links in the network topology by forwarding traffic on least congested links/paths. This approach is not workload specific. However, application in the DC can have different application requirements for their flows.

Figure 11: Load Balancing Based on Network State.

<!-- image -->
headers: 5.1.3.1 Load Balancing Based on Network State

text: Load balancing of traffic in C-PON can also be performed based on the cost of multipath in the C-PON fabric  as  estimated  by  routing  protocols  adopted  ( Figure  12 ).  For  example,  load  balancing  can  be
headers: 5.1.3.2 Load Balancing Based on Multipath Cost

text:
performed using equal cost multi-path (ECMP). ECMP is a standard load-balancing technique that can be  implemented  in  conjunction  with  most  routing  protocols  i.e.,  OSPF  and  BGP.  ECMP  randomly transmits flows on equal cost multipath to achieve load balancing. If multiple equal cost paths exist between a source and a destination node, ECMP randomly select a path from the list of equal cost paths on which to send each flow of the traffic that is being transmitted. However, multi-path between source and destination in C-PON are often not of equal cost. Hence, ECMP would only send flows through a single low-cost path in most instance. Consequently, a standard implementation of ECMP may be ineffective for load balancing in the C-PON fabric. Alternatively, load balancing through unequal  cost  multipath  (un-ECMP)  could  be  supported.  Hence,  enabling  utilization  of  all  multipath available between communicating nodes pairs in the C-PON fabric. Finally, weighted cost multipath (WCMP) can also be considered to achieve load balancing over the C-PON fabric.

Figure 12: Load Balancing Based on Multipath Cost.

<!-- image -->
headers: UltraCell Networks Ltd -In Strictest Commercial Confidence

text: Both  multipath  cost  and  network  state-based  load  balancing  do  not  support  application  specific features which may vary in DCs environment. Therefore, more advanced load-balancing techniques that also consider application specific characteristics and requirements can be developed for C-PON. Such advanced load balancing may require bespoke load balancing of DC traffic based on characteristics such as flow type/application type/traffic pattern. For example, different load balancing and routing techniques may be implemented for mice and elephant flows in the DC.
headers: 5.1.3.3 Load Balancing Based on Application Specific Features

text: There are two options to trigger resilience in the C-PON fabric, as follows:

As  illustrated  in Figure  13 (a), OLM  triggered  resilience  is  initiated  when  NIC  and  link  state  and utilisation is not received by the OLM from a given smart NIC after pre-defined period. Before traffic is re-routed  in  response  to  link  failure  notification,  it  is  recommended  that  the  OLM  performs  a connectivity test to validate NIC/link failure on the presumed failed links in the C-PON fabric.

Figure 13: Resilience Options for C-PON.

<!-- image -->

This is initiated when the receiving server detects lost flows of expected traffic. As illustrated in Figure 13 (b), the receiving server will check the incoming traffic and if a packet within a flow is not received, it  sends a (trigger) control message to the OLM. Otherwise, the receiving server continues to check until the flow transmission completes. The OLM then checks first if the transmitting server is active. If yes, the OLM marks the current assigned path (i.e., collection of links between the transmitting and receiving servers) as unavailable or failed and then recalculates the route and updates the routing tables  accordingly.  Then,  the  OLM  issues  new  control  messages  to  the  transmitting  and  receiving servers  to  restart  the  transmission.  If  the  transmitting  server  is  unavailable,  then  it  informs  the receiving  server  so  it  can  issue  a  new  request  from  another  server  that  has  a  copy  of  the  same requested data. This resilience scheme can be used in conjunction with the OLM triggered resilience.

Together with Vodafone we have identified  three key Edge Processing Use Cases:

- o Smart  Factory/Manufacturing  and  Industry  4.0 :  adoption  of  5G's  private  mobile network to automate manufacturing, investigate Microsoft glass and include smart glass as a feature.

Today,  user  demands,  and  expectations  are  fast  evolving.  Additionally,  many  manufacturers  now operate in highly competitive markets alongside new and established competitors. These changing market conditions require smart and adaptable manufacturing factories. To  achieve this and more, manufacturer and other factory operators are leveraging strongly emerging technological trends to satisfy changing and specific consumer needs in an efficient and sustainable manner.

Examples of technologies being used or considered include IoT, cloud computing, edge computing, AI and machine learning techniques and algorithm, wired and wireless connectivity, augmented reality, virtual  reality,  mixed  reality,  and  digital  twins.  The  adoption  of  such  technologies  enables  smart manufacturing/factories.

Importantly, the major beneficial outcome of  Smart Factory/Manufacturing and Industry  is that of increased  productivity  in  production;  measured  as  the  same  number  of  machines  producing  more output effectively lessening the embedded carbon in each unit of production. The benefit of increased productivity is recognised by leading bodies including the United Nations International Development Organisation (UNIDO) and the UK having adopted this in its Industrial decarbonisation Strategy [6], [7].

Although  the  increase  in  this  overall  infrastructure  efficiency  could  dwarf  the  networking  energy efficiency  provided  by  C-PON,  C-PON  aims  to  achieve  this  carbon  reduction  by  being  a  potential fundamental enabler to smart manufacturing.

According to the ' SMARTer2030 ICT Solutions for 21st Century Challenges ' Report, ICT will enable 20% reduction of the global carbon emission by cutting the need for 12.1 Gt CO2e by 2030 by enabling smart mobility, smart agriculture, smart energy and smart manufacturing [8]. By enabling smart manufacturing, which is estimated to reduce CO2e by 2.7 Gt, it is estimated that this will lead to overall 4.4% reduction in the Global carbon emission by 2030.

Figure 19: Features of Smart Manufacturing.

<!-- image -->

As illustrated in Figure 19 , the features of smart manufacturing/factory include (but are not limited to):

- Connected Assets and Data Collection: The assets (including sensors, devices, machines, robotics, AGV, tools, and products) in a smart factory are connected. Such connectivity could be achieved via wired or wireless connectivity and offers greater control and precision. Wireless connectivity is expected to enable optimal flexibility as it avoids cabling complexity and cost which can in turn reduce adaptability and access on the factory floor. Although wireless connectivity including Wi-Fi and  cellular  communication  technologies  such  as  3G  and  4G  has  inherent  challenges,  the architectural design, and technologies of 5G mobile networks adequately considered the smart factory use cases. Therefore, making it much suitable for different applications that run in smart factories.

Therefore, making it much suitable for different applications that run in smart factories. Data is collected from connected factory assets in (near) real-time.
- Data Analytics: Collected  data  is  analysed  to  derive  insights  and  intelligence  that  can  improve decision making. Such analysis may involve the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms. Additionally, the data collected from manufacturing floor could be combined with historical data from other systems in business ecosystem to derive greater insights.
- Adaptable  Production  Line: A  wirelessly  connected  manufacturing  floor  can  be  dynamically configured to adapt production lines based on current product demands. This enables greater flexibility of the manufacturing process which can significantly improve operational efficiency.
- Automation: Because factory/manufacturing assets are connected the manufacturing process can be  automated.  Automation  can  be  guided  using  insights  and  intelligence  derived  from  data

analytics  to  achieve  smart  automation  of  the  manufacturing  processes  for  optimal  product customisation and operational efficiency.

- Visibility and Transparency: The volume of data collected and the application of data analytics in smart  manufacturing/factors  promote  greater  visibility  and  transparency.  Such  visibility  and transparency could be achieved via functions such as remote monitoring of product quality and manufacturing  processes.  Given  the  ability  to  collect  data  from  connected  assets,  augmented reality, virtual reality, mixed reality, and digital twin technologies can be used to further improve visibility  and  transparency  of  manufacturing  operations  and  processes.  Such  technologies  can enable  seamless  action  on  insights  generated  from  data  analytics  and  the  application  of intelligence  derived  from  the  deploying  AI  and  machine  learning  algorithms.  For  example, intelligence derived from analytic and application of AI and machine learning to fault diagnosis (during AI-assisted monitoring) can be relayed to technicians using smart glasses with embedded AR  features  to  optimise  fault  diagnosis/troubleshooting  and  maintenance  and  repairs  on  the factory  floor  (AR-assisted  maintenance  and  repair).  Alternatively,  a  more  experienced  remote engineer  with  access  to  a  complete  virtual  replica  (digital  twin)  of  the  smart  factory  and  the manufacturing processes running in the factory can offer remote support to less experienced site technicians  using  smart  glasses  that  are  enabled  with  AR  features  (i.e.,  AR-assisted  real-time support).
- Precise and Predictive Maintenance: Because factory/manufacturing assets are connected precise and near real time fault detection is possible. However, centralisation  of  such  capability  as  purposed  by  the  cloud  computing  paradigm  can  be disadvantageous for some smart manufacturing applications such as quality control and dynamic automation of the manufacturing process. In general, the C-PON platform is an enabler for commercial use cases because it provides computing capacity for the various applications that are associated with each use case and also provides a fabric to interconnect underlying compute components.

The C-PON platform offers 3 diverse fabric types. Each fabric type features different capability in terms of latency, resilience and power consumption. Therefore, the C-PON platform offers the flexibility of selecting an optimal fabric for a specific application based on performance/QoS requirements such as latency  and  power  consumption.  Furthermore,  the  programmability  of  the  C-PON  platform  allows adaptation of any C-PON fabric to suit application specific demands. Therefore, each fabric can be programmed to deliver specific QoS requirement as desired by applications that are selected to run on the  C-PON platform. Additionally, routing and load balancing of traffic over a C-PON fabric can be performed based on a predefined cost function.

For example, consider a scenario where smart factory/manufacturing commercial use case is enabled by a private mobile network (PMN) that is implemented as a slice of the 5G network. It is further assumed that the C-PON platform is adopted to implement MEC and network virtualisation function infrastructure for the 5G network. While providing computing capacity as part of the network slice that enables the PMN, the network fabric provided by the C-PON platform can be programmed to support different classes of smart factory application and services.

One way of achieving such capability is by prioritising DC network traffic based on each application's class and requirements. Class specification for packets can be performed based on 5 tuple components i.e., source and destination IP address, source and destination port and the protocol. Healthcare  systems  are composed  of  hospitals  and  health departments,  in addition to the communication  infrastructure  that  connects  with  the  ambulances  and  in-home  patients.  The healthcare sector has witnessed several challenges over the past years that resulted in the need for interconnected  infrastructure  between  different  health  departments,  enhanced  communication systems  between  patients  and  hospitals  and  real-time  communication  between  different  health providers.

To  address  these  challenges  and  meet  future  demands  for  smart  healthcare  systems,  advanced technologies  are  to  be  adopted  at  different  layers  of  the  healthcare  system.  Examples  of  such technologies  include  cloud  computing,  edge  computing,  AI  and  machine  learning  techniques  and algorithm,  high  capacity  and  low  latency  wired  and  wireless  connectivity  that  includes  PMN,  and augmented reality. The adoption of such technologies enables smart healthcare systems to have the following features Figure 21 :

Figure 21: Features of Smart Healthcare.

- Assets  and  Environment  Monitoring :  The  assets  inside  hospitals  includes  the  sensors,  vitals monitoring devices, motorised beds, surgery robots and machines, and various scanning devices. Additionally, assets outside the hospital include the ambulances equipment and the monitoring devices provided for in-home patients. A smart healthcare system enables the collection of status from the assets and various sensors and provides centralised visual monitoring features in realtime to boost response to any loss or damage or change to required conditions.
- Data Analytics and AI-assisted diagnosis : Data of patients in a smart healthcare system are saved locally to increase customer privacy. As such data could be big, a smart healthcare system would contain ''edge or fog'' computing units that can store patience data and perform various ML and AI  algorithms  to  get  insights  that  can  improve  the  healthcare  experience  for  providers,  and patients.  Also,  doctors  can  utilise  the  outputs  of  an  AI-assisted  diagnosis  enabled  by  this infrastructure to accelerate the request of lab or scans results for the confirmation of the diagnosis.
- High  Speed  Private  Communications: To  reduce  the  delays  associated  with public  wireless connectivity including Wi-Fi and cellular communication technologies such as 3G and 4G, a smart healthcare system would use a Private Mobile Network (PMN). A PMN reduces the latency as its local  infrastructure  is  dedicated  for  the  healthcare  systems  and  services.  It  also  improves  the privacy  and  can  enable  additional  adaptive  features  and  resources  slicing.    5G  or  future technologies can be adopted to implement the PMN.
- Advanced Remote Patient Monitoring and Remote Surgical Consultation :  A  smart  healthcare system ensures full integration between the public and its private networks. It also ensures lowlatency interfaces with the public networks which can serve remote patients while meeting the sensitive delay standards of healthcare required to save lives. This can also enable remote surgical consultation where a paramedic at an accident scene can perform complex life-saving operation

The advantages that can be offered by connected vehicles have become apparent in the past few years which resulted in the need for fully integrated intelligent transport systems that can communicate with all  its  surroundings.  The  Vehicular  communication/V2X/Automotive/Mobile  data  use  case  should consider the following:

text:
- Cooperative Traffic Gap: This is required when a vehicle moves and crosses between different lanes which triggers an action to coordinate with other vehicles to locate a gap to cross safely.
- Interactive Vulnerable Road Users (VRU) Crossing: pedestrians and cyclists are considered VRU; hence they should be able to interact with surrounding vehicles to make them aware if they are crossing the road to ensure their safety.
- Vehicles are equipped with recoil reconfigurable radio systems which should be periodically checked and updated to ensure that it complies with the regional requirements and standards.

- Automated Valet Parking - Joint Authentication and Proof of Localisation: this feature enables drivers to drop off their vehicles in a parking facility equipped with autonomous access control, where the facility will direct the vehicle to an open space.
- Automated Valet Parking (Wake Up): this feature enables automatic vehicle start to be ready for pick up or to be moved from its space.
- Awareness Confirmation: vehicles are allowed to share confirmation messages with surrounding vehicles that contain information about their status and any safety messages. This enables vehicles to adapt their driving style according to their surroundings.
- Cooperative Curbside Management: Enabling better communication between a vehicle and a pedestrian for pick up especially in areas that are difficult to access and have more traffic or obstructions.
- Cooperative Lateral Parking: Once a vehicle locates a free parking space it coordinates with surrounding vehicles to park safely and efficiently.
- In-Vehicle Entertainment (IVE): provides entertainment such as videos games and online access. It  can  be  limited  in  non-automated  vehicles  during  operation,  while  it  is  fully  accessible  in automated vehicles.
- Obstructed View Assist: if a vehicle has obstructed view, it will require assistance from existing surveillance infrastructure or surrounding vehicles to be able to proceed safely.
- Vehicle Decision Assist: This feature enables a vehicle to differentiate between stationary and non-stationary vehicles, and what actions to take accordingly.

- Automated Intersection crossing: autonomous vehicles should be able to coordinate with traffic lights  when  crossing  or  going  through  an  intersection,  taking  into  consideration  all  the surrounding traffic lights timings.

- Autonomous  Vehicle  Disengagement  Report:  if  an  autonomous  vehicle  driving  system disengages then it should send a report capturing all the system data to the original equipment maker (OEM) and government data centres.
- Cooperative Lane Merge: vehicles should be able to coordinate and allow other vehicles to merge into traffic lanes safely.
- Cooperative  Manoeuvre  of  Autonomous  Vehicles  for  Emergency  Situations:  vehicles  are equipped  to  detect  upcoming  hazards;  hence  they  should  be  able  to  coordinate  with surrounding vehicles to avoid the hazard together successfully.
- Coordinated, Cooperative Driving Manoeuvre: if a vehicle needs to change lanes or perform any action on the road it should first inform all surrounding vehicles and get confirmation back that it is safe to take this action.
- HD Map Collecting and Sharing: Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) technology and sensors enable vehicles to collect and share information about its surrounding environment, which will then be analysed to improve the efficiency and accuracy of maps.
- Infrastructure Assisted Environment Perception: vehicles retrieve information from surrounding existing infrastructures that contains information about mobile and static objects within that environment, which enables the vehicle to enhance its sensors performance.
- Infrastructure-Based Tele-Operated Driving: cameras and existing monitoring and surveillance infrastructures provide vehicles with real time data of their surroundings to help them navigate safely.
- Remote Automated Driving Cancellation (RADC): autonomous driving mode in vehicles should have the ability to be remotely cancelled in emergency situations.
- Tele-Operated Driving (ToD): in case of a vehicle is navigating an area with unclear maps such as  industrial  areas,  a  remote  driver  can  then  intervene  and  drive  the  vehicle  to  its  desired destination.
- Tele-Operated  Driving  Support:  vehicles  can  request  assistance  from  remote  drivers  in situations where the action to be taken is unclear.
- Tele-Operated  Driving  for  Automated  Parking:  certain  parking  facilities  can  provide  remote drivers to assist with the autonomous parking option.
- Vehicle Collects Hazard and Road Event for AV: sensors within vehicles collect data from its surroundings and driving behaviour to be analysed and used to enhance V2X communication and autonomous driving.

- Vehicles that operate and move within a group of other vehicles such as transportation systems require  coordination to  increase  efficiency  and  reduce  traffic  congestion,  where  they  share information about joining or leaving a platoon or changing position within it.



- Bus Lane Sharing request: bus lane access can be managed and granted to certain vehicles to improve traffic.
- Bus Lane Sharing Revocation: if access to bus lanes will cause disruption in traffic or violate road safety, then it can be revoked.



- Continuous  Traffic  Flow  via  Green  Lights  Coordination:  dynamic  coordination  between consecutive traffic lights allows better management of ongoing traffic and allows vehicles to move efficiently which lowers the possibility of traffic bottlenecks.
- Group Start: autonomous vehicles and semi-automated vehicles coordinate went to start when they are held in a traffic light.

- Accident  Report:  if  a  vehicle  is  involved  in  an  accident,  then  a  report  with  all  the  incident information and the timeline will be uploaded to the proper authorities.
- Patient Transport Monitoring: emergency vehicles are equipped to send vital patient data to the  nearest  possible  hospital.  Surrounding  vehicles  should  be  able  to  detect  incoming emergency vehicles and make way for safe passing.

This document forms a detailed report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 1 st  January 2022 to 15 th  March 2022, focused on the one technical deliverable and one commercial deliverable of the project. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section 2 discusses the technical deliverable on the initial draft specification of C-PON cell.
- Section 3 details the technical implementation updates on the ECOICE project.
- Section 4 discusses the commercial deliverable on advanced specification of the first use case (with Vodafone or BT) on edge processing for applications.
- Section 5 discusses prospective use cases and deployments for C-PON with BT.

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs) with effective, resilient and energy efficient computing for various applications. The C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 3 to  TRL6 where a C-PON demonstration prototype will be fitted with monitoring and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including.

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The engineers in Ultracell Networks Ltd are involved in the development of the key C-PON components which include.

- C-PON NIC card.
- OLM.
- Optical back plane.
- Control software.
- C-PON cell development.

Several  industrial  collaborators  are  involved  with  the  use-case  development  and  validation  of components, systems, and subsystems of the C-PON platform, including:

- Vodafone (wireless networks, IoT, and cloud and fog DCs).
- BT (wired network, cloud DCs and fog computing).
- Orange (wired and wireless networks, cloud, and fog DCs, virtualization and network slicing).

C-PON technology is a patented [1]-[5] hardware and software networking for connecting and enabling low latency and high-speed inter-rack communication within edge and cloud data centers (DCs) and to the outside world. The patented intra-rack and intra-rack designs of the C-PON technology use cellular passive,  low  cost,  reliable  optical  components  to  replace  conventional  electronic  access  and aggregation switches. Therefore, it provides an infrastructure with energy-efficient hardware-software architecture to optically connect servers and storage in a DC or across distributed locations.

The ECOICE project aims to transition the C-PON technology from implementation on a computing hardware  to  a  minimum  viable  product  (prototype)  of  the  C-PON  technology  that  can  be  further developed into a commercial product. Amongst other deliverables, the specification of the C-PON cell forms one of the technical deliverables of the ECOICE project (i.e., DT16 ).

The C-PON technology offers various platform choices that are suitable for distributed or centralized computing and telecommunication systems. In these platforms, the C-PON cell is the smallest modular unit that can function (be operated) alone. A C-PON cell is a collection of inter-connected racks in the C-PON technology. The C-PON cell comprises a PON fabric (created using a cocktail of optical devices) that interconnect servers in different racks within the C-PON cell. Each rack in the C-PON cell hosts several servers and has a backplane that interconnects servers within that rack.

Each server in the C-PON cell has a programmable C-PON card which supports the implementation of the  networking  function,  specifically  packet  forwarding,  and  provides  two  network  interfaces  that connect the server to the PON fabric and the backplane within the rack. The C-PON platform comprises multiple C-PON cells that are interconnected by the optical line terminal (OLT) which is implemented as an optical line manager (OLM). The OLM is a shared component of the C-PON technology on which the control protocols of the platform are implemented. The OLM also connects the cells to external networks as illustrated in Figure 1 .

In what follows of this section of this report, we provide a detailed description of the components of the C-PON cell, the description of the physical architecture and the initial specification of a basic C-PON cell.

A server is equipped with specific computing hardware components (i.e., CPU, memory, network ports and hard disk resources) and software (i.e., operating system) to provide data and functional services. A server can offer such services independently or through distributed computing paradigms where this server exchanges data with a set of servers in the network to achieve the service. In this project, rackmounted servers will be used. Rack-mounted servers are general-purpose servers, mountable and can be stacked into a rack frame. Each server should have Peripheral Component Interconnect express (PCIe)  slots  to  allow  the  attachment  of  one  or  more  C-PON  cards.  Two  types  of  servers  can  be considered:

- i. Relay servers: Relay servers will act as a gateway to facilitate the communication between the servers in the same rack and the servers in other racks or the OLM. The relay server will have a direct link with the backplane and another link either with the OLM or with another relay server in different rack.
- ii. Normal servers: Servers that will be directly connected to the backplane. To communicate with other servers in the C-PON cell, the servers should send the data to the relay server through the backplane which will accordingly forward it to another relay server or to the OLM.

A rack is a steel frame that is designed to accommodate servers, network devices, cables, and other data centre equipment. In the C-PON platform, racks are interconnected using cellular passive optical technology to form C-PON cells.  Each rack contains several servers which are subsequently arranged into number of groups within the rack. Each group within the rack will accommodate one relay server.

The C-PON card is attached to each server in the C-PON platform. The C-PON card will be initially implemented using a Xilinx FPGA-based Smart NIC. The use of a programmable FPGA-based Smart NIC to implement the C-PON card enables direct implementation of some network functions such as the forwarding engine in the CPON card instead of the server's CPU. This will allow better utilization of the server's CPU for task computation. Xilinx Smart NIC supports the P4 high -level network programming abstractions, which is adopted in this project.

The PON fabric enables the connectivity between servers in different racks within each C-PON cell. It also enables the connectivity between servers in each rack of the C-PON cell and the OLM. The PON fabric comprises cables, splitters, and couplers which enable the connectivity provided by the PON fabric.



Cables  provide  the  physical  media  that  enable  server-to-server  connectivity  and  server-to-OLM connectivity. Optical fibre cables are proposed for the C-PON platform to support high data rates of 100Gb/s and beyond. Optical transceivers will be attached to both ends of the optical fibre cable to allow electrical/optical conversion.

Splitter/coupler are passive devices that are used to combine or split optical signals. All servers within a  group  will  be  connected  to  a  splitter  and  a  coupler.  On  the  one  hand,  splitters  can  be  used  to spread/broadcast  the  optical  signal  to  different  servers  within  the  same  group  for  downstream communication. On the other hand, couplers are used for upstream as they aggregate optical signals from different servers within the same group.

In the C-PON platform, each rack has an intra-rack backplane that provides an exclusive intra-rack fabric between servers in that rack. The backplane facilitates the exchange of direct traffic between servers within the rack. The backplane also supports transiting traffic within the rack. Typically, all racks in the C-PON platform have the same backplane structure. However, there is a range of options that can be adopted to implement the backplane in the C-PON platform. The options, which are illustrated in Figure 2 , include the following:

- i. Passive  Star  Reflector:  The  passive  star  reflector  can  be  used  to  broadcast  intra-rack  traffic between all servers within the same rack.

- ii. Fibre Bragg Grating: Fibre Bragg Gratings can be used to reflect selected wavelengths between servers in the same rack.
- iii. Polymer optical backplane: Passive polymer backplane with polymer waveguides can be used to provide non-blocking full mesh connectivity.
- iv. Programmable switch: Alternatively, the backplane can be implemented using a programmable switch that interconnects the servers within the rack.

Figure 2: Intra-rack options for the C-PON Cell.

<!-- image -->

The  optical  line  manager  (OLM)  interconnects  different  cells  in  the  C-PON  platform  and  provides interface to connect to external networks outside the cloud or edge DC environment. The OLM provides a physical communication boundary between C-PON cells in the C-PON platform because all inter-cell communication in the C-PON platform must be performed via the OLM. Furthermore, the intelligence and control needed to coordinate communication within and between C-PON cells are also embedded in the OLM. The OLM may also host the management and monitoring functions of C-PON platform.

The control software of the C-PON comprises a range of algorithms and protocols that dynamically assign network resources (e.g., bandwidth) and governs how communication is performed within each C-PON cell and in a full-fledged C-PON platform. The C-PON control software in its simplest form will provide  interfaces  and  establish  communication  protocol  between  the  C-PON  cards  and  the  OLM within a single C-PON cell. More sophisticated versions of the control software will enable distinct CPON cells to be joined together through the OLM and enable processing to be moved between C-PON cells (i.e., a heavily loaded C-PON cell borrows servers from nearby C-PON cells).

In each group, one of its servers acts as a relay for the remaining servers in that group. Thus, each rack would contain ( ð¹ )  relay  servers.  If  the  non-relay servers  of  each  group  need to  communicate with servers in other racks or with the OLM, they should first send their traffic to the relay server through the backplane. Then, the relay server forwards their traffic to the next hop on the communication path. In contrast to the patented C-PON technology which relies solely on PON, as illustrated in Figure 2, the introduction of relay servers simplifies the traditional C-PON architecture by avoiding the optical power budget limitations that are associated with the broadcast of optical signals within each group of servers over the fully passive PON fabric. This is a refinement beyond the patent, that is introduced here for

the first time to simplify the implementation. A collection of these refinements will lead to a future, implementation focused patent. Likewise, direct connectivity between the relay servers and the OLM addresses similar limitations of the architecture in Figure 2 .

An advantage of the cell-level scalability is avoiding the additional control complexities required for inter-connecting multiple C-PON cells and furthermore localising more traffic within the cell which further  reduces  the  overall  structure  by  reducing  the  inter  cell  traffic  and  its  routing  demands. However, the disadvantages include the need to restructure the physical topology, which includes changing the number of servers in each group, the backplane, and the connections within the scaled C-PON  cell.  The  OLM  also  should  update  the  control  and  monitoring  operations  to  reflect  on  the architectural changes and to recalculate the forwarding tables. In addition, increasing ð² would reduce the server share of the link capacity (in Gbps) and hence the value of the maximum throughput per server within a specific group due to the use of the relay server for inter-rack traffic.

Scaling the C-PON platform at the platform-level enables incremental upgrade for a C-PON platform via the addition of new cells. However, it requires the OLM to handle communication with servers in

other C-PON cells through the central OLM, which will restrict the number of available paths between servers in different cells and hence can reduce the resilience of the C-PON platform.

Therefore,  the  choice  of  a  particular  C-PON  cell  size  and  total  number  of  cells  depends  on  the applications to be supported, for example in terms of the number of servers that are needed to run each application. These servers may best be collocated in one C-PON cell to localise traffic, reduce complexity and increase energy efficiency by reducing the cross (inter-cell) traffic. The applications also dictate the total number of servers needed, in addition to the resilience and latency requirements.

Therefore, in addition to the technical development (reported in Section 2), we have engaged in parallel in  commercial  use  case  development  (reported  in  Section  4)  to  guide  the  choice  of  the  best configuration of the C-PON cells, (in addition to guiding choices in NICs, OLM, backplane and software). It should be noted that a general purpose C-PON platform design is also possible, but its optimality may vary with applications.

This fully programmable forwarding plane is implemented using the interconnected C-PON cards in the basic CPON cell. Each C-PON card in the C-PON cell implements an instance of the forwarding block of the CPON platform by programming the forwarding plane of the C-PON card via a P4 program running on its embedded FPGA. The instance of the forwarding block of the C-PON platforms on each C-PON card specifies how packets (that are bound for a specific IP address should be forwarded) to achieve endto-end communication over the physical topology of the cell.

This is achieved by installing a forwarding table on each C-PON card in the cell. For example, consider the schematic diagram of the basic C-PON cell in

The C-PON card implements an instance of the forwarding block. The forwarding block in each C-PON card (in each server) performs the following functions to enable end-to-end communication.

- i. Forwarding table installation :  Allow the installation of a forwarding table which defines how each packet will be forwarded by each C-PON card.
- ii. Packet forwarding : The forwarding block should forward packets in the following manner.
- a. Receive packets that are destined for the current server.
- b. Send packets from current server via the C-PON card and forward such packets via one of the interfaces of that C-PON card towards the destination server as defined by the forwarding table installed in that C-PON card.
- c. Relay transit packets (not destined for the current server) via one of the interfaces of the C-PON card as defined by the forwarding table installed in the C-PON card.
- iii. Update Packet Fields : Additionally, the forwarding block in each C-PON card should define and/or update the time to live (TTL) value of each packet in the following manner:
- a. Set  the  TTL  value  of  traffic  originating  from  the  C-PON  according  to  the  size  of  the network.

- b. Decrement the TTL value of  transiting  packets at  each  C-PON  card.  The  C-PON  card should  drop  packets  that  have  TTL  value  of  zero  and  an  ICMP  message  should  be generated and an appropriate response to the original sender of dropped packets is then sent.
- iv. Collection  and  Update  Metadata :  The  C-PON  card  should  also  collect  and/or  update designated packet metadata during the packet forwarding process.

text: Mininet is a network emulator used to validate and debug the developed P4 programs of C-PON before the actual deployment on Smart NICs. It provides an inexpensive real-time emulation for customised and complex network topologies. It uses standard Linux kernel and network applications for creating hosts, switches, links, and SDN controllers. Moreover, Mininet provides the flexibility to emulate the link bandwidth, the expected delay and NIC queue size. It has a command line interface (CLI) that is aware of the network topology, which is used in configuring, monitoring, running supported systemlevel  regression  tests  and  debugging  network  issues.  Therefore,  the  built  P4  programs  that  are successfully  deployed  on  Mininet  can  be  shipped  to  the  physical  network  components  with  minor changes/considerations  related  to  the  hardware  manufacturer's  design.  In  addition,  topologies  in Mininet can be scaled to support larger networks (i.e., substantial number of hosts, switches, etc.), hence,  it  has  enabled  us  to  test  the  C-PON  cell  topology  and  validate  the  use  case  minimum requirements.

The emulated C-PON topology is an initial representation of the basic C-PON cell as shown in Figure 13 . The  topology  is  composed  of  3  racks  each  with  2  servers  referred  to  as  hosts  in  this  emulation environment. Each of these hosts is equipped with a network interface card that has two interfaces (eth0, eth1). These interfaces are connected internally within the host.  The connections between the different hosts were optimised to realise full forwarding amongst all hosts within the cell.  The links' capacities between different hosts were set to 1 Gbps with a maximum queue size of 1000 packets and each packet had a maximum transmission unit (MTU) of 1500 bytes. These parameters were just within the emulation capabilities of the hardware (CPU, memory etc) of the platform used.

Ultracell Networks Ltd has prepared this document for BEIS as evidentiary information of achievement of key milestones and objectives relating to the deliverables of the  second quarter of 2022 for the Cellular Passive Optical Networks (C-PON) platform of the Energy-efficient Cellular Optical Interconnects for Clouds and Edge-processing (ECOICE) project.

We are confident that we have understood and met the objectives and are providing a high quality, value-based report that meets the requirements as defined in the project. In summary:

- We achieved the technical deliverable DT6 within WP4 which is the initial draft specification of the  C-PON  control  software.  We  specify  a  software  defined  networking  (SDN)  compatible management architecture for the C-PON platform.  We defined the C-PON control software and outlined the three critical elements of the C-PON control software which are the controller, network applications and the interfaces between the control software and C-PON card.  We furthermore provided a generic control protocol which leverage the critical elements on the control software in conjunction with the C-PON cards to achieve end-to-end communication in the  C-PON  platform.  We  also  review  candidate  controllers,  interfaces,  and  management protocols from the SDN paradigm that can support the realisation of C-PON control software. In  addition,  we  present  initial  simulation  of  C-PON  platform  using  an  open-source  SDN controller and an update on the emulation of the round-trip time (RTT) meter for the C-PON platform. This is beyond MS3 requirements.
- We achieved the third commercial deliverable (i.e., DC3 Within WP6) which is the advanced specification of the first use case (with Vodafone or BT) on edge processing for applications. The work done in DC3 builds on the achievements of the previous commercial deliverables which scoped a range of possible use cases for the C-PON platform and gave advanced specification of some use cases.  This iteration of the commercial deliverable focuses on further interaction with partners (the High Value Manufacturing Catapult, Vodafone, and BT) of the ECOICE project to further develop commercial use cases of the C-PON platform.

This document forms a detailed report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project  from  1st  April  2022  to  15th  June  2022,  focused  on  the  one  technical  deliverable  and  one commercial deliverable of the project. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 discusses the technical deliverable on the initial draft specification of C-PON control software.
- Section 2 details the technical implementation updates on the ECOICE project.
- Section  3  discusses  the  commercial  deliverable  on  development  of  the  first  use  case  with Vodafone or BT on edge processing for applications and on other commercial engagements performed of the ECOICE project.
( WP4, DT6 Initial draft specification of C-PON control software)

C-PON technology is a patented [1]-[5] hardware and software networking for connecting and enabling low latency and high-speed inter-rack communication within edge and cloud data centres (DCs) and to the outside world. The patented intra-rack and intra-rack designs of the C-PON technology use cellular passive, low cost, reliable optical components to replace conventional electronic access and  aggregation  switches.  Therefore,  it  provides  an  infrastructure  with  energy-efficient  hardwaresoftware architecture to optically connect servers and storage in a DC or across distributed locations.

The  ECOICE  project  aims  to  transition  the  C-PON  technology  from  implementation  on  a computing hardware to a minimum viable product (prototype) of the C-PON technology that can be further developed into a commercial product. Amongst other deliverables, the  specification of the control software forms one of the technical deliverables of the ECOICE project (i.e., DT6).

In  contrast with legacy networks where both control plane and data plane components are embedded in every network device, the C-PON platform leverages the software defined networking (SDN) architecture.  Hence,  the  control  plane  of  the  C-PON  platform  is  centralised  into  the  control software which is decoupled from the data plane (C-PON cards) of the C-PON platform. The C-PON control software dynamically governs how communication is performed within the C-PON platform by computing and installing forwarding information onto the C-PON cards and monitoring the state of the underlying network.

In this section of this report, we provide a brief description of the legacy network management architecture and describe how the novel SDN management architecture is leveraged for the C-PON platform. Then, a detailed description of the C-PON control software and its associated elements is given. Using CPON's management architecture, a generic control protocol for dynamic communication
is proposed for C-PON. Finally, some candidates for realising elements of the C-PON control software are reviewed.

The  management  architecture  of  a  traditional  network  consists  of  three  distinct  layers/planes namely the management, control, and data planes as illustrated in Figure 1.

- Management  plane: The  management  plane  performs  functions  such  as  network  device configuration,  monitoring,  and  collection  of  network  statistics  for  management  and  optimal operation of the network.
- Control plane: The control plane performs routing related functions i.e., decides how packet will be forwarded in the network by maintaining the forwarding information of the data plane.
- Data plane: The data plane performs data transfer (forwarding) functions based on the installed forwarding tables. Additionally, it is responsible for packet buffering, packet scheduling and header field modifications.

Figure 1: Traditional network management architecture.

<!-- image -->

Traditional network devices (such as routers and switches) are designed in a such way that the control plane and data plane are closely bundled into each network device. This tight integration of the control  and  data  planes  can  complicate  the  network  management  task.  For  example,  the  task  of debugging  network  configuration  problems  across  many  network  devices  could  be  challenging. Consequently,  the  traditional  network  architecture  offers  minimum  configuration  flexibility  and
minimum  coordination  between  network  devices.  Hence,  the  overall  network  performance  (i.e., latency, throughput, bandwidth, etc) of the network can be adversely affected.

The  concept  of  software  defined  networking  (SDN)  presents  an  alternative  approach  for network management by separating the control plane and data plane. The control plane is logically centralised  into  the  control  software  that  act  as  the  controller.  Relative  to  the  traditional  network management  architecture,  the  SDN  paradigm  improves  network  management  architecture  in  the following ways:

1. Decouples  network  control  plane  from  data  plane,  and  hence  data  plane  functions  can  be deployed  on  high  speed  and  simplified  network  devices  that  are  optimised  for  packet forwarding tasks.
2. Forwarding of network packets based on destination IP is replaced with  flow-based  packet forwarding where packet forwarding decisions are based on any (or group of) packet header field value(s) in the transport, network, or link layer header.
3. Reduces  complexity  through  centralising  network  automation  in  response  to  network  or dynamic flow patterns change.
4. Increases  network  reliability  by  eliminating/reducing  manually  configuration  of  network devices.

These  benefits  of  the  SDN  paradigm  are  leveraged  in  the  design  of  the  C-PON  platform  to achieve optimal performance. The architectural approach of SDN is particularly adopted in the design of the C-PON control software.  Similar to the architectural approach of SDN paradigm, the control plane and data plane are decoupled in the C-PON platform as illustrated in Figure 2 Control plane functionalities  reside  in  the  logically  centralised  control  software  along  with  management  plane functions. The data plane of the C-PON platform comprises distributed C-PON cards (within servers and the  OLM)  which  are  simple  forwarding  devices  that  forward  packets  as  instructed  by  the  control software. The devices of the C-PON data plane are incapable of computing forwarding information on

their own; hence the control software computes and distributes forwarding information to C-PON data plane devices. Furthermore, control information is not directly exchanged between C-PON data plane devices, as all control information sent from the C-PON data plane is directed to the control software.

Figure 2: C-PON network management architecture.

<!-- image -->

Given the modular architecture of the C-PON platform resulting from the adoption of the SDN architecture, different vendors and organisation can focus on providing different elements of C-PON network management architecture. For example, certain vendors can focus solely on the design and development of C-PON cards, while others focus on the design and development of the components within the control software. The flexibility of this design and development approach aligns with the commercialisation roadmap for the C-PON technology and would help to drive innovation.

The C-PON control software is a logical entity that governs how communication is performed within  each  C-PON  cell  and  in  a  full-fledged  C-PON  platform.  It  comprises  a  range  of  algorithms, protocols  and  applications  that  dynamically  assign  and  manage network  resources.  Relative  to the network  management  architecture  of  traditional  network  devices,  the  C-PON  control  software performs control plane and management plane functions as illustrated in Figure 2. C-PON network intelligence resides in the control software i.e., the control software is the brain of the C-PON platform.

The  C-PON  control  software  in  its  simplest  form  will  provide  interfaces  and  establish communication protocol within a single C-PON cell.  The C-PON control software computes, manages, and  installs  forwarding  information  into  all  data  plane  devices.  Such  forwarding  information  are computed after adequate consideration of routing, load balancing, and resilience policies. The control software  is  also  responsible  for  configuration  and  management  of  C-PON  data  plane  devices.  In addition to leveraging the SDN architecture, the C-PON control software will leverage protocols of the widely deployed TCP/IP protocol suite to implement it functions. However, the development of novel customised protocols which can enable optimised performance of the C-PON platform is not precluded.

C-PON  control  software  comprise  of  three  critical  elements  i.e.,  a  controller,  network applications and interface as illustrated in Figure 3.

- i. Controller :    The controller maintains accurate and recent information about the state of topology, links and C-PON cards in the C-PON fabric and makes such information readily available for network applications of the control software. The controller maintains a global view of the C-PON network by collecting latest network statistics and other information about that state of links and C-PON cards in the C-PON fabric. The controller makes such information readily available to the network applications and publishes changes in network state. Network applications in-turn subscribe to event notification for changes in network state  and  respond  accordingly  by  performing  specified  actions  such  as  modification  of network configuration and management accordingly. The controller can also store copies of the current forwarding information on each data plane device. Storing such information can help the controller to maintain a global view of the network state.
- ii. Network Applications : Network applications run as part of the C-PON control software to enable monitoring, programming, and management of underlying data plane devices in the C-PON platform. Network applications specify policies that determine how the forwarding information  to  be  installed  in  data  plane  devices  is  computed.  Examples  of  network applications include but are not limited to routing application, load balancing application,

firewall/access control application and MAC learning application as described below. It is important to note that the list of network applications below is not exhaustive as the design and development network applications will be based on requirements and  different use cases. For example, new applications can be developed to optimise energy efficiency and resilience  in  the  C-PON  platform.  Therefore,  a  design  approach  that  supports  the development and deployment of new network applications  is  recommended for  C-PON control  software.  However,  the  routing  application  has  been  identified  as  an  essential application needed to achieve end-to-end communication in the C-PON platform. A brief overview of some network applications is as follows:

- a. Routing application : The routing application is an application to determine end-to-end paths to be followed between data plane devices in the C-PON platform. This can be achieved by running an instance of a routing algorithm such as Dijkstra algorithm or Bellman-Ford  algorithm  based  on  the  most  recent  link  and  node  state  information received from the controller.
- b. Firewall/access control application :  Is  an  application  that  determine  the  (groups  of) packets that would be forwarded by the data plane devices. Conversely, this application determines the (groups of) packets that would be discarded by the data plane devices.
- c. MAC learning application : Is an application that implements a process of learning the MAC address of all data plane devices in the C-PON platform.
- d. Load  balancing  application :  The  load  balancing  application  is  an  application  that distributes forwarded packets via different paths between data plane devices to achieve load balancing.

Figure 3: C-PON Control Software

<!-- image -->

- iii. Interfaces :  Interfaces  allows  the  control  software  to  interact  with  and  program  the underlying distributed data plane devices of the C-PON platform. Such interfaces support protocols that allows the control software to program, monitor and control underlying data plane  devices.  The  underlying  data  plane  devices  also  inform  the  control  software  of changes in the network state via such interfaces and supported protocol.

A generic control protocol is proposed for dynamic communication in the C-PON platform. The control protocol provides a high-level description of how communication is performed in the C-PON by leveraging the components, features, and functions of the control software (i.e., controller, network applications and interfaces) in conjunction with the features of distributed data plane devices in the CPON platform. It is important to note that the list of functions, features and applications considered in
headers: A Generic Control Protocol for C-PON Platform

text:
the  generic  control  protocol  in  Figure  4  is  non-exhaustive.  However,  this  is  sufficient  to  enable demonstrate end-to-end communication in the C-PON platform.

Given the physical connectivity within the C-PON platform, the control protocol as illustrated in Fig. 4 operates as follows:

- Step  1 :  The  controller  and  network  devices  of  the  C-PON  platform  are  bootstrapped  and configured. Additionally, the resilient in-band control channels to support control information exchange can be setup. The features and functions of this step are associated with control and management applications/protocols of the control software.
- Step 2 : Compute end-to-end routes for required data paths using a routing application. Endto-end route computation may consider defined, load balancing, resilience, and other traffic engineering policies prior to the computation of forwarding information. The functions in this step are performed by the routing application in the control software.
- Step 3 :  Update forwarding information on each data plane device in the C-PON platform to implement  optimal  end-to-end  routing  of  network  traffic.  The  functions  of  this  steps  are performed by the controller in control software over the interfaces that connect the control software to the data plane of the C-PON platform.
- Step 4 : Each packet is forwarded by the data plane devices to the next hop on C-PON fabric based  on  installed  forwarding  information  until  it  reaches  the  intended  destination.  In  the process of forwarding, data plane devices should also update the packet metadata as required. Furthermore, the data planes devices should also collect relevant statistics needed for optimal performance and to maintain accurate global view of the network. The functions in this step are associated with the data plane of the C-PON platform.
- Step 5 :  Each data plane device in the C-PON platform periodically reports the network state (device/link state and utilisation) via established control channel to the control software. These are functions that should be coordinated by the controller and by protocols that are supported by the control software.
- Step 6: Based on information received or not received from distributed data plane devices in the C-PON platform, the control software determines if a change in network state has occurred.
- o If network state changed : return to Step 2

- o If network state did not change :  continue Steps 4 and 5 until all traffic forwarding is complete.

The C-PON control software is expected to run on a single or multiple commodity server(s). Although  logically  centralised,  the  C-PON  control  software  can  be  physically  deployed  in  multiple commodity servers for optimised performance, reliability, and scalability. For example, if each OLM is implemented as a chassis with a commodity server and multiple C-PON card, an instance of the control software can run on the commodity server of each chassis. Furthermore, the control software can provide interfaces to all C-PON cards in the C-PON platform.

Candidate Interfaces: Interfaces include application programming interfaces (APIs), which formalise the  way  the  controller  and  the  forwarding  elements  interact.  APIs  are  used  to  push  configuration information  and  to  install  forwarding  information  in  the  data  plane.  Some  candidate  interfaces  to realise APIs in C-PON include:
headers: Review of Candidates to Realise C-PON Control Software

text:
- i. OpenFlow :  OpenFlow  is  the  most  widely  known  open  API  that  provides  a  common specification for the communication channel between the separated control plane and data plane in SDN architecture. However, OpenFlow was designed for a specific set of common use cases and assumed the forwarding elements have a fixed, well-known behaviour, which makes it harder to extend and add new features. More recently, the P4 language, a data plane language the enables greater programmability of data plane networks compared to OpenFlow, has been proposed.
- ii. Protocol-Oblivious  Forwarding  (POF) :  POF  was  introduced  to  enhance  the  network programmability. In contrast to OpenFlow which defines the flow tables according to the existing network protocols, POF dynamically programs the forwarding plane to support new protocols.
- iii. P4  Runtime :  P4  Runtime  is  an  API  designed  to  control  any  data  plane  devices  whose behaviour defined by P4 language. It provides flexibility to add features over time while using  the  same  API.  Additionally,  P4  Runtime  can  be  used  to  emulate  the  behaviour  of OpenFlow and to extend its functionalities.

Previously, P4 language was proposed to define the C-PON cards pipeline i.e., fields to match upon, actions to be performed on the packets and the order to perform matches and actions. Given the adoption of the P4 programmable Xilinx smart NIC as the development platform for the C-PON card, adoption of the P4 Runtime API is more appealing. However, should a different interface be required in the future based on unique needs, new bespoke interface will be developed, as necessary.

Candidates Control Software: Since the emergence of the SDN paradigm a range of proprietary and open-source network operating systems (NOS) and controllers have been developed to leverage the benefits of the SDN architecture. Examples of open source SDN controllers include NOX, OpenDaylight and ONOS. It is important to note that proprietary controllers, such as HPE virtual application networks (VAN) SDN controller, are also an option. However, the ECOICE project intends to give priority to opensource SDN controllers over proprietary controllers such as:

- i. NOX : NOX is a legacy SDN controller which supported OpenFlow. NOX provides interface for management and the development of network applications. These network applications determine how flows are routed in the underlying network.
- ii. OpenDaylight :  OpenDaylight  is  an  open-source  SDN  controller  that  adopts  a  modular architecture for application development. It is a collaborative project that is manged by the Linux Foundation. OpenDaylight architecture comprises application and control layers and plugins (and protocols) that enable communication between these two layers and to the network  devices  that  are  being  controlled.  Amongst  others,  OpenDaylight  supports OpenFlow and OVSDB as plug-ins between OpenDaylight platform and network devices.
- iii. ONOS :  ONOS  is  a  scalable  and  distributed  open-source  control  platform  for  the  SDN paradigm which features an intent framework. ONOS is also part of the Linux Foundation. ONOS SDN controller offers several choices of interfaces to communicate with underlying network devices. For example, ONOS supports both OpenFlow and P4 Runtime amongst other next generation SDN interfaces. The adoption of a P4 programmable data plane in the C-PON platform makes ONOS an appealing candidate for the development of the C-PON platform.

In addition to control plane functions, the control software is expected to perform the management plane  functions  (i.e.,  configuring  and  managing  networking  devices)  in  the  C-PON  platform.  Some candidate protocols that can be leveraged to implement network configuration and management in control software include:

- i. Simple  Network  Management  protocol  (SNMP ):  SNMP  is  a  common  protocol  used  to monitor and manage network devices. It relies on management information bases (MIBs) to define the collected information and how to change and configure the devices. Although SNMP is widely used, it has drawbacks that limit its ability to configure network devices in an  automated  way.  Therefore,  SNMP  is  used  for  monitoring  purposes  rather  than configuration.

- ii. Telecommunication Language (TL1): TL1 is ASCII-based management protocol mainly used for managing network elements. TL1 is well-structured, which makes it easy to understand and implement. It is similar in some respects to SNMP, and they can co-reside with each other or with other management protocols.
- iii. Network Configuration Protocol (NETCONF): Recently, NETCONF emerged as a configuration management protocol. It was proposed to address the limitations of SNMP by bringing out capabilities that enable network automation. NETCONF provides an efficient mechanism to install, manipulate, and delete the configuration of the network devices. It uses YANG, a data modelling language to model configuration and state data.

Three primary blocks are needed for effective communication and control in the C-PON fabric: Control Block, Routing Block, and Forwarding Block. The control and routing blocks are implemented in  the  control  software  while  the  forwarding  block  is  implemented  in  the  data  plane.  The  control software of C-PON can use ONOS (Open Network Operating System) which enables programming and controlling  a  network  comprising  P4Runtime-enabled  devices  with  all  the  benefits  of  a  logically centralized SDN platform as in Figure 6.

ONOS is logically centralized remote controller which Provides APIs to make it easy to create apps to control a network. ONOS can also run as a distributed system across multiple servers, which increases scalability, high-availability, and performance. ONOS was originally designed to work only with OpenFlow and now extended to work with P4 programs.

The network links are automatically discovered by ONOS using Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP). LLDP is an open IEEE standard protocol (802.1AB) that its operation is deployed based on two modules that are LLDP transmit module and LLDP receive module as shown in Figure 7.

This  operation  is  one-way  communication  that  does  not  require  a  request,  reply  or acknowledgement messages. LLDP packet is sent as LLDP Data Unit (LLDPDU) within an Ethernet frame (shown in Figure 8) where LLDPDU (shown in Figure 9) consists of a sequence of type-length-value (TLV) structures (shown in Figure 10). TLV is an encoding format that allows flexible extensions that can be placed in any order inside the message body. Network devices send LLDP packets periodically in the network to advertise their identity, and capability.

The Round-Trip Time (RTT) is a value that measures the amount of time a certain signal, packet or acknowledgment takes to traverse from source to destination in a network. RTT is usually measured in milliseconds (ms) and is considered an important metric in monitoring and identifying the stability of  network  connections.  Network  administrators  usually  use  RTT  to  analyse  network  connections' speed and reliability. The total RTT in a network is defined as the summation of the average of both the server-side RTT and the client-side RTT.

Then  the  average  total  RTT  for  this  network  connection  is  calculated  by  summing  the average RTT for both server (RTTs) and client (RTTc) and is given as follows:

```
Average Server RTT = (RTTs1 + RTTs2)/2 Average Client RTT = (RTTc1 + RTTc2)/2 Average Total RTT = avRTTs + avRTTc
```

Several factors can affect the actual round-trip time such as:

- Distance: defined as the length of time a request takes to reach a server and to be fulfilled with a response.
- Transmission medium: defined as the medium used for communication which can have varying speeds depending on the material used for example such as copper connections or fiber optic cables.
- Number of network hops: defined as the number of hops it takes a certain request to reach a destination and for a reply to be received, which can highly impact the RTT if the number of hops increases.
- Traffic levels: defined as a measure of network congestion usually in large dense networks; the lower the traffic levels the lower RTT.
- Server response time: defined as the time required for a specific server to fulfill a client's request. This can be affected by several factors such as the server's processing and memory capacity and the number of clients being served.

To  monitor  quality  of  service  (QoS)  and  quality  of  experience  (QoE)  on  C-PON  cards,  we implemented a P4 program to perform packet forwarding and RTT monitoring. Initially, this program was developed to support the behavioural model architecture (BMv2) and was emulated in a Mininet environment.  The topology considered in this emulation included three  hosts  and three  switches connected as shown in Figure 12. During the emulation, TCP traffic was generated from h-2 (client) to h-1 (server) and the RTTs were monitored on switch-2. Since RTT values are calculated based on Ack packets only, the source IP and port will have the sever h-1 information and the destination IP and port will have client h-2 information.

Figure 12 : Mininet's topology setup for RTT Emulation

<!-- image -->

For results validation, Wireshark was used to capture the forwarded packets of the switch and calculate their associated RTT values on both ingress and egress ports (before and after the forwarding process). Once the traffic is generated and the communication is complete, the RTT values produced by the P4 RTT meter are compared to their associated values calculated by Wireshark for the same TCP traffic. In Wireshark, RTT values calculated at the egress port are higher than the RTT values calculated at the ingress port due to the switch processing delay. Since the P4 program monitors RTTs during the

forwarding process, it is expected that the produced RTTs will have a value greater than the RTT at the ingress port before forwarding and smaller than the RTT at the egress port after forwarding.

For example, the packet (Flow id: [10.0.1.1, 10.0.2.2, 9899, 59868, 2931465001, 3990485462]) highlighted in Figure 13 and Figure 14 has RTT values of:

- 11.641ms: calculated by Wireshark at the ingress port (eth-2).
- 6.0284ms: calculated by Wireshark at the egress port (eth-1).
- 2.4129ms: calculated by the P4-based RTT meter during forwarding.

The cell consists of six servers (each two server in one rack) equipped with P4 enabled NIC cards and one ONOS controller server where all servers are interconnected via 25 Gigabit Ethernet copper links as depicted in Figure 16.

In  the  configuration  phase,  the  ONOS's  network  view  is  enabled  using  the  network configuration service which is required for ONOS network applications and devices configuration. The configuration parameters are specified using the standard NETCONF JSON syntax that describes the network elements, links, hosts, port types ..., etc. and informs ONOS of the existence of C-PON cards and other devices in  the  network.  A  shell  command  is  applied  in  ONOS  CLI  to  upload  and  set  the configuration parameters.

Afterwards,  the  ONOS  controller  can  start  the  discovery  process  and  check  availability  and connectivity of the configured network devices.  The C-PON cards are identified as programable P4 data plane devices in our simulation setup. A unified P4-defined pipeline program (basic.p4) is compiled using P4 compiler and applied on all simulated C-PON cards. ONOS controller interacts with P4 enabled devices using P4runtime interface to control the P4 pipeline in these connected devices and perform the following control functions:

- Establish  remote  procedure  call  (gRPC)  connections  with  existed  network  devices  that prescribed in ONOS controller's NETCONF configuration.
- Activate the master role on the connected devices.
- Query the connected NICs state information such as pipeline tables, actions, meters, active portsâ¦, etc.

As ONOS is built with several kernel subsystems (drivers, protocols, utilitiesâ¦, etc.). to enable the mentioned bootstrap functions in our  C-PON topology a specified  set  of drivers  and  protocols  are activated in the ONOS controller via CLI or GUI. In our simulation environment we have enabled the following components:

- Netconf provider
- P4runtime protocol
- Bmv2 driver
- Device service provider
- LLDP protocol

In  our use case, it is necessary for ONOS controller to translate and interpret CPON card's P4 -defined  pipeline  which  includes  the  customized  actions,  tables,  registers,  metersâ¦,  etc.  In  ONOS settings, the pipeline configuration service was activated to enable the interoperability and the northbound  integration  of  ONOS  networking  applications  and  C-PON  cards.
