Ultracell  Networks  Ltd  has  prepared  this  document  for  BEIS  as  evidentiary  information  of achievement of key milestones and objectives relating to the deliverables of the third quarter of 2022 for  the  Cellular  Passive  Optical  Networks  (C-PON)  platform  of  the  Energy-efficient  Cellular  Optical Interconnects for Clouds and Edge-processing (ECOICE) project.

We are confident that we have understood and met the objectives and are providing a high quality, value-based report that meets the requirements as defined in the project. In summary:

- We achieved the technical deliverable DT5 within WP2 which is the advanced specification of optical line manager (OLM) to be implemented on FPGA. We gave an overview of a generic OLM for the C-PON platform by defining the functions performed by the OLM and by describing the physical  architecture  of  the  OLM.  Thereafter,  we  gave  the  technical  specification  of  the components and sub-components of the OLM. We provided a detailed specification of the OLM for a C-PON testbed that will be implemented during the ECOICE project. We discussed the options for establishing a control and data paths through the proposed C-PON Testbed.
- We achieved the seventh technical deliverable (i.e., DT7 within WP5) which is the advanced specification  of  C-PON  optical  backplane.  We  provided  a  brief  overview  of  the  backplane covering  the  functions  it  offers  within  the  C-PON  platform.  We  reviewed  the  options  for implementing the C-PON optical backplane and settled for optical circuit switch (OCS) as the most feasible option. We outlined and reviewed a range of deployment options for OCSs in the C-PON platform and evaluated the performance of each option. We decided on which option to implement based on the output of a Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) optmisation model. Finally, we discussed connection management for OCS-based optical backplane for CPON.

This  document forms a detailed report on  the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 1 st July 2022 to 28 th  September 2022, focused on the two technical deliverables as well as progress on commercial engagements in the project. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section  2 discusses  the  technical  deliverable  on  the  advanced  specification  of  OLM  to  be implemented on FPGA.
- Section 3 details the advanced specification of C-PON optical backplane.
- Section 4 details technical implementation updates in the ECOICE project.
- Section 5 discusses updates on commercial engagements in the ECOICE project.

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs)  with  effective,  resilient  and  energy  efficient  computing  for  various  applications.  The  C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL)  3  to  TRL6  where  a  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  will  be  fitted  with  monitoring  and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including.

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The engineers in Ultracell Networks Ltd are involved in the development of the key C-PON components which include.

- C-PON NIC card.
- OLM.
- Optical back plane.
- Control software.
- C-PON cell development.

Several industrial collaborators are involved with the use-case development and validation of components, systems, and subsystems of the C-PON platform, including:

- Vodafone (wireless networks, IoT, and cloud and fog DCs).
- BT (wired network, cloud DCs and fog computing).

This ECOICE project report focuses on the deliverables of Milestone 4 (MS4) which covers the third quarter of 2022 (Q3 2022). Q3 2022 deliverables include a technical deliverable (DT5), which relates to work package (WP2) and a technical deliverable (DT7), which relates to WP5.

( WP2, DT5 Advanced Specification of OLM to be Implemented on FPGA )

C-PON technology is a patented hardware and software networking technology for connecting and enabling low latency and high-speed inter-rack communication within edge and cloud data centers (DCs) while also providing connectivity to the outside world. The patented intra-rack and inter-rack designs of the C-PON technology use cellular passive, low cost, reliable optical components to replace conventional electronic access and aggregation switches. Therefore, it provides an infrastructure with energy-efficient hardware-software architecture to optically connect servers and storage in a DC or across distributed locations.

The  ECOICE  project  aims  to  transition  the  C-PON  technology  from  implementation  on  a computing hardware to a minimum viable product (prototype) of the C-PON technology that can be further developed into a commercial product. Amongst other deliverables, the specification of optical line manager (OLM) to be implemented on FPGA forms one of the technical deliverables of the ECOICE project (i.e., DT5).

The OLM is a physical hardware that facilitates communications within the C-PON platform and between the C-PON platform and external systems by performing a range of essential functions. These functions  are  enabled  by  the  physical  components  of  each  OLM  such as  C-PON  cards,  backplanes, computing hardware and auxiliary components.

In  subsequent  subsections  of  this  section,  we  give  an  overview  of  the  OLM  and  its  physical architecture  as  well  as  provide  the  technical  specification  of  the  OLM.  We  also  give  detailed specification of OLM for C-PON Testbed and discuss options for establishing communication paths in C-PON Testbed.

The optical line manager (OLM) is a physical hardware of the C-PON platform that supports intra-cell and inter-cell connectivity. It also enables north-south communication between cells and the external systems. These features of the OLM are fundamental for end-to-end communication within the C-PON platform.

The OLM implements a range of physical functions, packet forwarding (data plane) functions and logical functions to enable communication within/to/from the C-PON platform. A high-level description of these functions is given as follows:

- i. Physical Functions : These functions enable physical connectivity to and from the OLM. These comprise features that enable physical connectivity and media access control (MAC) in the CPON platform.
- ii. Packet Forwarding Functions : The packet forwarding functions of the OLM comprise data plane functions that enable packet forwarding. These functions support end-to-end communication within/to/from the C-PON platform. Packet forwarding functions focus on enabling transfer of packets through the OLM.
- iii. Logical Functions : The logical functions of the OLM comprise control plane and management plane functions which provide the intelligence that dictates how end-to-end communication is performed over physical connectivity in the C-PON platform. The logical functions of the OLM are  predominantly enabled by the  control  software that  is  hosted  in  the  OLM.  The  control software governs how communication is performed in the C-PON platform by using a range of algorithms, protocols and applications that perform logical functions of the OLM. Such logical functions provided by the OLM include routing; intelligence and control to coordinate the cells and to interface cells to the external systems; network traffic load balancing capability over network fabric of the C-PON platform; and configuration of additional routing paths through the OLM for resilience.

The specification of the physical architecture of the OLM and how this physical architecture enables physical functions and packet forwarding functions of the OLM is the subject of study in this section of the report. On the other hand, the specification of the control software, which implements the logical functions of the OLM, is outside the scope of this report and was discussed in the Milestone 3 (Q2 2022) report.

The OLM chassis hosts several physical components as illustrated in Fig. 1; these components implement the physical functions and packet forwarding functions of the OLM and provide necessary computing capacity to support the control software which implements the logical functions of the OLM. At  a  high-level,  the  primary  physical  components  of  the  OLM  include  C-PON  cards,  backplane, computing hardware and auxiliary components.

C-PON Cards: The C-PON cards that are positioned in the OLM perform a range of functions which include the following:

- i. Interfacing with physical media to receive and transmit bitstreams.
- ii. Parsing  of  packets  and  using  the  content  of  the  packet  header  to  make  decisions  about forwarding, queuing, and/or discarding during period of link congestion.

- iii. Storing packets during processing and queuing. This is enabled by the memory buffer of the CPON card.
- iv. Forwarding of packets to the host of the C-PON card, to ports on the same C-PON card and/or to other C-PON cards as required.

Consequently,  the  C-PON  cards  comprise  a  range  of  physical  sub-components  i.e.,  network interfaces, forwarding engines, buffers, traffic managers as illustrated in Fig. 1. Detailed discussion on the sub-components of the C-PON card are given later in this report.

Figure 1: Physical Architecture of the Optical Line Manager.

<!-- image -->

Backplane: The backplane of the OLM provides connectivity between distinct C-PON cards in the OLM. This ensures that the packets arriving at any interface of a C-PON card in the OLM can be transferred to any interface of another C-PON card in the OLM.

Computing  Hardware: The  computing  hardware  of  the  OLM  provides  general  purpose  computing capacity i.e., CPU, memory and storage needed to support instances of the C-PON control software. The control software provides logical functions to the C-PON platforms which generally include control plane and management plane functions. The control software configures and manages the distributed C-PON cards in the C-PON platform.

Auxiliary  Components: The  OLM  also  requires  auxiliary  components  which  support  its  operations. Examples  of  such  auxiliary  components  include  power  supply  systems  and  cooling  systems.  Such auxiliary systems can be deployed in a redundant manner to improve the OLM's resilience. Additionally, auxiliary components can include a dedicated component that performs the management of cooling and power systems as well as other internal management functions within OLM. In this report, the features  of  the  power  systems  and  cooling  system  of  C-PON  platform  development  devices  and components are adopted.
This section gives further technical specification of the components of the OLM as illustrated in Fig. 1.
headers: 2.3. Technical Specification of the Optical Line Manager

text:
The C-PON cards comprise a range of physical sub-components which include network interfaces, forwarding  engines,  buffers  and  traffic  managers  as  illustrated  in  Fig.  1.  These  sub-components systematically enable the previously outlined functions of the C-PON cards. Hence, detailed discussion on each sub-component of the C-PON card is important and is given as follows:

- i. Network  interfaces :  Network  interfaces  are  integrated  into  C-PON  cards.  These  interfaces provide physical layer interfaces and media access control (MAC) on the OLM. Hence, network interfaces  comprise  Ethernet  ports  and  Peripheral  Component  Interconnect  Express  (PCIe) interfaces that provide connectivity to physical links. The Ethernet ports terminate physical links from servers in the C-PON platform or from gateway routers. On the other hand, PCIe interfaces terminate PCIe lanes to the host of each C-PON card. Ethernet interfaces receive packet frames from the physical links and transmit packet frames as bitstreams over electrical or optical links in compliance with IEEE 802.3 standard. In contrast, PCIe interfaces receive packet frame from physical links and transmit packets over electrical links in compliance with PCIe standard.
- ii. Forwarding  engine: A  forwarding  engine  determines  the  output  C-PON  card(s)  and/or  the corresponding interface(s)  to  which  a  packet  would  be  forwarded  by  performing  necessary lookups. Such lookups use the forwarding information installed by the control software. A CPON card can have one or more forwarding engine instances. On the one hand, the forwarding engines in each C-PON card can be designed to perform only minimal tasks needed to transfer packets between the C-PON cards in the OLM. On the other hand, the forwarding engine can also be designed to perform complex functions such as traffic classification and prioritization. Furthermore, forwarding between interfaces in the same C-PON card can be performed locally on that C-PON card by directing the packet to the corresponding output interface. In contrast, forwarding across interfaces connected to different C-PON cards must be performed via the backplane. Each forwarding engine may implement both ingress and egress packet forwarding pipelines for packets that arrive and are destined to the interfaces serviced by the forwarding engine. Forwarding is performed at line rate; hence, it can be performed in a custom hardware such as Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC). However, during the development phase, programmable Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) can be adopted in the place of ASIC.
- iii. Buffers: Buffers  enable  the  C-PON  card  to  temporarily  store  the  packet  payload  while  the forwarding engine is performing lookups. The buffers in the C-PON card also temporarily store packets when the output link from the OLM is not idle. When the buffer is full, packets can be dropped in a coordinated manner. Buffers can be implemented as on-chip memory in the SoC and/or in an external memory. Usually, on-chip memory or buffer is relatively smaller compared to external memory but faster.
- iv.

The buffers in the C-PON card also temporarily store packets when the output link from the OLM is not idle. When the buffer is full, packets can be dropped in a coordinated manner. Buffers can be implemented as on-chip memory in the SoC and/or in an external memory. Usually, on-chip memory or buffer is relatively smaller compared to external memory but faster.
- iv. Traffic manager: A traffic manager manages the queue in the C-PON cards; it is responsible for queueing  and  scheduling  functions  in  the  OLM.  Additionally,  the  traffic  manager  can  also support traffic policing and shaping based on predefined Quality of service (QoS) and Service Level Agreements (SLAs). The traffic manager can also support admission control of packet into

buffers. An admission control mechanism would determine what packets should be admitted into memory/buffer and what packets should be dropped.

The backplane interconnects distinct C-PON cards in the same OLM. In an OLM with multiple CPON cards, a switched backplane with equal number of input and output ports can be adopted to interconnect  such  C-PON  cards.  This  is  because  a  switched  backplane  offers  high  bandwidth  since concurrent communication between multiple C-PON cards is possible. Alternatively, a proportionally sized  backplane  can  be  adopted  for  the  OLM  when  few  C-PON  cards  are  installed  in  it.  It  is  also important to note that an OLM can deploy redundant backplanes to improve capacity and resilience. Redundant  backplanes  help  to  withstand  failures  and  avoid  single  point  of  failure.  Additionally, redundant backplanes can also reduce delay when used to transfer a large frame in parallel. However, despite high bandwidth offered by a switched backplane, contention is a probable issue when the OLM adopts a switched backplane. Therefore, within each timeslot, a scheduling mechanism is needed to determine the input port that is permitted to transmit to a given output port via the backplane.

The computing hardware hosts the control software, which implements management and control plane functions, using a general-purpose hardware. Routing protocols, management software and load balancing and resilience policies of both control and management planes run on the general-purpose computing hardware of the OLM. The control software manages packet forwarding operations in the OLM and in other C-PON cards. The resilience of an OLM can be improved by running multiple instances of  the  control  software  in  the  same  or  multiple  computing  hardware.  However,  control  and  data channels must be established between the computing hardware and distributed data plane component in the C-PON cell.

headers: 2.4. Specification of OLM for C-PON Testbed

text:
In the illustration in Fig. 2, the C-PON cards of the OLM are implemented using Xilinx SmartNIC which provides some functions of network interfaces, forwarding engine, buffer, and traffic manager.

- i. Network Interfaces : The Xilinx SmartNIC supports the Ethernet standards along with support for direct-attach copper and optical cables. Additionally, the Xilinx SmartNIC also possess a PCIe interface with which they interface with the x86 server. Virtual interfaces between applications running on the x86 server and the C-PON cards are also implemented via direct memory access over PCIe.
- ii. Forwarding Engine : The Xilinx SmartNIC supports a range of traffic engineering features which include packet parsing and filtering. These features are performed by the integrated streaming processor of the Xilinx SmartNIC platform. The Xilinx SmartNIC also supports implementation of one or more instances of the forwarding engine for the C-PON testbed by providing a suitable environment to develop, host and support custom packet processors called plugins. Plugins are additional packet processors that can be written in P4, RTL or HLS. Such plugins are developed to  run  at  line  rate  on  the  FPGA  of  the  programmable  Xilinx  SmartNIC  to  provide  new functionalities i.e., to support additional features and new protocols. The FPGA of the Xilinx

SmartNIC is a relatively close substitute for implementing forwarding engine in a custom ASIC as expected in a commercial C-PON platform. In the C-PON testbed, the forwarding engine of each C-PON card can be designed to support additional functions (such as packet classification, access  control  list  processing  and  policing)  as  needed.  This  is  achieved  by  developing  new plugins which perform the required functions. Additionally, Xilinx SmartNIC supports routing of network traffic to appropriate interfaces (physical or virtual) and as well as the replication of packets.  Replication  of  packets  will  enable  multicasting  and  broadcasting  of  packets  as necessary. Based on the outlined functions and features of the Xilinx SmartNIC, the forwarding engine on C-PON cards in the OLM is designed to perform the following functions outlined below. These outlined functions are realised via a custom plugin that is written with the P4 language.

- a. Parsing :  This  involves  receiving  packets  from  interfaces  of  the  C-PON  card  (after conversion  from  bitstream  to  frames)  and  separating  the  packet  header  from  the payload. Subsequently, the information needed to perform the packet forwarding is extracted from the header. Extracted information could include source and destination MAC address, EtherType, source, and destination IP addresses and TCP/IP protocol.
- b. Lookups : The forwarding engine performs both layer 3 and layer 2 lookups to determine where the received packet should go to (in accordance with the information extracted from the header.

Subsequently, the information needed to perform the packet forwarding is extracted from the header. Extracted information could include source and destination MAC address, EtherType, source, and destination IP addresses and TCP/IP protocol.
- b. Lookups : The forwarding engine performs both layer 3 and layer 2 lookups to determine where the received packet should go to (in accordance with the information extracted from the header. Such decision can direct packets to any of the local interfaces of the CPON card which include the transmitter of the input  interface  or  the  transmitter  of another interface or to transmitting lanes of the PCIe bus which lead to the computing hardware of the OLM.
- c. Packet Modification : Packet header updates/modifications such as updating the nexthop  destination  MAC  address  are  performed  based  on  packet  header  rewrite instructions associated with each successful lookup.
- d. Deparsing :  The  (new) header is combined with the stored payload and the resulting packet is validated and subsequently streamed to the output interface.
- iii. Buffers : The Xilinx SmartNIC provides IP (intellectual property) blocks to support plugins that are developed to implement the features and functions of the forwarding engine. This IP blocks provide buffers to store packet when the parsed packet headers are being processed by plugins of the forwarding engine. For example, during lookups in the forwarding engine, the payload is stored/buffered. Additionally, IP blocks provided in the Xilinx SmartNIC also support ingress and egress buffering for plugins when packets arrive faster than they can be processed and when an egress interface is slower compared to how quickly packets are processed respectively.
- iv. Traffic manager : Xilinx SmartNIC IP blocks also support scheduling of packets to prevent head of line blocking in the packet data path and to implement QoS for some sources. Additionally, traffic management feature such as more sophisticated queue management and traffic policing and  shaping  could  be  designed  as  custom  plugins  on  the  programmable  Xilinx  SmartNIC platform.

A proportionally sized backplane is implemented in the C-PON testbed by adopting a directattach copper cable or optical cables to create a point-to-point link between the two Xilinx smartNICs. This simple design is sufficient to represent a functional non-blocking backplane for the OLM in the CPON testbed. This because only two Xilinx smartNICs are installed in the x86 server that is adopted to implement the OLM of the C-PON testbed.

The C-PON testbed leverages the computing (i.e., CPU, memory, and storage) components of the  x86  server  that  are  adopted  for  the  OLM  to  provision  the  computing  hardware  that hosts  the control software. On the one hand, the computing hardware can be provisioned as a bare-metal server which  hosts  only  the  control  software  of  the  C-PON  testbed.  On  the  other  hand,  the  computing hardware of the OLM can be provisioned as one of many virtual machine servers running on the x86 server. Each Xilinx SmartNIC also provides an integrated Arm system on-chip (SoC) (i.e., an on-board CPU) which offers additional computing hardware that can host an instance of the control software in a similar way as the x86 server. Alternatively, the computing capacity of the Arm SoC of the SmartNIC could be dedicated for hosting control plane agents of the control software. Such control plane agent of the control software is a custom control application that can facilitate updates of data plane tables in each C-PON card in the OLM.

The  C-PON  testbed  relies  on  the  power  and  cooling  system  components  of  x86  server  that  is adopted for the OLM.



A functional C-PON platform requires both data and control paths for transmission of data plane and control and management plane information. Consequently, both data and control communication paths are specified for the C-PON testbed.
headers: 2.4.4 Power and Cooling System: Auxiliary components

text:
As illustrated by the blue solid lines in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, the data paths of the C-PON testbed are created through the Xilinx SmartNICs i.e., C-PON cards by the cables between C-PON cards and as well as the lanes of PCIe bus within the x86 servers. Data plane packets and in-band control plane packets are sent over the data paths in the C-PON testbed.

Figure 3: C-PON Testbed with In-band Control Paths over Data Paths.

<!-- image -->

Both in-band and out-band control paths are feasible for the C-PON testbed as shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 respectively. However, some inherent features of the Xilinx SmartNIC make setting up in-band control  channels  the  better  option  for  the  C-PON  testbed.  Xilinx  SmartNIC  supports  a  NIC  routing function which enables the SmartNIC to direct in-band control plane packets to a CPU on the x86 server (on which a Xilinx SmartNIC is installed) or to CPU on the Arm SoC on Xilinx SmartNIC. This feature of the Xilinx SmartNIC supports establishment of in-band control paths over the data paths of the C-PON testbed  for  configuration,  management,  and  monitoring  of  remote  C-PON  cards.  The  design  and implementation of an in-band control paths over the data paths of the C-PON testbed can be achieved as follows.

- i. The control software which resides in the OLM of the C-PON testbed sends control plane packet information as data plane packets over the data paths of the C-PON testbed.
- ii. Control plane packets sent over the data paths of the C-PON testbed are processed as data plane packets until they arrive at an ultimate destination.
- iii. At an ultimate destination, the in-band control plane packet is routed to the CPU on the x86 server or to CPU on the Arm SoC on Xilinx SmartNIC where a control software agent resides.
- iv. The control software agent processes the received control plane information to extract the instruction in the control plane packet.
- v. Control plane agent (the control plane agent is a custom control application that is installed on the Arm SoC of the Xilinx SmartNIC that can) perform pre-defined actions/updates/configuration which can for example be an instruction to update the installed tables on a SmartNIC.

Figure 4: C-PON Testbed with Out-of-band Control Paths and Dedicated Data Paths.

<!-- image -->

As shown in Fig. 4, it is important to note that the OLM requires out-of-band control channels to forward control information to the distributed C-PON cards if an out-of-band control architecture is selected for the C-PON testbed. Hence, dedicated interfaces for control channels and interfaces are required in both the OLM and the distributed C-PON cards.
( WP5, DT7 Advanced Specification of C-PON Optical Backplane )

Backplane offers network connectivity between the servers within the same rack in the C-PON platform. Each rack has a backplane that provides an exclusive intra-rack fabric between servers in the same rack. All racks in the C-PON platform have the same backplane structure. All servers within the rack (i.e., normal servers and relay servers) have a direct link to the backplane which facilitates the exchange of data traffic. Additionally, the backplane of a rack is essential for allowing the servers of that rack to access servers in other racks or cells within the C-PON platform.
Several options are considered to implement the backplane including fiber Bragg grating, optical polymer backplanes, optical packet switches, and optical circuit switches.
headers: 3.2. Implementation Options for C-PON Optical Backplane

text:
Fibre Bragg grating (FBG) can be utilised to facilitate communication between the servers within the same rack (i.e., intra-rack communication) as well as communication between servers in other racks and the OLM (i.e., inter-rack communication). To facilitate intra-rack communication, a FBG is deployed after star couplers as depicted in Fig. 5. A certain wavelength is utilised for communication within the rack,  and  the  FBG  is  used  to  reflect  this  dedicated  wavelength.  When  the  FBG-based  backplane  is adopted, servers must be equipped with tuneable transceivers to generate multiple wavelengths which enable the passive connectivity within the C-PON cell. Alternatively, servers can be equipped with an orthogonal  frequency  division  multiplexing  (OFDM)  transceiver  that  enables  the  uses  of  multiple carriers for communication with other servers in the same rack, with servers in other racks or with the OLM. However, OFDM transceivers are expensive and thus will lead to increased deployment cost for the C-PON platform.

Figure 5: An example of FBG used to connect one rack

<!-- image -->

A passive polymer backplane, with multimode polymer waveguides, enables high-speed, low cost, scalable and compact size point-to-point optical interconnection. It offers non-blocking full mesh connectivity with 10 Gb/s -100 Gb/s and beyond data rates per waveguide. Vertical-cavity surfaceemitting laser (VCSEL) and photodiode arrays can be mounted on each C-PON card and connected to the  backplane.  Fig.  6  shows  an  illustrative  example  of  a  4  x  4  polymer  backplane  to  support  the communication between four (servers with) C-PON cards. To transmit data between two cards or to perform a loop back on the same card, the card addresses the appropriate VCSEL in its transmitter to reach the required destination (i.e., its receiver or the receiver in other cards). Polymer backplane is considered as an ideal option to be implemented as a backplane to passively support high data rate communication  between  the  C-PON  cards.  However,  polymer  backplanes  are  not  commercially available, and hence, other alternatives are considered.

Figure 6: A polymer backplane to connect four cards.

<!-- image -->

To improve the energy efficiency of the C-PON design, we consider studying several options for the optical switches and highlight their characteristics and shortcomings. Introducing optical switches in  data  centres  fully  or  partially  have  been  proposed  to  overcome  the  bandwidth  limitations  of electronic switching, reduce costs, and improve the performance and energy efficiency of data centres. Such technologies eliminate the need for Optical/Electrical/Optical (O/E/O) conversion at intermediate hops (associated with electronic switches) and make the interconnections data-rate agnostic. Optical switches in data centres can be classified into optical packet switches and optical circuit switches.

Optical  packet  switches  (OPSs)  perform  the  switching  of  packets  payloads  optically,  while  the headers can be processed electronically (transparent OPS) or optically (all-optical packet switches). In term of their components, OPSs can be composed of couplers, splitters, multiplexers, demultiplexers, tuneable and/or fixed wavelength converters, optical gates, optical delay lines, amplifiers, and arrayed waveguide grating (AWG). Based on the used components, there are two types of OPS:

- A broadcast-and-select switch where the OPS is composed of three layers: Wavelength encoder, space switch, and the wavelength selector. Each of the input fibres contains one wavelength. A splitter  per  input  fibre,  splits  the  signal  into  multiple  optical  gates  which  selects,  or  blocks packets as needed while ensuring correct timings and correct output fibre for each packet.

- An AWG-based switch: AWGs are used for switching instead of the optical gates used in the broadcast and select OPSs. They are composed of three layers: input wavelength converter, AWG element, and output wavelength converter. In AWG-based OPSs, input and output fibres can carry multiple wavelengths. For the input stage, the signal per port is first demultiplexed and then, tuneable wavelength converters ensures that only one selected wavelength is passed per packet at its time slot to the AWG. The AWG, then routes the packet to the destinated output port and a fixed wavelength converter is used afterward at a specific wavelength per AWG output port, and a multiplexer then, provides the final WDM output.

OPSs are used widely in optical core networks and have been proposed for usage in data centres. However, OPSs have the following challenges:

- Lack  of  efficient  optical  buffering  and  optical  random-access  memory  (RAM)  memories  as optical delay lines are bulky and provide limited buffering duration and capacity which can be in few packets.
- Expensive wavelength converters and complex control of the high number of the converters.

In  Optical  Circuit  Switches  (OCSs),  the  headers  of  the  packets  are  not  processed,  hence,  to switch the packets, external control is needed to reconfigure direct (circuit) optical links from input to output ports. External control (steering) of optical beams inside the OCS can be performed using MicroElectro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) or piezoelectric actuators. In MEMS-based OCSs, several mirrors or reflectors are tilted to direct the beams to desired output port with typical reconfiguration time in the scale of ms or Âµs.  Due to their simple structure and energy efficiency, MEMS-based OCSs have been proposed for data centres. Among the shortcomings of MEMS are the relatively slow switching time that can lead to contentions. However, MEMS-based OCS have been advancing over the years and switching time in the scale of Âµs is achievable. Moreover, recent emergence of SDN-enabled MEMS OCS has also eased external control of MEMS-based OCS used in data centre fabric.

The Polatis 6000 and 7000 series OCSs are example of OCSs that use piezoelectric actuators for beam-steering.  They  use  the  Piezoelectric DirectLight beam  steering  technology  to  offer  Âµs reconfiguration delay. Polatis OCSs are commercially available with up to 384 by 384 port and they support SDN by having embedded OpenFlow and NETCONF control interfaces.

The SDNenabled OCSs are preferred for the implementation of the racks' optical backplane because they can be jointly coordinated and orchestrated along with the OLM and the C-PON cards.

This section reviews several ways to connect the servers within the rack using optical circuit switches to realise the functions of a backplane. Four distinct options that can facilitate intra-rack communication are considered. These options differ in the number of optical switches used, in the

physical connectivity between the optical switches, and in the physical connectivity between optical switches and servers. Consequently, diverse pathways exist between servers within the same rack as well  as  between  servers  in  different  racks.  The  number  of  switches  also  contributes  to  the  power consumption of each option. It is important to highlight that each rack is assumed to have the same configuration and number of servers. To give an illustrative example of each option, we considered an evaluation scenario where a C-PON cell has three racks. Each rack comprises six servers, the servers in each  rack  are  divided  into  three  groups  where  each  group  contains  two  servers.  Table  3  gives  a summary of the physical structure of all the rack backplane options considered in this report under the specified evaluation scenario.

Table 3: Mapping of OLM generic architecture to Planned Implementation of C-PON Testbed .

|          |   Number of Servers |   Number of Ports in a C- PON Card |   Number of Optical Circuit Switches |
|----------|---------------------|------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Option A |                  18 |                                  2 |                                   12 |
| Option B |                  18 |                                  3 |                                   12 |
| Option C |                  18 |                                  2 |                                    3 |
| Option D |                  18 |                                  2 |                                   27 |
headers: 3.3. Deployment Options for Optical Circuit Switches

text:
In this option, as it can be seen in Fig. 7, two layers of switches are considered in each rack. Generally, the first layer comprises a number of switches similar to the number of the groups within the  rack.  The  first  layer  of  switches  enables  intra-group  communication  while  the  second  layer  of switches enables intra-rack communication. In each rack, a single second layer switch is utilized to connect all the groups irrespective of the number of the groups within that rack. The number of input and output ports (i.e., the size) of the second layer switch of a rack is determined by the number of groups in the rack. A limitation of this option is the need to use both layers of the switches to send traffic between different groups in the same rack which might lead to higher delay.

The required number of switches and ports to implement this option for each rack can be summarised as follows.

- Number of switches in the first layer = Number of groups.
- Number of switches in the second layer = 1.
- Number of ports in a first layer switch = Number of servers in one group.
- Number of ports in a second layer switch = Number of switches in the first layer or number of the groups.

Figure 7: Option A, two layers of OCS

<!-- image -->
headers: 3.3.1 Option A: Two layer of OCS

text:
This option is similar to the previous option in terms of the number of switches required to enable the communication in a C-PON cell with the same setup. However, the switches are connected in a different physical architecture from the prior option (i.e., option A). As shown in Fig. 8, each group within a rack has a dedicated OCS that is used to interconnect all servers (i.e., both standard and relay servers) in the group. Additionally,  each rack has a single OCS  which  exclusively provides interconnectivity between the relay servers in the same rack. The main advantage of this option is the direct connection between the relay servers via a dedicated OCS which can lead to better performance in cases where relay servers are directly communicating with each other. However, a drawback of this option is the need for a standard server to send all its traffic through a relay server when it intends to send the traffic to any other server in other group or rack.  Moreover, each relay server requires a CPON card that has three ports to achieve the described connectivity. A summary of the requirements for this option in a single rack is given as follows.

The required number of switches and ports to implement this option for each rack can be summarised as follows.

- Total number of OCS in groups = Number of groups.
- Number of dedicated OCS that interconnects relay servers = 1.
- Number of ports in intra-group OCS = Number of servers in one group.

- Number of ports  in  dedicated  OCS  that  interconnects  relay  servers  =  Number  of  the  relay servers = Number of groups in the rack.

Figure 8: Option B, Intra-Group and Relay Servers Inter-connections.

<!-- image -->
headers: 3.3.2 Option B: Intra-Group and Relay Servers Inter-connections

text:
In this option as in Fig. 9, one OCS is used to interconnect all the servers in each rack, regardless of their type (i.e., standard server or relay server) or the group that they belong to. Therefore, the number of the ports (i.e., size) of the OCS in each rack is strictly dependent on the number of the servers in  the  rack.  Accessing  any  other  server  within  the  rack  requires  passing  through  the  OCS.  A  major intuitive advantage of this option is the use of few OCS which leads to low power consumption. The requirements to deploy this option in a single rack are as follows.

The required number of switches and ports to implement this option for each rack can be summarised as follows.

- Number of OCS per rack = 1.
- The required number of input and output ports = Number of servers in the rack.

Figure 9: option C: A single switch option.

<!-- image -->

This option relies on the clos network to connect all the servers in each rack. In electronic switching, a generic clos network is often adopted to reduce the number of cross-points required in electronic switches when electronic switching is considered by using a number of smaller crossbar switches. A clos  network  provides  non-blocking  communication between the input and the output ports using multistage switches. In this option, a similar multistage architecture which adopts OCS is proposed to implement a non-blocking backplane for each rack in the C-PON platform. A possible disadvantage of this  option  is  the  need  for  many  switches  which  consequently  increases  the  power  consumption. However, it is important to note that commercial OCS consume significantly lower power compared to electrical switches. Fig. 10 gives an example of a three-stage clos network (i.e., a total number of nine switches) that connects six servers in a rack. It is important to mention that the number of switches in each stage can increase based on the number of input and output ports. The three stages include the first stage switches, the second stage switches, and the third stage switches are described as follows:

- a. The first  stage  switches  (i.e.,  the  input  switches):  This  includes  the  OCSs  which  are  directly connected to the servers. The required number of input OCSs depends on the number of servers in each rack. The number of input ports is equivalent to the number of servers in each rack. In the considered scenario, the input port of two input stage OCSs is connected to the transmitter of all servers in the two groups of each rack. The number of output ports of each input stage OCS depends on the number of second stage OCSs in the three-stage clos network.

- b. The second stage OCSs (i.e., the middle stage): This stage provides connectivity between the input stage OCSs and the output stage OCSs. Providing a non-blocking communication requires that any idle input port must be allowed to reach an idle output port. A three-stage clos network ensures non- blocking communication by providing a specific number of middle stage OCSs. This number depends on ratio of total number of input ports connected to the clos network to the number of input port on each input stage OCS.  In this scenario, three second (middle) stage OCSs are utilized. On the one hand, the number of input ports of each second stage OCS is equal to the number of input stage OCSs. On the other hand, the number of output ports of a second stage OCS is equal to the number of output (third) stage OCSs.
- c. The third stage (i.e., the output OCSs): This is the final stage of the clos network. The output port of the third stage OCSs connects to the receiver of each server in the rack. In this stage, the number of third stage OCSs is equal to the number of first stage OCSs. However, the number of input ports of each third stage OCS is determined by the number of middle stages OCSs which is three in this case. Consequently, (3x2) third stage OCSs are adopted in the illustrated example in Fig. 10.

Figure 10: Option D: Clos Network.

<!-- image -->

A mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model was developed to evaluate the performance of the  proposed  options.  The  objective  of  the  MILP  model  is  to  minimize  the  time  slots  required  for communication. Timeslot is an important metric when OCSs are deployed because they provide a

mechanism to overcome contention. Contention occurs in a situation where a transmitting source cannot send traffic to the receiver of an intended destination because the receiver is configured to receive from a different transmitter at that given moment. Additionally, we also compare the options in terms of the total power consumption resulting from the communication between the servers. It is important to mention that the total power consumption is calculated based on the sum of the power consumption of all activated OCSs.   An evaluation scenario where each active OCS consumes a fixed power is adopted in all cases. Based on the outcome of the MILP models from the evaluation scenario, we  select  the  best  option  for  the  C-PON  platform  i.e.,  say  that  the  observed  results  (i.e.,  power consumption and timeslot count) state that this is the best of all options considered. All four backplane options are evaluated under the following (three) types of traffic:

- Intra-cell  communication  (cell  level): This  traffic  type  implements  all-to-all  communication within the cell. In other words, each server in the cell has a request to every other server in that cell (expect itself).
- Intra-rack communication (rack level): This type of traffic implements all-to-all communication within each rack. In other words, each server in each rack has a request to every other server in that rack (expect itself). Hence, traffic exchange between servers is localised within each rack in the C-PON platform.
- Intra-group communication (group level): This  traffic  type  implies  that  each  server  in  each group within a rack has a request to every other server in that group (expect itself). Hence, traffic exchange is localised within each group in the C-PON platform.
headers: 3.4. Performance Comparison of OCS Deployment Options

text:
The results in Fig. 11 show that all options require the same number of timeslots for completing the transmission of all the received traffic requests when communication is required at the group level. However, when all-to-all communication required at cell level, the option that adopted a single switch within the rack, and the clos network (i.e., options C and D) perform better than options A and B. This is because the OCSs in options A and B become bottlenecks (i.e., they are contended) when the servers in the same the group wish to communicate with servers in other groups of the same rack concurrently. A  similar  observation  is  made  all-to-all  communication  is  required  at  rack  level  (i.e.,  intra-rack communication). Hence, the servers in the same group must take turns to communicate with severs in other groups of the same rack.

Figure 11: Delay measured in number of used timeslots

<!-- image -->

The comparison of the power consumption is solely based on the number of switches activated to provision the demands under each deployment option. The power consumption of each switch is assumed to be 100 watts. As expected, the results in Fig. 12 indicates that option C is the most efficient option. This is because fewer active switches required under option C. Moreover, the results are also expectedly  shows  that  backplane  options  A  and  B  have  similar  performance  in  term  of  power consumption because of having the same number of switches. Furthermore, Fig. 12 shows that the clos network gives the worst performance in terms of power consumption as a high number of switches is required. Additionally, in the group level communication a single layer of However, it is important to note that commercial OCSs consume significantly lesser power compared to electrical switches.

In conclusion, a single switch option (i.e., option C) performed better in terms of both delay and power consumption, and hence it is preferred option that will be considered for the implementation of the C-PON platform.

Figure 12: Power consumption measured based on number of active OCS.

<!-- image -->

Given the fact that the optical switches are reconfigurable, the problem of how to find their optimal configuration under a given traffic scenario is inevitable. More importantly, the solution to the problem must provide optimal reconfiguration policies in the presence of traffic load changes. Furthermore, a high possibility of contention occurs in some cases if many servers need to communicate with the same server at the same time. Therefore, it is important to consider a scheduling algorithm to maintain the scheduling to facilitate fair access among the servers. Consequently, the configuration of the switch needs  to  be  adjusted  over  a  range  of  timeslots  using  the  scheduling  algorithm  to  ensure  that  all demands are eventually satisfied. In each time slot, the scheduling algorithm sets the states of the optical switches (i.e., the connection path between the input and output ports) based on the demands at  the  input  ports.  This  may  require  the  existing  connections  from  the  previous  timeslot  to  be rearranged to create new communication path between new pairs of input and output ports. The scheduling algorithm is described in three phases:

- Request phase: In this phase, the server initiates a request to access another server (output port) through the input port. Each output port maintains a virtual queue to track the requests.
- Grant phase: In this phase, the transmitting server is given the permit to start the connection with the receiving server. In other words, the connection path is set up between the input and the output port.
- Transmit phase: In this phase, the actual transmission of the traffic takes place.

A key parameter of the reconfiguration process is the traffic load between the servers which largely depends on the features of the running applications. If the traffic varies and requires connections to be changed  faster  than  the  existing  connections  can  be  rearranged,  the  management  overhead  will increase.  Examples  of  management  functions  include  setting  up  the  connections,  monitoring  and keeping track of the existing connections, and tearing them down when they are not needed.

Implementing configuration changes in OCS can be performed using the following models:

- All-stop model: In the all- stop model, each time a configuration needs to be made, the ongoing traffic stops.
- Not-all-stop model: In the not-all-stop model, the change in configuration can be performed while other servers continue to send traffic without disruption.

Relative  to  the  previously  proposed  software  defined  network  (SDN)  for  the  control  software implementation in Milestone 3 (Q2 2022) report, the same approach is considered for control and management of the OCSs. The control and management of the OCS can be performed in a centralized manner, where each backplane is connected to a centralized controller via a control link. Additionally, the management can be performed locally within each rack. This requires a direct control link between the backplane and the local control entity in that rack.
headers: 3.5. Connection Management for Optical Circuit Switches

text:
C-PON  testbed  hardware  components  were  successfully  received,  installed,  and  tested  at Ultracell Networks' company site on 16th of Sept 2022. Ultracell Networks' Engineers worked closely with Getech (an official partner of our hardware vendors Lenovo, Xilinx and Mellanox) to complete the commissioning, testing and configuration of the hardware components. Received components in the bill of materials include x86 servers, optical transceivers, optical and DAC cables and Xilinx smart NIC cards. The installed setup is highlighted in Fig. 13.

Currently, the team is progressing on setting up the six C-PON servers including Xilinx U25 NIC cards,  operating  systems,  bare-metal  hypervisor,  and  other  software  components  such  as  Vitis development platform, Xilinx Real-time library (XRT)..., etc. The hardware installation plan checklist has been reviewed and approved by the project manager and health and safety officer. The estimated deadline of the testbed readiness is by mid of Oct 2022.

Additionally, two Mellanox SN3700 trial switches were received and installed as shown in Fig. 14. These trial switches were loaned to Ultracell Network by Mellanox for an initial evaluation. Each switch is equipped with 32 ports of 200 Gb/s and offers 12.8 Tb/s bidirectional switching throughput between C-PON servers in the same rack. A Linux based networking operating system is installed on both switches to provide advanced switching capabilities such as network virtualization using VXLANs and IPv6 segment routing. It is worth mentioning that these switches support Layer-2 and Layer-3 networking functionalities.

Figure 13: Installed rack servers of the C-PON testbed.

<!-- image -->

Figure 14: Installed rack servers and trial switch of the C-PON testbed

<!-- image -->

We continue to conduct monthly meetings with Louise Krug (Head of Sustainability research at BT)  to  progress  on  the  Stadium  of  the  Future  use  case.  Meetings  were  held  on  12/08/2022  and 16/09/2022. It was agreed to model the spine and leaf data centre (done), the C-PON cell (done) and gather statistical information about the virtual reality or augmented reality (VR/AR) applications. The models were developed using linear programming and various simulation programs such as GNS3.

In  the  models  we  considered  the  ratio  of  the  requirements  of  VR/AR  applications  to  other applications in the edge. We also compared the cases of hosting VR/AR applications in C-PON and in BT's initial design in terms of:

- The energy consumption.
- The average delay.
- The end-to-end delay.

The results were obtained for 100 users with two allocation schemes and two objectives after refinements and modifications according to feedback.

As  future  steps,  we  will  study  M/M/C  queues  modelling  for  the  switches  as  switches  have multiple queues per port (a queue per output port). This can reduce the MILP-based queuing delay that is based on M/M/1 to obtain more realistic lower values that can fit into the 150 ms end-to-end delay budget provided by BT. Additionally, new results will be generated for evaluation scenarios with 500 users and 1500 users.

text:
Ultracell  Networks  Ltd  has  prepared  this  document  for  BEIS  as  evidentiary  information  of achievement of key milestones and objectives relating to the deliverables of the fourth quarter of 2022 for  the  Cellular  Passive  Optical  Networks  (C-PON)  platform  of  the  Energy-efficient  Cellular  Optical Interconnects for Clouds and Edge-processing (ECOICE) project.

We are confident that we have understood and met the objectives and are providing a high quality, value-based report that meets the requirements as defined in the project. In summary:

- We achieved the commercial deliverable DC5 within WP6 which is the advanced specification of a second use case on smart stadium with BT. We started with an overview of a smart stadium and discussed the key players and applications in smart stadiums. Thereafter, we gave detailed description of augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) assisted event viewing in smart stadiums and in similar use-places. Furthermore, we highlighted end-to-end content flow for the AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case as well as described the infrastructural components needed to implement the use case. Subsequently, we described BT's simplistic setup for AR/VR -assisted  event  viewing  as  well  as  the  description  of  a  visionary  setup  for  production environment.  We  discussed  C-PON  value  propositions  as  an  edge  computing  platform  for AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case in smart stadiums.
- We achieved the commercial deliverable DC7 within WP6 which requires the documentation of initial  plans  to  showcase  a  use  case  of  the  C-PON  platform.  We  started  by  discussing  the recommend approach (as proposed by a representative of BT) for showcasing a use case of CPON at BT Labs. Finally, we described two testbeds (i.e., spine-leaf testbed and C-PON testbed) which will be deployed for performance evaluation during the planned showcase.

This  document forms a detailed report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE  project  from  1 st October  2022  to  30 th December  2022,  focused  on  the  two  commercial deliverables in the ECOICE project. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section 2 discusses the technical deliverable on advanced specification of a second use case on smart buildings or smart factory.
- Section 3 details the initial plans to showcase a use case.

text:
Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs)  with  effective,  resilient  and  energy  efficient  computing  for  various  applications.  The  C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL)  3  to  TRL6  where  a  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  will  be  fitted  with  monitoring  and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including.

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The engineers in Ultracell Networks Ltd are involved in the development of the key C-PON components which include.

- C-PON NIC card.
- OLM.
- Optical back plane.
- Control software.
- C-PON cell development.

Several industrial collaborators are involved with the use-case development and validation of components, systems, and subsystems of the C-PON platform, including:

- Vodafone (wireless networks, IoT, and cloud and fog DCs).
- BT (wired network, cloud DCs and fog computing).

This ECOICE project report focuses on the deliverables of Milestone 5 (MS5) which covers the fourth quarter of 2022 (Q4 2022). Table 1 provides a summary of the deliverables and work packages of the ECOICE project and highlights the current deliverables. The Q4 2022 deliverables include two commercial  deliverables  (DC5  and  DC7),  which  relate  to  work  package  (WP6)  on  commercial development.

In the last decade, the exponential growth in the development of the modern digital technologies and the wide adoptions of such technologies across various industries have led to many disruptions globally. Evidence of such disruption is visible in sport stadiums and events arenas. The popularity of live sports and entertainment events are pushing for the creation of more engaging experience for instadium fans. Therefore, stadium owners are seeking ways to provide captivating services for fans that can compete with the over-the-top media streaming services. The smart stadium paradigm leverages high performance digital infrastructure along with IoT sensors and smart end-devices to deliver the desired improved experience in stadiums as well as to improve operational efficiency.

Smart stadiums are established to enable demand-driven innovations that extend, build on top or leverage the existing stadium infrastructure. The term smart comes from the ability to collect data in real-time  and  apply  actions  with  little  or  no  human  intervention.  Through  introducing  a  range  of services  and  applications,  stadiums  are  set  up  to  provide  more  personalized,  convenient,  and  safe experiences  for  fans.  Smart  stadiums  can  improve  the  fans  experience  by  creating  a  personalized services for fans and thus increasing the revenue per customer, while reducing the operating costs for stadium owners. New tools such as Augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) also provide new ways of experiencing live sports events.

The implementation of certain features in smart stadium requires edge computation particularly in  instances  where  the  feasibility  or  optimal  performance  of  such  features  is  dependent  on  in-situ computation. For example, the adoption of AR and VR technologies in stadium to provide enhanceduser-experienced would benefit immensely when edge computing capacity is near the smart stadium. In  a  stadium  with  up  to  100,000  attendees,  the  power  consumed  by  implementing  such  edge computing capability with a conventional setup is expected to approach 3.75 MW. In contrast, when networking accounts for 20% of IT power consumption, an edge computing setup that deploys C-PON technology in a stadium with similar capacity will reduce power consumption to 3.15 MW. On the other hand, when networking accounts for 80% of IT power consumption in the edge computing location, power consumption of edge computing setup that deploys C-PON technology will reduce to 1.35 MW.

text:
AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  adopts  extended  reality  (XR)  technology  to  process  captured contents (video and data streams) from live events. These processed contents are subsequently sent back to fans at the location of the event to deliver memorable immersive experiences that motivate fans to return for similar experiences. This is because of the personalized, convenient, and engaging experience delivered to fans (users) which enables the fans to select their preferred view and to select how the preferred view is experienced. Consequently, the AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case in smart  stadiums  helps  to  increase  revenue.  This  increase  in  revenue  complements  cost  reductions achieved  when  other  applications  and  services  of  the  smart  stadium,  which  enable  improved operational efficiency, are implemented.

There are two parts to the AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums i.e., AR-assisted event viewing and VR-assisted event viewing. A high-level description of both AR-assisted and VR-assisted event viewing is given as follows:

- AR-Assisted Event Viewing : AR technology is used to embed data streams obtained from events or from other sources into the video stream of the event. The modified stream is subsequently transmitted back to smart end-devices. Using such a technology, facts (such as real-time and non-real time stats) about players, teams and the game can be overlaid on the video stream that  is  sent  to  smart  end-devices.  AR-assisted  event  viewing  involves  the  insertion  of information in real-time into the video source. Thereafter, the modified video stream is sent to the audiences/users.
- VR-Assisted  Event  Viewing :  VR-assisted  event  viewing  provides  an  immersive  viewing experience for fans with suitable smart end-devices e.g., a VR handset. In the context of smart stadium,  VR-assisted  viewing  technology  provides  both  fans  and  game  officials  with  the opportunity  to  experience  key  moments  of  the  event  again  in  an  immersive  manner. Furthermore, the experience provided by VR-assisted event viewing can be further improved when used in conjunction with omnidirectional (or 360-degree) cameras, which capture 360degree videos.

The AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case is easily complemented by other features of the smart stadium to deliver a memorable user-centric immersive experience of events held at the stadium. Such features  include  but  are  not  limited  to  enhanced  audio,  360-degree  event  viewing  and  in-stadium navigation. Furthermore, it is important to note that a smart stadium can be adapted for other events such as musical concerts and other sporting events. Consequently, AR/VR-assisted event viewing setup can also be adapted to function optimally when the smart stadium is being used to host unconventional

events. For example, a smart stadium with a functional AR/VR-assisted viewing infrastructure can be used to host a musical concert.

text:
End-to-end  content  flow  in  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  involves  the  capturing,  transmission, storage, processing, retransmission, and presentation of captured content.

- i. Capturing :  This  involves  the  capturing  and  the  encoding  of  generated  content  from  the event arena. This includes the following.
- a. Capturing of video streams by distributed cameras in the event arena.
- b. Capturing of user current (active) view, location, and requests by smart end-devices, via applications and sensors on such devices.
- c. Capturing  of  data  streams  (of  ball  location  and  trajectory)  by  distributed  sensors  at event arena.
- d. Encoding of captured content into suitable format for effective and efficient transmission.
- ii. Transmission : This involves the transmission of content from event arena (via wired and/or wireless infrastructure) to a production/processing infrastructure.
- iii. Storage :  This  entails  decoding  of  captured  content  and  subsequent  storage  of  captured content into content servers.
- iv. Processing : This involves the task of extracting insights from captured content as well as the task of combining the extracted insights with video stream received from the event arena. Processing  also  involves  transformation  (i.e.,  reformatting)  and  subsequent  encoding  of content for destination smart end-devices.
- v. Retransmission : This involves the transmission of processed and enriched content back to smart end-devices via wired, wireless or hybrid (wired/wireless) infrastructure.
- vi. Presentation : This involves the decoding and displaying of processed content on smart enddevices in the preferred format to deliver an immersive experience.

Figure 2: Architectural Overview for AR/VR-Assisted Event Viewing.

text:
The  end-to-end  content  flow  described  earlier  helps  to  create  a  high-level  overview  of  the architectural set up required for AR/VR-assisted event viewing. At a high-level, enabling AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums and in other use places requires some components as illustrated in Figure 2. These components include distributed cameras, network infrastructure, edge computing pod, smart end-devices, and IoT sensors. Each component is described as follows:

- i. Distributed  Cameras :  Distributed  cameras  at  the  event  arena  capture  and  encode  video streams in the smart stadium. Subsequently, the captured data is sent to the edge computing pod for storage, processing, and analytics. The range of cameras deployed for sporting events in  smart  stadiums  can  also  include  360-degree  cameras  which  can  captures  video  in  all directions.
- ii. Network Infrastructure : Network infrastructure provides connectivity from smart end-devices and sensors to the edge computing platform and from cameras to the edge computing platform. The interactive nature of AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case in smart stadium implies that a  low  latency  and  high  data  rate  network  infrastructure  is  required  to  deliver  an  optimal immersive experience.  This is because a network infrastructure with low latency and high data rate can enable the delivery of high-quality video streams to users (fans). The desired network infrastructure can be implemented using wired networking technologies, wireless networking technologies, or a combination of both. Wireless network infrastructure can be implemented

using Wi-Fi or radio access technologies such as 4G or 5G mobile networks. A high-performance wireless network can ensure that smart end-devices and IoT sensors enjoy adequate wireless coverage across the smart stadium. Consequently, 5G mobile network is a leading technology for establishing connectivity to distributed cameras, sensors, and smart end-devices because it offers  low  latency and high data rate which helps to deliver effective interactive immersive experience.  For  optimal  performance,  private  5G  cellular  network  can  be  established  and dedicated to a smart stadium. Additionally, next generation mobile network such as 6G can enable even better performance for AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums since such technological  advancement  is  expected  to  deliver  higher  capacity  and  lower  latency.  Local consumption of high-quality content by users (fans) is important for maintaining favourable user perception of the AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums. Network infrastructure can provide network capacity to support the AR/VR-assisted event viewing as well as support the other critical applications needed to operate and manage the smart stadium optimally. On the  one  hand,  a  single  flexible  network  infrastructure  with  integrated  intelligence  can  be deployed  in  such  a  scenario.  Alternatively,  dedicated,  and  independent  networks  can  be designed for critical services/applications and user-centric applications such as AR/VR-assisted event viewing.

- iii. Edge Computing Pod : The edge computing infrastructure is of crucial importance for AR/VRassisted event viewing and in the wider smart stadium ecosystem. This is because applications like AR/VR-assisted event viewing are latency sensitive and will therefore benefit significantly when processing and analytics are performed at the edge of the network. The edge computing pod is responsible for decoding the captured content (video and data), storage of the decoded content  and  for  the  subsequent  processing  and  reformatting  of  the  decoded  content.  The transformation of collected data stream into insights and statistics that can be added to AR/VRassisted event viewing workflow is also performed at the edge computing pod. The outlined functions of the edge computing pod can be performed by a one or more applications that run at the edge computing pod. Such applications include processing intensive applications, which can perform the task of rendering of the graphics based on the view requested by each user (fan), as well as analytics applications which transform captured data stream into insights. Other applications  in  the  edge  computing  pod  may  also  be  responsible  for  embedding  generated insights into the video stream that is sent to fans. On the one hand, the edge computing pod can be owned and operated by the stadium owner/operator. Alternatively, the edge computing pod can be provided by a mobile network operator as a mobile edge computing infrastructure located in proximity to the event arena or stadium.
- iv. Users (Smart End-devices and Applications) : Smart end-devices and the applications running on them deliver enhanced experience to users (fans) by receiving and decoding the processed content  sent  from  the  edge  computing  pod.  Subsequently,  smart  end-devices  and  the applications running on them also aid the high-quality presentation of the decoded content. Smart end-devices are simple devices such as simple AR/VR glasses, AR/VR lenses, smart TVs, mobile phones, and tablets that provide immersive experience. In a different context, smart end-devices can also be the source of (content) data that is integrated into the production

workflow. For example, consider a situation where smart end-devices collect and transmit data of a user's active view to the edge computing pod to ensure that the view sent to each user delivers  optimal  experience.  Alternatively,  smart  end-devices  can  also send  users'  location information to facilitate the generation of the right scene and accompanying audio stream.

text: We have had several interactions with a representative of BT (Louise Krug, Head of Sustainability Research)  during  which  we  have  been  given  detailed  description  of  the  edge  computing  testbed deployed in the '5G Edge -XR' project to implement and demonstrate AR/VR-assisted event viewing. BT's 5G Edge -XR project leverages edge computing and high data rate and low latency 5G wireless connectivity to deliver extended reality (XR) experience for a range of use places. An example of such a  use  place  is  the  smart  stadium  where  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  supports  instantaneous consumption of locally generated content at that location of a sporting event. This section details the description of the edge computing testbed used in BT's 5G Edge -XR project as well as the description of an envisioned production styled environment for implementing the AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case in smart stadiums.
headers: 2.4. Description of BT's Setup for AR/VR -Assisted Event Viewing

source_file: MS5_Final Draft of ECOICE Report V1.2_Final
text:
The  demonstration testbed  adopted  in the  5G Edge-XR  testbed  comprises  of  multiple  cameras distributed  across  the  event  arena  which  send  video  data  to  the  edge  computing  pod.  The  edge computing testbed consists of three important components as illustrated in Figure 3.

- i. Model Server : The model server is dedicated to pre-processing of received video contents. The model server is a content server which decodes, and stores captured video content.

- ii. Normal Host Servers : These servers host virtual machines (VMs) or containers. Each VM or container  hosts  a  XR  application  which  retrieves  stored  video  content  from  the  model servers and processes the video contents to generate the corresponding view and format requested by a corresponding user. In the testbed developed for 5G Edge-XR project, a user requires a dedicated VM or container to render a desired view. The testbed comprises of 4 normal servers as illustrated in Figure 3. Each normal server can support up to 25 VMs (i.e., 25 users).
- iii. Data Centre Network : A data centre network (DCN) interconnects all servers in the edge computing pod. The DCN adopted in the 5G Edge-XR project includes an edge gateway switch and links that interconnect servers in the edge computing pod. The edge gateway switch receives content (video and data) from the event arena and forwards it to the model server. The edge gateway switch also receives processed content from normal host servers and forwards such content to user smart end-devices.

Figure 3: 5G Edge XR Project Edge Computing Testbed.

<!-- image -->

The communication flow in edge computing pod of the 5G Edge-XR project is summarized in the illustration in Figure 4. The steps of the communication flow include the following.

- Step 1 :  Unprocessed 100 Mbps video stream is received from the event arena via capturing cameras.
- Step 2 : The model server stores the unprocessed 100 Mbps video stream.
- Step 3 : IoT sensors send collected data to normal host servers in the edge computing pod.

- Step 4 : User requests a certain view of the event via a smart end-device.
- Step 5 : A VM is instantiated and assigned to the user who made a request for the view.
- Step 6 : User's VM processes the collected data from IoT sensors.
- Step  7 :  User's  VM  requests  and  receives  pre -processed  100  Mbps  stream  from  the  model server.
- Step 8 : User's VM processes the received video stream and generates a 10 Mbps stream.
- Step 9 : User's VM sends the generated 10 Mbps stream to a corresponding smart end -device at the event arena.

Figure 4: Communication Flow in Edge Computing Pod for AR/VR-Assisted Event Viewing.

<!-- image -->

text:
In a simplistic research scenario as described earlier, the applications that enable AR/VR-assisted event viewing can run in a dedicated edge computing testbed. However, this is not expected in an ideal production  style  environment.  A  production  edge  computing  environment  will  support  other applications concurrently with the applications that enable AR/VR-assisted event viewing. In contrast with the simplistic edge computing infrastructure illustrated in Figure 3 and Figure 4, which is designed to support up to 100 users, a production style edge computing platform is expected to support more (up  to  130,000)  users/fans.  Consequently,  more  servers  are  expected  in  an  ideal  production environment to support a wide range of applications and a larger number of users. Furthermore, the simplistic DCN illustrated in Figure 3 is also replaced with a spine-and-leaf-based data centre network in the production environment as show in Figure 5.

The illustration of a production style edge computing platform in  Figure 5 comprises two pods, where each pod consists of six racks. Each rack contains six servers that can be for compute or storage. Each  server  has  network  interface  cards  with  which  it  connects  to  the  spine  and  leaf  datacentre

Deployment  of  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  in  smart  stadiums  requires  a  resilient  (highly available),  high  bandwidth  and  low  latency  infrastructure  to  support  content  capturing,  content processing  and  transmission  of  processed  content  back  to  the  users. High performance in more specific terms involves low latency and high data rate communication as well as high availability and resilience of network infrastructure, content storage, and processing infrastructure. Furthermore, the setup must be very flexible and scale effectively to support increased uptake  of  the  AR/VR-assisted  events  viewing  by  stadium  goers  (fans).  The  C-PON  low  power consumption is a key enabler for the scaling of the infrastructure and its economic operation.  The

underlying features and value proposition of C-PON make it a suitable technology to provide edge computing  infrastructure  to  support  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  in  smart  stadiums.  These  value propositions are also applicable for other features of smart stadiums that require (or would benefit from)  edge  computation.  Consequently,  the  spine-and-leaf-based  production  style  environment  in Figure 5 can be replaced with comparable C-PON-based production style environment in Figure 6.

- Scalability : High scalability is required as smart stadiums evolve and grow with the addition of new  assets (cameras, sensors, capacity, technologies  and features etc.). The cellular architecture of C-PON platform would support proportional scaling of the platform to support the introduction of novel user smart end-devices, cameras, network capacity and features.
- Power/Energy  Efficient  Computing :  The  adoption  of  the  C-PON  platform  in  place  of  a traditional  edge  computing  pod  can  enable  significant  (up  to  80%)  reduction  in  the  power consumed. The energy efficient computing capacity provided by a C-PON platform at the edge can also encourage hosting a wide range of smart stadium applications which include but is not limited to AR/VR events viewing. Furthermore, a C-PON-based edge computing pod can also support virtual network functions that are needed to set up public or private mobile networks which can enable wireless connectivity in smart stadiums.
