Power consumption saving as a result of using C-PON in a smart stadium with AR/VR.

- In this estimation, a large stadium that accommodates 100,000 fans is considered.
- Based on BT's deployment setup, each server can host 25 virtual machines (VMs). Each VM is dedicated to one user, providing multiple views from cameras, augmented reality, and virtual reality.
- Thus, 4000 servers are required for a large stadium that accommodates 100,000 fans. However, the  number  of  servers  needed  is  typically  higher  to  allow  for  server  failures  and  provide redundancy. Thus, 5000 servers are considered in this use case.
- A typical server and associated networking power consumption is 500W. The typical power usage  effectiveness  (PUE)  in  an  installation  of  this  size  is  1.5  (i.e.,  the  facility  uses  air

conditioning, has AC-DC-AC power conversion losses, and uses lighting etc.). Thus, for each watt of IT, a total of 1.5W is consumed.

- The 5000 servers and their networking (500W each) thus result in an IT power consumption of 2.5 MW. Taking the PUE of 1.5 into account, the power consumption is 3.75 MW.
- Networking is currently 20% of the total IT power consumption in a data centre installation and is expected to grow to 80% of the data centre IT power consumption. This growth is because clock speeds in processors have been growing very slowly (from 1.5 GHz to 3.5 GHz) over the past decade and the number of cores per processor has also grown very slowly. In contrast, over the last 15 years or so, the communication data rate per server has grown from 1Gb/s to 100Gb/s with roadmaps to 1Tb/s per server over the next decade.
- Taking a conservative estimate where networking represents 20% of the IT power consumption, then networking represents a power consumption of 0.5 MW. C-PON saves 80% of this, which is a saving of 0.4 MW. Taking the PUE into account the 0.4 MW becomes 0.6 MW.
- A typical home in the UK consumes 9000 kWh per year. Assuming the smart stadium processing cell is used for the stadium when the stadium is operational and for the city during other times, the 0.6 MW power saving as a result of C-PON is equivalent to eliminating the power demands of (600 kW x 24 x 365 / 9000) 584 homes.
- At  the  other  end  when  networking  accounts  for  80%  of  the  IT  power  consumption,  then networking is 2 MW in this facility. C-PON saves 80% of this, which is 1.6 MW power saving. Taking the PUE of 1.5 into account, the saving is 2.4 MW. This is equivalent to saving the energy needed by 2336 UK homes.

These power savings are due to a single deployment in one stadium. The savings scale as more facilities such as shopping centers, museums, schools, enterprises etc. are considered and are equipped with AR / VR capabilities.

Carbon emission saving as a result of using C-PON in a smart stadium with AR/VR.

- Carbon emissions are 0.193 kg of CO2e per kWh in the U.K.

This  document forms a detailed report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 2 nd   January 2023 to  31 th   March  2022, focused on the two deliverables in the ECOICE project. The organisation of this report is as follows:

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs)  with  effective,  resilient  and  energy  efficient  computing  for  various  applications.  The  C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL)  3  to  TRL6  where  a  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  will  be  fitted  with  monitoring  and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including:

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The  engineers  in  Ultracell  Networks  Ltd  are  involved  in  the  development  of  the  key  C-PON components which include:

- C-PON NIC card: The C-PON card is a programmable network interface card (NIC) that is attached to the servers to perform networking functions. The C-PON card currently under development can have one or two ports with speeds of 100 Gbps, 50 Gbps, 25 Gbps, or 10 Gbps. One form of C-PON cards adopted in this project is an FPGA-based programmable NIC, where different functionalities can be implemented through high level languages (e.g., C++, Python, P4) or hardware description languages (e.g., Verilog and, VHDL).
- Optical Line Manager (OLM): the manager in C-PON that controls the networking in the C-PON platform.
- Optical back plane: Is the network connecting the servers within a rack. Typically, each rack has the same structure for the intra-rack network. There are two options in C-PON which are 1) A network of fibre cables and passive devices connecting transceivers and ports of the C-PON cards of the servers within the same rack. 2) An active programmable optical switch connecting the servers within the rack through fibre cables.
- Control  software:  The  algorithms  loaded  to  C-PON  cards  and  the  OLM  that  dynamically  assign bandwidth and govern the communication.
- C-PON  cell  development:  A  collection  of  racks  connected  through  a  C-PON  fabric.  These  racks contain the computing units containing CPU, memory, and hard disk resources in addition to an operating system. In this project, we use rack-mounted servers. The servers in C-PON should have PCI express slots to host one or more C-PON cards. The operating system should support the drivers required by the developed C-PON card/cards.

The control software plays a central role in the C-PON platform, acting as the key enabler for communication between different entities. It consists of algorithms, protocols, and applications that dynamically assign and manage network resources. The control software can be implemented as a single central unit. In such case, the optical line manager (OLM) accommodates the control software to act as a centralised controller. The main advantage of this model is the ability to have a central view of the network which helps to collect information and utilise the network resources. However, one drawback faced by this model is that the centralised controller can be considered as a single point of failure. An alternative approach for the implementation of the control software involves distributed instances of the control software running within the C-PON cell which act collectively as a single logical unit. The presence of multiple control entities in the distributed control architecture helps to overcome the single point of failure issue associated with the central controller. However, sharing the updates between the instances in a distributed control architecture can introduce additional overheads.

In this stage of the ECOICE project, the implementation of a central controller is being considered. However, multiple instances of the control software run concurrently in the OLM to ensure resiliency and reliability of the control architecture of the C-PON platform. The C-PON control software leverages the  software  defined  network  paradigm  (SDN)  where  the  control  plane  and  management  plane functionalities are decoupled from the data plane functionalities. Such paradigm offers high flexibility to effectively manage the network resources within the C-PON platform. To enable the communication within the C-PON cell, the control software is mainly responsible for the following:

- Perform the initial configuration of the C-PON cards within the C-PON cell.
- Compute the end-to-end paths after applying predefined policies such as routing, load balancing and resilience polices.
- Compute the forwarding tables and periodically updates the tables as required.
- Distributes the forwarding tables to the corresponding C-PON cards and update the tables based on changes in the network.
- Preserve  a  global  view  of  the  C-PON  platform  and  maintain  accurate  records  of  the  network devices and links.
- Use  the  collected  statistics  to  monitor  the  operation  of  the  network,  and  to  optimise  the performance of the C-PON platform.

Three main components are required to implement the C-PON control software; these include the  Network  Operating  System  (NOS),  the  Xilinx  P4  pipelines,  and  the  routing  and  forwarding algorithms. The NOS manages the network resources; the Xilinx P4 pipelines enable the communication within the platform; and the routing and forwarding algorithms which manages how traffic is routed and forwarded within the network. The requirements and components are described in the following sections.

ONOS is an open-source network operating system used to create and deploy dynamic network services. ONOS is a SDN controller that offers both the control and management planes functionalities. Hence, ONOS performs the initial configurations, manages the network components to enable the communication,  and  monitors  the  overall  system.  ONOS  features  seamless  customisation  of  the routing, management, and monitoring services, and thus enables high scalability, high availability, and improves the overall performance of the network. Although ONOS can be implemented in a distributed manner where a cluster of identical instances can be installed in different network devices, it remains a  logical  centralised  entity.  This  is  mainly  to  sustain  the  simplicity  of  a  centralised  controller.  Each instance can take over workloads from other instances to apply policies, such as load balancing, in case of  failure  in  one  of  the  instances.  For  overall  visibility  and  management  ONOS  provides  a  simple graphical user interface (GUI) to maintain information of the network. ONOS has a defined architecture which comprises three tiers which abstract the operation of the devices and applications. The tiers are briefly explained as follows:

- Tier 1: This tier is also identified as the southbound application protocol interface (API). This tier includes the modules and protocols that facilitates the communication with the network devices (i.e., data plane devices) in the system. ONOS relies on the southbound APIs to mediate between the distributed cores and the network devices. Such mediation involves sending instructions and receiving sensory data to and from the corresponding network component through the southbound APIs.
- Tier  2: The  second  tier  comprises  of  the  distributed  cores  that  are  critical  components  of  a centralised logical controller. It allows the separation of the physical data and control functions. These cores are instrumental for managing the distributed instances of the control software. Each core  acts  as  an  individual  subsystem  that  could  independently  keep  track  of  network  state information. However, all cores preserve a similarly high-level design architecture, including two components: the manager component and the store component.
- Tier 3: The third layer is also known as the Northbound API layer or the northbound APIs. This layer is attached to the application layer to convey network state information to the applications. This information includes abstractions to the network devices, the links, and the topology graph which are used by the applications to update and enforce the predefined policies.

In order to communicate with the data plane components (i.e., the C-PON cards), the P4runtime API is installed on both ONOS (i.e., P4runtime controller) and the managed devices in the data plane (i.e., P4runtime agent). ONOS uses the P4 runtime interface (i.e., southbound API) to interact with the

C-PON cards in the platform. P4runtime controls the P4 defined data plane and serves as the interface between the applications and the managed devices.

Generally, a high-level architecture of the P4 pipeline contains three customisable engines (i.e., blocks), namely, the parser, the deparser, and the Match-Action engine. Each engine has a specific task that is discussed in detail below:

- Parser engine: The parser is the first block that receives packets and decouples the headers form the payload. The parser includes three predefined states, namely start, accept, and reject; with the flexibility to define other states. The parser implements these states sequentially and it can set a default  state  to  be  executed.  After,  traversing  all  stages  of  the  parser  engine,  the  packets  are passed to the second engine for further processing.
- Match-Action engine: The second block is responsible of modifying the headers and the control packets. The packets are received and processed in a first in first out (FIFO) order. The MatchAction  engine  applies  actions  on  the  headers  such  as  forwarding  to  a  specific  port,  dropping packets, or taking no action. Typically, the match-action engine takes the match field value, which include data such as the IP address or the MAC address, as input and performs an action based on the  match-action table. Additionally, a  default  action  can  be  specified to  any  value  that  is not included in the list of the Match-Action tables. The match-action engine can contain several matchaction  tables  which  is  adaptable  based  on  the  pipeline  design. The  three  match types  used  to compare the match field values with the values in the tables are:
- o Exact Match: This type compares the exact match field value of the received packet to the available IP addresses in the match-action table. If the same IP address is encountered, the equivalent action will be performed on the packet.
- o Longest Prefix Match (LPM): In this case, the match field value does not necessarily have be an exact match with the value in the match-action table. However, the longest prefix of the value is selected to match the value in the table. This is helpful in minimising the number of forwarding match-action entries.
- o Ternary: This match type compares the input data with a wildcard mask in the match-action table. This is particularly useful when dealing with variable length fields.
- Deparser engine: The final block of the pipeline combines the packet and the header back into the original  shape.  After  the  deparsing  process,  the  packets  are  left  with  one  of  three  main destinations: the packets can either be transmitted to the next ports, or directed to the controller, or they can be dropped.

The routing and forwarding algorithms determine the best path for the packets between a given source to a given destination based on predefined policies. The control software defines the routing algorithms to manage the communication within the C-PON platform.

- Routing algorithms: The routing algorithms involve finding the best route for the packets. The selection of the best paths can follow various policies based on the network requirements. The main outcome of the algorithms is the forwarding tables which are pushed to the data plane devices to instruct the packet forwarding actions. In case of updates encountered in the network, the  devices  send  the  information  to  the  control  software  which  reflects  these  updates  in  the forwarding  tables.  The  control  software  pushes  the  updated  forwarding  tables  to  data  plane devices.
- Forwarding algorithms: The forwarding algorithms are accountable for following the predefined paths which are computed by the routing algorithm. Typically, the generated forwarding tables are installed on the data plane devices.

This  section  discusses  the  C-PON  testbed  that  is  being  developed  to  provide  energy  efficient computing and networking capabilities for edge and cloud-based processing. In addition to considering the specification of C-PON components such as OLM, smart NIC cards and the backplane as detailed in the previous deliverables of the ECOICE project, the practical implementation of the C-PON cell has also considered the following additional factors:

- The market availability of hardware as well as the compatibility of software.
- The manufacturing limitations and supply chain issues.
- The level of the programmability of the smart NIC cards and the backplane switches.
- The interoperability with different TCP/IP stack's networking protocols i.e., MPLS, OSP F, etc.

To determine the testbed components options and associate them with the C-PON specifications and requirements, we divided the development of C-PON testbed functional and engineering elements into three levels as shown in Figure 1. These levels helped us to define the selection criteria of the applicable testbed components within the project timeline and budget.

The C-PON testbed implementation fulfils four main functional requirements; these are listed and described as follows:

- Intra-rack Communication: The communication between the servers in the same rack is preformed through the optical backplane switch in that rack. Using the connected C-PON card that is installed in each server, traffic between servers in the same rack is forwarded via the ports of the optical backplane switch in each rack. Intra-rack communication involves invoking the forwarding entries that are listed in the switch configuration memory to ensure that matched communication between servers is within the same rack. These entries can be match-based on MAC or IP addresses and are managed, and periodically configured by the control software.
- Inter-Rack  Communication: The  communication  between  each  two  racks  in  the  C-PON  cell  is performed through two main intermediate elements i.e., the designated relay servers or the OLM. Both  elements  are  equipped  with  smart  NIC  cards  (C-PON  cards)  that  perform  the  routing  and forwarding between two servers in different racks. Additionally, the control software should be aware of the resources requested by the communicating server pairs as well as those requested by intermediate elements such as the OLM and the relay servers. The control software computes the best  path  and  provides  load-balancing  between  the  connected  entities  to  satisfy  the  QoS requirements and the predefined power consumption policies.
- Traffic Processing: C-PON control software implementation is built to monitor, optimise, and adapt the  networking  services  by  analysing  the  traffic  patterns.  Control  software  can  perform  traffic prioritisation, measure, and analyse the resources utilisation of the connected servers in the C-PON cell. Typically, a software agent will be deployed in each server to monitor a set of resources such as CPU, memory, NIC queues, etc.

A project plan was drafted for the implementation of C-PON  control software. This implementation  plan aims to determine  the implementation  tasks and identify each task's dependencies. The proposed implementation plan is divided into two phases to identify and mitigate the challenges that are encountered during the implementation. The phases are described as follows:

In this phase we initialised a basic testbed in a setup comprising of three servers with integrated C-PON cards. One of the three servers is customised as a centralised controller. This customised server accommodates the control software and is connected to the other two servers. All three servers are connected to form a basic C-PON cell as shown in Figure 2.

The implementation steps and tasks required to setup the basic testbed is outlined as follows:

- Step 1 : Initialise three Lenovo ThinkSystem SR665 servers and perform the recommended tests for the server memory, storage, cooling system, etc.
- Step 2 : Enable the required configuration of the pre-installed Xilinx U25 SmartNIC cards using the server BIOS configuration.
- Step 3 :  Setup the supported operating system (OS) RedHat Enterprise Linux 8.3 in each server, activate the OS subscriptions, and complete the essential peripherals configurations.
- Step  4 :  List  the  control  software  setup  perquisites  and  install  the  required  Xilinx  P4  compiler libraries, such as XRT, C++, Python, etc., and other kernel drivers.
- Step  5 :  Setup  the  ONOS  controller  and  its  essential  drivers  and  dependencies,  compile  the developed control software, and enable it as a networking module.
- Step 6 :  Install  Xilinx  Software Development Kit and Vivado Design Suite v2021.2 and install the licenses of Vitis networking P4 and IP Catalog.
- Step 7 : Validate that the OS can detect the pre-installed Xilinx U25 SmartNIC cards and perform a basic connectivity test between the servers using compatible DAC cables attached to Xilinx U25 SmartNIC interfaces.
- Step 8 : Format the Xilinx U25 MPSoC and perform the internal firmware updates and tests.
- Step  9 :  Build  the  initial  C-PON  P4  pipelines  which  include  the  three  main  engines  i.e.,  parser, deparser, and match-action engines.
- Step 10 : Test and validate the developed C-PON P4 pipelines design using Xilinx synthesis analysis tool.
- Step  11 :  Deploy  the  P4  pipeline  on  the  Xilinx  U25  SmartNIC  cards,  register  the  corresponding servers as devices in the ONOS controller via ONOS CLI.

AR/VR applications comprises a group of applications that enable immersive experiences. These group of applications include augment reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) and 360/immersive video streaming.

- Augmented Reality : AR improves the user experience of the real environment by superimposing a virtual  layer  on  it.  AR  experience  is  usually  delivered  via  mobile  devices  and  may  require  the integration of peripheral devices such as lenses.
- Virtual Reality :  VR immerses users in a virtual/synthesised environment that is isolated from the real environment. VR provides an immersive experience into the virtual world via a headset device.
- 360/Immersive Video Streaming : 360/immersive video streaming enables users to stream a video with a specified viewing angle and direction.

It  is  important  to  note  that  these  AR/VR  applications  can  also  be  complemented  by  other applications such as augmented audio.

AR/VR applications are highly versatile applications with a wide range of use cases across multiple sectors  of  the  global  society.  In  each  use  case,  AR/VR  applications  help  to  deliver  convenient, personalised, enhanced and engaging experiences to the users of such applications. These sectors with viable use cases of AR/VR application can be categorised as follows:

- Retail and Real Estate : AR technology can be used to augment stats onto retail items on display. AR  technology  can  also  be  used  to  augment  furniture  and  dÃ©cor  on  real  estate  property. Alternatively,  users  can  be  immersed  in  a  virtual  representation  of  a  retail  store  or  a  housing property of interest.
- Education  and  Maintenance :  AR/VR  applications  can  enhance  the  experience  of  students, technicians, engineers, medical personnel, and other professionals during training and maintenance by presenting instruction as an overlaid virtual layer on the real environment.
- Healthcare :  In  the  medical  field  AR/VR  applications  can  be  used  to  improve  the  efficiency  of surgical procedures, since remote surgical assistant can be provided using AR/VR technologies.
- Travel and Tourism : AR/VR applications can enable improved navigation service as well as provide immersive experience for tourist in (wildlife and adventure) parks and museums.
- Automotive, Aviation, and Aerospace : AR/VR application can be deployed to support training of driver and pilots.
- Entertainment and Sports : VR application can enable remote attendance of events; for example, an immersive stadium experience which can enable fans to be virtually present at the match.

Furthermore,  in-stadium  experience  can  be  improved  by  delivering  AR  view  of  the  pitch  to spectators i.e., stats and insightful information will be overlaid over live action on the field of play.

The  AR  and  VR  market  refers  to  the  development,  distribution,  and  use  of  technologies  and applications that allow users to have a full immersive experience in a virtual world while incorporating and augmenting the real world. As previously mentioned, AR/VR applications cover a wide range of use cases. In the recent years, the market has been rapidly growing as more industries and applications are making use of these AR/VR technologies. In general, the AR/VR market can be divided into the following categories:

- AR Advertising : Focuses on mobile applications advertising that are mostly deployed within social media platforms.
- AR Hardware : Focuses on the development of the peripheral hardware such as AR headsets and glasses.
- AR  Software :  Can  be  divided  based  on  the  applications  such  as  social  media,  gaming,  and eCommerce applications.
- VR Advertising : Focuses on advertisements shown in gaming platforms and VR videos.
- VR Hardware :  refers  to  the  visual  and  audio  devices  such  as  tethered  head-mounted  displays (HMDs) and stand-alone HMD headsets.
- VR Software : Refer to VR games, VR videos or any application that requires and uses VR peripherals i.e., VR headsets, sensors, etc.

Furthermore, these categorise feed into the market's revenue and penetration rates. The main source of revenue is from in-app purchases of application and games, in-app advertisements, AR/VR software and hardware purchases. The AR/VR market are driven by:

- Increasing technical capability meets increasing number of viable use cases:
- o Increasing graphical realism
- o Increasing remote streaming capability
- o Step changes in processing power, streaming capability, graphical interfaces
- o Technology is becoming 'mature'
- Increasing commercial pressures to:
- o Increase productivity (virtual prototyping, meetings)
- o Eliminate travel costs (VR)
- o Improve worker safety (AR onsite, VR training)
- o Lower carbon footprint (travel)
- o Reduce worker errors (training)
- o Protect worker health (training/operations for hazardous environments)

These drives for change require more powerful edge processing for 'local' applications, drive for low latency 5G connectivity and resurgence of 'On Prem' servers to tackle the challenges arising of the current constraints on bandwidth and latency.

Moreover, in recent technical reports there has been constant references to the ability of VR and AR to significantly reduce the carbon footprint of different applications. This is mainly due to reduced travel requirements for certain activities such as remote training. There are several key players in the market including companies such as Meta (Oculus VR), Microsoft (HoloLens), Snap Inc, HTC, Google and many more.

This section outlines the features of AR/VR application by discussing the range of deployment architecture  often  adopted  for  AR/VR  application  and  by  detailing  the  requirements  of  AR/VR applications.

The  architectural  setup  for  each  use  case  of  AR/VR  applications  can  be  as  simple  as  a  single standalone end-user device (i.e., HMD) that performs all the functions required to support a functional use case of the AR/VR application. In such architectural setup, the standalone end device is embedded with all  components i.e., input, processing, and output components, required in an AR/VR system. However, the functional and non-functional requirements of many known, emerging, and future AR/VR applications  are  not  easily  satisfied  by  this  simplistic  architectural  setup.  This  is  because  AR/VR applications  require  seamless  access  to  sufficient  computing  capacity  while  ensuring  optimal  user experience. For many AR/VR applications, the end-user devices are strictly unable to provide sufficient computing  capacity  to  support  the  computationally  intensive  processing  demands  that  must  be performed. Thus, prompting the emergence of other deployment architecture (architectural setup) for AR/VR applications. Such deployment architectures offload some or all processing capability from enduser devices.

In addition to the input, processing, and output components of simplistic standalone end-user deployment  architecture  for  AR/VR  applications,  offloading  (in-whole  or  in-part)  of  processing capabilities  from  end-user  devices  introduces  networks  as  an  essential  component  of  AR/VR application  deployment.  Hence,  networks  provide  an  infrastructure  that  can  support  the  seamless deployment of AR/VR applications. On one hand, the introduction of networks into the architectural setup for AR/VR applications can be as simple as the use of wired links to connect the end-user devices to a local workstation. On the other hand, the introduction of networks can be as complex as the use of wireless (i.e., 3G, 4G, 5G and Wi-Fi) network or the public internet as a medium to connect end-user devices to remote servers at the edge or in the cloud. Wireless networks are somewhat preferred because they enable seamless mobility for the users of an AR/VR application.

Generally, the architectural setups deployed for AR/VR application is defined by the location of the core processing functions enabling that application. Examples of such core processing functions include multimedia composition and video graphics rendering. Using this principle, coarse and fine classification  approaches  for  AR/VR  application deployment  architectures  exists.  Both  classification approaches are briefly  reviewed  below. The  illustration  in  Figure  8  also  gives  an  overview  of  both classification approaches.

Figure 8: Classification of AR/VR Application Deployment Architectures

<!-- image -->

A  coarse  classification  approach  for  the  AR/VR  deployment  architectures  AR/VR  generalised architecture as client-side rendering and remote (cloud/edge) rendering.

- Client-Side Rendering : Client-side architecture performs rendering of AR/VR application on enduser devices such as HMDs.
- Remote Rendering : Remote rendering architecture performs rendering of AR/VR application on remote servers in the cloud or at the edge. In contrast with client-side rendering, remote rendering architecture allows easy scaling and upgrading of the processing capabilities that enable AR/VR applications. Consequently, remote rendering architecture has the capability of supporting certain use cases of AR/VR applications that are infeasible when a client-side rendering architecture is adopted.

Fine classification: A fine classification of AR/VR application deployment architectures provides an alternative  to  the  coarse  classification  approach  discussed  earlier.  A  fine  classification  approach categorises the deployment architecture of AR/VR applications as localised, cloud-based, edge-based or hybrid deployment architectures. These deployment architectures are reviewed as follows:

- Localised: Two variants  of  the  localised  architecture  are  possible;  one  variant  of  the  localised architecture  places  AR/VR  functions  in  local  servers  while  the  other  variant  implements  a standalone system where an AR/VR display device performs all processing function as well as the function of displaying processed  contents. On  one  hand,  the  first variant requires the

establishment of network connectivity between the local servers and the display devices of endusers  which  can  lead  to  increased  delay.  On  the  other  hand,  the  second  variant  is  ideal  for application with ultra-low latency requirement. However, it is required that a standalone AR/VR end-user device must have sufficient processing capability as well as battery capacity to support computationally intensive AR processing functions and to support the presentation of processed content to the end-user. These requirements are not easily jointly satisfied on consumer devices .

- Cloud-based: This  architecture  implements  cloud  offloading;  hence,  the  servers  that  perform computationally intensive AR/VR core functions, are placed in the cloud. Display devices are thin clients which receive processed content from cloud-based AR servers over the public internet. This architecture is largely suitable for applications/use cases that are highly tolerant to latency since users are susceptible to increased latency under cloud-based architecture.
- Edge-based: This architecture implements edge offloading; hence, the display devices remain thin clients which receive processed content from the edge-based server. In contrast with the cloudbased architecture, the servers, which perform computationally intensive AR/VR functions, are placed  closer  to  the  display  client  at  the  edge  of  the  network.  Consequently,  the  architecture reduces the latency; hence, making it suitable for AV/VR application use cases with (ultra-)low latency requirements and other latency-critical applications.
- Hybrid: This  architecture  offers  both  cloud  offloading  and  edge  offloading  options  for  AR/VR applications. Hence, it provides support for diverse use cases of AR/VR applications with diverging latency  requirements  concurrently  by  enabling  selection  of  a  suitable  location  for  processing functions  based  on  each  use  case.

- Hybrid: This  architecture  offers  both  cloud  offloading  and  edge  offloading  options  for  AR/VR applications. Hence, it provides support for diverse use cases of AR/VR applications with diverging latency  requirements  concurrently  by  enabling  selection  of  a  suitable  location  for  processing functions  based  on  each  use  case.  This  is  because  of  the  correlation  between  the  location  of processing function of an AR/VR application and the end-to-end latency experienced by the end users of that application.

The location of the AR/VR processing functions in each deployment architecture determines the end-to-end latency experienced by users of the corresponding AR/VR application, which can in turn determine the feasibility of certain AR/VR application under selected architectural set-up. Generally, the choice of the architectural setup deployed for a specific AR/VR application under a selected use case  largely  depends  on  the  computation/processing,  latency  and  bandwidth  required  under  that scenario. Consequently, when a deployment architecture that employs remote servers are considered, the  requirements  for  the  network  (that  connects  the  end-user  devices  to  the  remote  severs)  also depends on requirements of the use case.

The  requirements  of  AR/VR  applications  vary  with  the  use  case  being  considered.  These requirements of an AR/VR application dictate the deployment architecture that can be adopted for the application.  The  primary  requirements  of  traditional  AR/VR  application  are  ideally  focused  on processing and presentation. However, adoptions of certain deployment architectures (i.e., architectures  that  offload  processing)  for  an  AR/VR  application  brings  communication  network requirements into focus as well.

In the context of the ECOICE project, requirements focused on the presentation performed by end-user  device  is  out  of  scope.  In  contrast,  processing  and  communication  network  focused

requirements associated with AR/VR applications fall within the scope of the ECOICE project. However, given that the core technological proposition of the ECOICE project (i.e., C-PON architecture) aims to interconnect  processing  servers  using  a  novel  network  architecture,  the  discussions  of  AR/VR application  requirements  are  directed  towards  communication  networks  requirement  as  against processing requirements. Generally, the processing and network requirements of AR/VR applications under different use cases include delay, capacity, availability, scalability, sustainability, and adaptability as  illustrated  in  Figure  9.  It  is  important  to  note  that  the  satisfaction  of  these  requirements  could contribute  to  metrics  that  are  evaluated  to  determine  compliance  with  predefined  service-level agreements (SLAs) for AR/VR application deployments under different use cases.

- Delay: Delay is an important requirement for all use cases of AR/VR applications. The delay metric determines  the  feasibility  of  each  use  case  of  an  AR/VR  application  as  well  as  the  quality  of experience of end-users. An explicit estimation of end-to-end delay sums up transmission delays, propagation delay, processing delay and queuing delay experienced across processing and network infrastructures.  Based  the  properties  of  the  AR/VR  application  under  consideration  and  the corresponding use case of that application being considered, end-to-end delay requirement of an AR/VR application  could  be  moderate  (non-critical),  low,  or  extreme  (i.e.,  ultra-low  latency  or critical). For instance, ultra-low latency is a characteristic feature of AR-assisted surgery (an AR/VR application use case) where high delay is life-threatening. Although, the selection of a deployment architecture for specific use case of AR/VR application can have significant impact on the delay experienced  by  users, evaluating the individual contribution  of  computing  and  network components to end-to-end delay is also important for optimisation purposes.
- Capacity: The capacity requirement of AR/VR applications is focused on having enough computing and  network  resources  to  deliver  the  expected  performance.

Although, the selection of a deployment architecture for specific use case of AR/VR application can have significant impact on the delay experienced  by  users, evaluating the individual contribution  of  computing  and  network components to end-to-end delay is also important for optimisation purposes.
- Capacity: The capacity requirement of AR/VR applications is focused on having enough computing and  network  resources  to  deliver  the  expected  performance.  Compute  capacity  for  an  AR/VR

application  covers  both  processing  and  storage  capacity  since  the  computing  infrastructure deployed  for  an  AR/VR  application  usually  requires  (in-situ)  content/data  storage  to  enable optimal performance. Furthermore, AR/VR applications are generally known to be computationally intensive application. On the other hand, the network capacity requirement i.e., bandwidth/data rate of an AR/VR application deployment can be low, moderate, and extreme (high)  depending  on  the  properties  of  the  AR/VR  application  under  consideration  and  the corresponding use case of the application that is being considered.

- Availability: The availability requirement of AR/VR application is focused on ensuring that endusers can access the system deployed to support the AR/VR application irrespective of its location i.e.,  end-users  should  receive  response  to  their  specific  service  request.  Given  that  AR/VR applications are user-facing, this requirement is of vital importance. This is because the availability of AR/VR application may be directly linked to performance and financial viability of the application since availability contributes to user perception and experience of the service being offered under each use case of an AR/VR application. Hence, it is essential that the system deployed to support AR/VR  application  be  highly  available  (i.e.,  must  have  minimal  downtime)  irrespective  of  the adopted deployment architecture. Consequently, maintaining high uptime of both computing and network resources deployed to enable AR/VR application deployment is necessary to ensure high availability and minimal loss of service.
- Scalability: The scalability requirement of AR/VR applications is closely related to capacity and availability requirements as it is focused on scaling computing and network resources to deliver expected performance when there is a surge in the number of connected end-user devices and/or sensors. Consequently, an easily scalable infrastructural setup is preferred for AR/VR applications especially  in  scenarios  when  AR/VR  application  is  deployed  in use  cases  where  the  number  of connected  end-users  and  sensors  in  each  area  or  location  can  be  massive.  Furthermore,  the scalability  requirement  of  AR/VR  application  may  also  require  seamless  scaling  of  enabling infrastructure  in  a  geographically  distributed  manner  to  provide  proportionally  sized  edge computing  capacities  to  distributed  users.

Furthermore,  the scalability  requirement  of  AR/VR  application  may  also  require  seamless  scaling  of  enabling infrastructure  in  a  geographically  distributed  manner  to  provide  proportionally  sized  edge computing  capacities  to  distributed  users.  Thus,  leading  to  the  need  for  proportionally  sized distributed DCs across different locations. Hence, the modularity of the enabling infrastructure for AR/VR application is closely associated with the scalability requirement of AR/VR applications.
- Sustainability: Sustainability is focused on the non-functional requirements of AR/VR applications under  different  use  cases  since  it  is  centred  around  the  eco-friendliness  and  power/energy efficiency  of  the  AR/VR  application  deployments.  This  requirement  aims  to  curtail  power consumption as well as carbon emissions associated with the use of AR/VR applications under all use cases. This is  of particular  importance  because  of expected  ubiquitous  adoption  of  AV/VR applications. Since AR/VR applications are known to be computationally intensive applications, wide deployment of AR/VR applications is expected to lead to high power consumption as well as high carbon emissions.
- Adaptability: The adaptability requirement of an AR/VR application is associated with how well both computing and networking resources can be dynamically changed on-demand based on the present or desired state of the infrastructure. This may require automation and programmability of the infrastructure deployed for a specific use case of an AR/VR applications. Adaptability helps

to improve the resilience of the AR/VR system since the programmability and automation of the adaptable  system  can  be  leveraged  to  seamlessly  respond  rapidly  to  disruptions  or  increased demands. Adaptability also promotes elasticity of the infrastructural setup used to support AR/VR applications. For example, installed compute resources and network resources can be logically scaled-up  or  scaled-down  based  on  changes  in  user  demands  for  AR/VR  applications.  Such elasticity  could  contribute  to  the  satisfaction  of  the  sustainability  requirement  of  AR/VR applications deployments  because  it encourages  proportional utilisation of the installed computing and networking resources.

C-PON is suitable for the transforming both edge processing and cloud processing. This is because C-PON adopts optical networking technology to enable low power, high data rate, low latency, and low heat modular DCs. Based on the outlined requirements of AR/VR applications, this section discusses how C-PON network architecture, and its value propositions can contribute to the satisfaction of the listed  requirements  of  AR/VR  applications.  This  discussion  focuses  on  how  the  adoption  of  C-PON technology as a network fabric at edge and cloud processing locations can aid the satisfaction of the previously outlined requirements of AR/VR applications. Firstly, the value propositions of C-PON are stated.  Subsequently,  the  section  discusses  how  that  stated  value  propositions  of  the  C-PON technology  can  contribute  to  the  satisfaction  of  the  outlined  requirements  for  AR/VR  applications deployment.

As defined in the ECOICE project business and technical annex and as summarised in Figure 10, the primary value propositions on C-PON include the following.

- High data transmission speed : C-PON technology is capable of well over 100 Gb/s with the ability to deliver Terabits/s -'future proof' for faster and higher density servers and storage. Existing data electrical switching communication architecture has an inter-rack data traffic bottleneck that limits speed to mostly 10Gb/s even when the copper links are replaced with high-speed optical links.
- Multiple high bandwidth inter-rack routes between servers : Avoids bottlenecks, reduces latency, increases resilience and configurability to allow real time load balancing.
- Cellular architecture : Almost infinitely scalable, 'pay as you grow' inspiration from cellular mobile communications where millions of devices are connected with limited available bandwidth. It is inherently optimised for the fast-growing modular data centre market.
- Multiplexing  capability :  Suitable  for  bolt-on  partial  PON  implementation  which  run  alongside existing data centre architecture which facilitates gradual adoption.
- High energy efficiency : Reduces power consumption by up to 82% compared to conventional data centre networks with electronic switches.
- Resilience : Paramount importance for service providers to ensure reliability and quality of services -directly linked with financial performance and competitiveness.

- Low Capex cost : Cost savings of up to 43% compared to conventional switch networks.
- SDN compatible :  Multiple software reconfigurable, high-bandwidth paths between servers and storage - ideal for virtualisation and software defined technologies (SDN).

C-PON architecture offers low delay communication between processing components in the DC. Compared to conventional DCN, the use of optical technology enabled C-PON to achieves up to 85% reduction in delay. The reduced delay improves performance of AR/VR application and allow greater flexibility in the delay budget of each use case of an AR/VR application. As a result of the delay reduction achievable when C-PON technology is deployed to support an AV/VR application that adopt the edge-

based architecture, new use cases of AR/VR applications may be made possible. The use of passive optical  component with  inherent  low  delay  characteristics  in  C-PON  network  architecture  helps  to ensure low delay when the network architecture is deployed in cloud or edge DC that supports AR/VR applications. Additionally, presence of high-capacity links in the C-PON network topology also ensure that lower delay is experienced when traversing the network.

Use of optical technology by C-PON enables high data rates of well over 100 Gbps which can be scaled  in  the  future  to  increase  capacity  as  optical  communication  technology  matures  and  as the demand for AR/VR application grows. Thus, C-PON future proofs the DC network deployed in DCs against growth in demand. Consequently, C-PON optical architecture and solution provides a DCN for immediate  and  future  communication  requirement  of  AR/VR  applications.  The  multiple  high bandwidth paths between servers of the C-PON architecture can also be leveraged to ensure sufficient network capacity. The cellular architecture of the C-PON network ensures that the predominant eastwest  traffic  of  AR/VR  applications  in  both  edge/cloud  computing  infrastructures  is  localised.  Thus, minimising network capacity bottlenecks when C-PON-based computing infrastructure is deployed for AR/VR application.

The redundant links of C-PON help to improve the availability of computing infrastructure deployed to  support AR/VR applications. This is because the redundant links enable C-PON to offer multiple communication paths which provide alternative network paths in the computing infrastructure. These alternative paths can improve the availability of C-PON-based processing nodes despite link or node failure. Furthermore, the cellular architecture of the C-PON ensures physical isolation of faults and failures.  Hence,  contributing  to  high  uptime  of  AR/VR  applications  when  C-PON  based  computing infrastructure is adopted. Additionally, the adoption of reliable passive optical components in the CPON architecture also ensures improved availability of AR/VR applications.

C-PON network architecture can be scaled incrementally without any restriction when adopted in both cloud and edge processing nodes. This feature of C-PON network architecture can be effectively exploited when AR/VR applications adopt cloud-based or edge-based deployment architectures. For example, consider a scenario where the edge-based deployment architecture is adopted for a use case of  AR/VR  application  in  smart  stadiums.  The  adoption  of  C-PON  in  edge  processing  setups  makes seamless horizonal and vertical scaling possible in this scenario. On one hand, edge computing capacity can  be  scaled,  by  increasing  the  size  of  the  cell,  to  satisfy  changing  demand  patterns  of  AR/VR applications. On the other hand, edge computing capacity can be scaled, by increasing the number of cells at the processing node, to satisfy changing demand patterns of AR/VR applications.

As a result of expected wide uptake of AR/VR applications and the low delay required for many use cases  of  the  application,  wide  implementation  of  the  edge-based  deployment  architecture  as  a distributed system is expected. CPON's cellular architecture pre sents an appropriate setup for this

expected deployment architecture since a C-PON based infrastructure can be proportionally sized to provide modular deployment at each processing location. Furthermore, since C-PON can be deployed gradually  and  can  co-exist  with  other  infrastructure,  a  dedicated  C-PON-based  edge  computing infrastructure  can  be  deployed  solely  to  provide  proportional  computing  capacity  for  AR/VR applications  while  the  conventional  edge  computing  infrastructure  of  5G  deployment  continues  to perform its functions. Thus, providing an energy efficient setup for computationally intensive AR/VR applications  while  protecting  existing  investment.  Additionally,  use  of  optical  technology  in  C-PON fabric ensures that the capacity of the network fabric can scale as optical technologies advances .

C-PON offers a low-cost network architecture for both edge and cloud computing infrastructure which consumes less energy and consequently leads to lower carbon emissions. Compared to spine and leaf network, C-PON technology enables up to 82% reduction in the network power consumption via the use of passive optical components and its novel architecture. This promotes sustainable scaling of AR/VR applications to support upward growth in user demands given that wide adoption of AR/VR applications is expected and that the enabling computing infrastructure will be distributed. Compared to a conventional DCN, C-PON DCN offers up to 43% reduction in CAPEX and up to 27% reduction in OPEX.  As  result  of  the  lower  CAPEX  and  OPEX  enabled  by  C-PON-based  computing  infrastructure, AR/VR  applications  that  adopt  the  platform  can  be  scaled  sustainably  as  the  demand  for  such application  proliferates.  High  availability  and  resilience  of  C-PON  infrastructure  ensure  excellent uptime for mission critical applications, such as AR/VR application, while also leading to reductions in maintenance  and  management  cost.  Thus,  further  promoting  sustainability  of  AR/VR  applications deployments.

C-PON offers SDN-enabled network architecture with multiple redundant, reconfigurable links and paths between compute and storage servers which can be configured on-demand to optimise the performance  for  AR/VR  applications.  It  can  also  help  to  elastically  scale  the  network  of  the  edge processing node on demand to support more users and sensors. By leveraging the improved availability and  adaptability  of  C-PON  infrastructure,  C-PON  infrastructure  can  provide  a  reliable  and  resilient network  infrastructure  to  support  AV/VR  applications.  Since  reliability  and  availability  of  AR/VR applications are closely related to the overall performance of user-facing applications such as AR/VR applications, adaptability of the C-PON technology can aid the push for optimal performance when such applications are deployed in a C-PON-based computing infrastructure. The ability to program the C-PON fabric to scale up or down also supports dynamic scaling of installed capacity and can enable load  balancing.  Such  ability  enables  the  C-PON  network  architecture  to  effectively  complement programmability of computing resources in the processing node. The adaptability of property of C-PON puts  the  technology  at  a  vintage  position  to  contribute  to  addressing  the  requirements  of  AR/VR applications i.e., delay, capacity, scalability, availability, resilience, reliability, and sustainability. Hence, putting C-PON in a good position to satisfy performance levels defined in service level agreements of AR/VR applications.

The scope of the ECOICE project includes engaging in the co-development of the C-PON platform with a blue-chip partner. To this end, a key deliverable of the ECOICE project is the selection of an exemplar use case to demonstrate the C-PON technology with a blue-chip partner. Following several interactions with Ultracell Network's primary blue -chip partners on the ECOICE project i.e., Vodafone and BT, we settled for the AR/VR application as the application of choice to demonstrate the value propositions of C-PON in edge processing. This is because AR/VR applications are high growth vertical 5G applications whose versatility proposes many potential use cases of C-PON technology. Some of these use cases as proposed by both BT and Vodafone were well documented in previous milestone reports of the ECOICE project.

The smart stadium use case of the AR/VR application has been selected as the exemplar use case which will  be  used  to  demonstrate  C-PON  technology  with  BT  (a  blue-chip  partner  on  the  ECOICE project). The ecosystem required for the selected use case of the AR/VR application includes features such as private mobile networks, edge processing and smart building. Our consideration of the smart stadium  use  case  focus  on  the  use  of  AR/VR  technology  to  assist  event  viewing  in  smart stadium/building or venue.

The smart stadiums leverage high performance digital infrastructure along with IoT sensors and smart end-devices to deliver improved fan experience in stadiums as well as to improve operational efficiency. Smart stadiums improve the fan experience by creating personalised services for fans. Such improved  experience  can  be  achieved  using  AR  and  VR  technologies  which  provide  new  ways  of experiencing live sports events via AR/VR-assisted events viewing. The AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums aims to deliver a memorable user-centric immersive experience of events held at the stadium. AR/VR-assisted event viewing adopts extended reality (XR) technology to process captured contents from live events. These processed contents are subsequently sent back to fans at the location of  the  event  to  deliver  memorable  immersive  experiences  that  motivate  fans  to  return  for  similar experiences.  Consequently,  the  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  use  case  in  smart  stadiums  helps  to increase revenue.

The architectural setup of AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadiums as illustrated in Figure 11 begins with distributed sensors (including IoT devices and cameras) which capture and encode video and data streams. Subsequently, the ecosystem leverages wired or wireless network infrastructure to transmit the captured streams to a remote processing location at the edge of the network i.e., an implementation of the edge-based deployment architecture. It is important to note that an edge-based deployment architecture is preferred because AR/VR-assisted event viewing in smart stadium is a delay critical use case of AR/VR applications. Furthermore, this use case of AR/VR applications also requires high bandwidth. Consequently, in addition to adopting the edge-based deployment architecture for AR/VR  applications,  5G  wireless  communication  technology  is  often  adopted  to  complement  the adoption  of  edge-based  architecture  for  AR/VR-assisted  event  viewing  in  smart  stadium.  This  is

because 5G  technology offers  low  latency  and  high  bandwidth  communication  as  required  by  the AR/VR-assisted event viewing use case of AR/VR application.

In the edge computing pod, the captured and encoded content is decoded and stored prior to transformation of the collected data into insights by data analytics software and/or the rendering of video graphics by XR rendering software. Furthermore, a multimedia stitching software can be used to combine processed video, audio, and data streams. The output of multimedia stitching is subsequently retransmitted for presentation on smart end devices in the event arena. These smart end devices and the applications running on them deliver the enhanced experience to users (fans) by receiving and decoding the processed content sent from the edge computing pod.

Further to the plans detailed in the MS5 report of the ECOICE project, a meeting was held with Louise Krug and her team to discuss the progress and the next steps. It was agreed to focus on finalising the co-authored paper to leverage a buy-in with the BT engineers. The  performance  criteria  considered  are  power  consumption,  links average  delay  and  the  end-to-end  delay. A Heuristic is also being developed to further validate the results obtained by the MILP optimisation model.

Amongst other expected outcomes, there are three key desired outcomes of the proposed C-PON field trial. These include validation of the C-PON platforms readiness for field deployment, compatibility and inter-operability testing, and performance evaluation via field measurements. Each outcome is briefly detailed as follows:

- Validation of C-PON platform readiness for field deployment :  Conducting a field trial of C-PON platform  in collaboration with  the industrial partners  of  the  ECOICE  project  will  provide opportunities to demonstrate and validate C-PON platform readiness for field deployment. For instance, the field trial will show how the C-PON platform can be interconnected with external systems (with multiple cameras) as well as the ability of the C-PON platform to support software applications to enable a selected use case of the AR/VR application.

- Performance evaluation via field measurements :  Another expected outcome of the C-PON field trial  is  to  conduct performance evaluation of the C-PON platform for AR/VR application via field monitoring  and  measurement  of  important  metrics.  Examples  of  metrics  to  be  monitored  and measured include power consumption, latency, and throughput. This  document forms a detailed  report on the work undertaken on the C-PON platform of the ECOICE project from 1 st April 2023 to 30 th June 2023, focused on the two technical deliverables as well as progress on implementation of a testbed that adopts a conventional network architecture i.e., spine and leaf network architecture. The organisation of this report is as follows:

- Section 1 is an introduction.
- Section 2 reports joint tests of C-PON card and OLM of the C-PON testbed.
- Section 3 reports initial tests of the backplane and the control software of the C-PON testbed.

Cellular Passive Optical Network (C-PON) is a platform that provides cloud or edge Data Centres (DCs)  with  effective,  resilient  and  energy  efficient  computing  for  various  applications.  The  C-PON technology organises the servers of this computing platform into C-PON cells. Each cell contains several racks and a data centre network fabric that enables connectivity between and within the racks.

The ECOICE project aims to transform the C-PON technology from Technology Readiness Level (TRL)  3  to  TRL6  where  a  C-PON  demonstration  prototype  will  be  fitted  with  monitoring  and measurement systems to verify its Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) including.

- Reduced power consumption.
- Reduced latency.
- Increased resilience.

The engineers in Ultracell Networks Ltd are involved in the development of the key C-PON components which include:

- C-PON NIC card.
- OLM.
- Optical back plane.
- Control software.
- C-PON cell development.

Several industrial collaborators are involved with the use-case development and validation of components, systems, and subsystems of the C-PON platform, including:

- Vodafone (wireless networks, IoT, and cloud and fog DCs).
- BT (wired network, cloud DCs and fog computing).

The C-PON card performs networking functions which include interfacing with physical media, parsing  of  packets,  temporary  storage  of  packets  and  forwarding  of  packets.  These  functions  are performed by a range of physical sub-components of the C-PON card. The physical sub-components comprise  network  interfaces,  forwarding  engines,  buffers,  and  traffic  managers.  The  Xilinx  U25 SmartNIC is adopted to develop the C-PON card in this project.

The OLM is a physical hardware that facilitates communications within the C-PON platform and between the C-PON platform and external systems by performing a range of essential functions. The features of the OLM are fundamental for performing end-to-end communication within the C-PON platform. Such features are enabled by the physical components of the OLM such as C-PON cards, backplanes,  computing  hardware  and  auxiliary  components.  The  C-PON  card  is  one  of  the  key components of the OLM. Therefore, the following section of the report provides details of the C-PON card development process before the outcomes of joint tests of the C-PON cards and the OLM are reported. The key performance metrics considered during the testing of C-PON card, and the OLM include performance and quality of service (QoS) metrics such as throughput, delay, jitter and packet loss. Power consumption is reported at the end of this document in a separate section for emphasis.

The  C-PON  card  is  a  programmable  Network  Interface  Card  (NIC)  utilised  to  carry  out networking functions.  The  C-PON  card  introduces  a  range  of  port  options  and  speeds  to  cater  for different data transfer requirements. Generally, the design of the C-PON cards depends on the data transfer  requirements.  However, in  this  project,  Xilinx  U25  SmartNIC  is  adopted  to  implement  the functionalities of the C-PON card. The Xilinx SmartNIC is an FPGA-based programmable NIC that can support diverse functionalities using high-level languages like C++, Python, P4, or hardware description languages  such  as  Verilog  and  VHDL.  The  choice  of  FPGA-based  programming  has  enabled  us  to customise and optimise the CPON card's operations, ensuring optimal performance and adaptability for  the  C-PON  cell  architecture  requirements  and  specifications.  In  this  project,  the  specified  P4 pipelines  are  implemented  on  Xilinx  U25  FPGA-based  SmartNIC  card  to  offload  and  optimise  the networking functions of the C-PON cell servers and these functions include forwarding, routing, traffic rate control and monitoring.

The development of the C-PON card is performed on Xilinx U25 FPGA-based SmartNIC. For FPGAbased NIC development, Xilinx provides a comprehensive software toolchain called Vitis Development platform. It encompasses all the necessary components for designing, implementing, verifying, and

programming  FPGAs.  The  suite  includes  the  Vivado  design  suite  which  offers  an  Integrated Development Environment (IDE) as graphical interface for system-level design entry, Register Transfer Level (RTL) synthesis, simulation, and debugging. Additionally, Vivado provides High-Level Synthesis (HLS) tools for designing with higher-level languages such as C/C++, python and P4, enabling designers to focus on algorithmic development.

Network testing refers to the process of evaluating and verifying the performance of the network. It  comprises  various  tests  and  measurements  to  assess  the  functionalities  of  the  network  and  to identify any potential issues. Network testing can be generally categorised as follows:

- -Performance  Testing: The  performance  testing  uses  various  traffic  loads  to  measure  the performance of network devices, such as routers, switches, and firewalls. It is used in assessing factors like throughput, latency, packet loss, and jitter under different network conditions.
- -Quality of Service (QoS) Testing: This test evaluates specific traffic classes or prioritise traffic based  on  different  QoS  parameters.  By  analysing  QoS  metrics  like  packet  delay,  jitter,  and

packet  loss,  the  performance  of  QoS  mechanisms  in  the  network  can  be  assessed  and optimised.

- -Application Performance Testing: Uses traffic patterns specific to applications or protocols to evaluate the performance of networked applications, such as video streaming, VoIP, or realtime data transmission. This helps to identify application-level issues, bottlenecks, and areas of potential optimisation.
- -Network Stress Testing: By generating high volumes of traffic, we can evaluate the network resilience and determine how well network devices and applications can handle heavy loads.

Device Unit Testing (DUT) helps to validate the functionality of the implemented C-PON card. The primary objective of DUT is to ensure that the card operates seamlessly by receiving and processing the ingress traffic through one port and efficiently forwarding the egress traffic through the other port. To execute the DUT, both ports of a C-PON card are connected to the traffic generator as depicted in Figure 9. The traffic generator is configured to compose 1500 bytes fixed-size Ethernet packets through different traffic loads ranging from 5Gbps to 25Gbps.

Figure 9: C-PON card DUT setup.

<!-- image -->

C-PON card DUT involves collection of important metrics such as the forwarding throughput, delay, jitter, and packet loss as traffic traverses the C-PON card. The results of the C-PON DUT are detailed as follows:

The  average  throughput  of  the  traffic  forwarded  between  the  C-PON  card  ports  remains consistently high across a range of traffic load i.e., 5 Gbps, 10 Gbps, 15 Gbps and 20 Gbps. This level of throughput indicates that the C-PON card effectively handles the traffic with minimal  performance degradation, as shown in Figure 10.

However,  it  is  worth  noting  that  at  the  maximum  link  speed  of  25  Gbps,  a  slight  decrease  in throughput is observed. This decrease in throughput can be attributed to the higher data rate, which presents greater challenges for processing and forwarding of packets efficiently. While the reduction in  throughput  is  marginal,  it  highlights  the  need  for  continued  optimisation  to  ensure  optimal performance at the highest link speeds.

To obtain the delay results, traffic generation was rerun for 5 iterations where each was a duration of 10 seconds. Figure 11 depicts the average of these iterations at each traffic load increment. The forwarded traffic between the C-PON ports exhibits an average delay of 14 microseconds across a range of traffic loads spanning from 5 Gbps to 20 Gbps, as can be seen in Figure 11. This delay value is in line with values that are typically observed in store-and-forward Ethernet switching, which is usually within the  range  of  tens  of  microseconds.  Therefore,  the  C-PON  card's  performance  in  terms  of  delay  is comparable to industry standard performance.

However, at the link speeds of 10 Gbps and 25Gbps, the average delay increases to approximately 15 microseconds. This leads to a noticeable increase in packet loss at these data rates as shown in Figure 13. The additional processing required to handle and forward packets efficiently at 10 Gbps and 25 Gbps introduces a delay that is more pronounced compared to other traffic loads.

It is important to note that while the average delay at 10 Gbps may be higher, it is still within an acceptable range considering the associated challenges of maintaining optimal performance at this specific data rate. Efforts will be made to further optimise the P4 pipelines or enhance the underlying hardware to reduce the impact on delay at 10 Gbps and 25 Gbps traffic loads. Attention to optimising performance and addressing potential packet loss issues at these link speeds can further enhance the overall performance of the C-PON card in demanding network environments.

Figure 10: C-PON card DUT average throughput.

<!-- image -->

The  jitter  of  the  forwarded  traffic  in  the  C-PON  system  decreases  as  the  traffic  load  increases  as depicted  in  Figure  12.  Jitter,  in  this  context,  refers  to  the  standard  deviation  of  the  random  delay experienced by Ethernet packets that are forwarded between the C-PON card's ingress and egress ports.

This reduction in jitter signifies that the C-PON card is effectively managing and controlling the packet flow by leveraging the enhanced backpressure feature and the optimised queuing memory to achieve a more reliable and consistent transmission of packets from the ingress to the egress ports. The decreased variability in delay differences between consecutive packets indicates the optimised synchronisation and enhanced efficiency in the packet forwarding process due to Xilinx implementing the IEEE 1588v2 standard for precision timing protocol (PTP) in the Alveo SmartNICs.

Jitter is usually expected to increase with traffic flow when the match-action engine is overloaded, however Xilinx SmartNICs are designed with a flow control mechanism which is equipped with 4 banks of Double Data Rate (DDR) memory each the size of 6GB. To further reduce queuing delay, the FPGA controls and minimise access to DDR memory using built in large quantities of small, internal RAM blocks. This enables pipeline-style computation which allows parallel traffic processing. These features are progressively utilised with traffic loads increase.

By  achieving  reduced  jitter  even  under  high  traffic  loads,  the  C-PON  card  demonstrates  its capability to provide reliable and stable packet forwarding, which is crucial for maintaining the QoS in data transmission. This trend reinforces the suitability of the C-PON card for demanding environments, where predictable and consistent performance is essential.

Figure 11: C-PON card average DUT delay.

<!-- image -->

Figure 12: C-PON card DUT jitter.

<!-- image -->

Packet loss is a key performance metric in assessing the reliability of networking devices under different network conditions and traffic pattens. Additionally, it provides useful insights to optimise the performance of the experimental designs and networking functions.

In the C-PON card DUT scenario, the overall average packet loss is 0.002%, as shown in Figure 13. This value is significantly low and falls well below the acceptable threshold for packet loss in audio and video  streaming  applications,  which  typically  ranges  around  1%  of  the  overall  packet  stream.  This indicates a high level of reliability in the tested networking device. For non real time data transmission, such packet loss can be recovered by the higher layers.

However, an anomaly in packet loss behaviour was identified specifically when 10 Gbps traffic load is  considered.  This  unexpected  packet  loss  pattern  requires  further  investigation  to  determine  the underlying reasons behind this abnormal behaviour. Addressing the causes of this irregular packet loss is  crucial as it  can directly impacts the overall performance of the C-PON cell. This anomaly will be investigated further with Xilinx to address the drawbacks caused by the manufacturing design of the Xilinx Alveo SmartNICs.

Investigating the factors contributing to the abnormal packet loss behaviour will provide insights into potential bottlenecks or limitations within the system. By identifying and resolving these issues, the overall performance and reliability of the C-PON cell can be improved to ensure seamless and uninterrupted flow of data.

Figure 13: C-PON card DUT testing packet loss

The joint testing of the C-PON card and the OLM is performed by connecting the traffic generator ingress port to a port of server S1 in rack 1 (S1 server is directly connected to OLM as shown in Figure 6. By establishing  this  interconnected  setup,  it  becomes  possible  to  evaluate  the  performance  of  both components in tandem and understand their combined impact on the overall C-PON cell.

In the C-PON platform, a backplane enables network connectivity between the servers within the same rack. Additionally, the backplane of a rack also enables the servers of that rack to access servers in other racks or cells within the C-PON platform. The optical backplane of the C-PON platform can be implemented with fibre Bragg grating or an optical polymer backplane or optical packet switches or optical  circuit  switches.  However,  technical  design  constraints  of  implementing these options have necessitated the use of an alternative backplane architecture for the C-PON testbed. This alternative backplane architecture is a representation of the polymer backplane. The optical polymer backplane offers higher capacity relative to other backplane options for the C-PON platform. Since, the polymer backplane is not commercially available, it can be represented at a small scale by a full mesh fabric. Therefore, a simple full mesh fabric is deployed to implement a backplane in each rack of the C-PON testbed. At higher TRL levels, beyond TRL6, we will explore scalability issues and the potential use of optical switches to simplify the design as all the routes in a full mesh are not all used at the same time.

The control software is the key enabler of communication between different entities in the C-PON testbed.  It  consists  of  algorithms,  protocols,  and  applications  that  dynamically  assign  and  manage network resources. In the C-PON testbed, the control software is implemented as a single centralised control  unit.  This  centralised  control  unit  resides  in  the  OLM  and  is  realised  via  the  open  network operating system (ONOS). ONOS is an open-source network operating system which can provide a software defined networking control plane for networks.

The backplane and the control software are important for establishing communication in the CPON platform. On the one hand, the backplane guarantees physical connectivity in the C-PON platform while the control software guarantees logical connectivity by providing the intelligence the enables end-to-end communication performed over physical devices. Initial testing of the backplane and the control software is conducted in this section. These tests include performance tests and QoS tests. Subsequently, the outcomes of these tests are reported.

To perform the end-to-end testing of C-PON testbed, the ingress port of the traffic generator is connected to the first port of server S1 in rack 1 and the egress port is connected to one of output ports of server S6 in rack 2 using the SFP28 25 Gbps Ethernet optical cables. The performance metrics collected during the testing of the full mesh testbed include throughput, latency, jitter, and packet loss. The analysis of the collected performance metrics is presented as follows:

The average end-to-end throughput is a crucial performance metric that offers deep understanding  of  the  networking  capabilities  that  are  offered  by  C-PON  cell  components.    The throughput also measures the synchronisation consistency and the interaction robustness between the C-PON cell components across different traffic loads and conditions. Moreover, it helps  to identify potential  bottlenecks  that  may  occur  along  the  communication  path  at  any  network  device  or component.

The average end-to-end throughput is measured across a range of traffic loads, including 5 Gbps, 10 Gbps, 15 Gbps 20 Gbps and 25 Gbps, as illustrated in Figure 19. The results show a consistent throughput over the applied traffic loads with slight degradation at the link speeds of 5 Gbps and 25 Gbps. The slight decrease in throughput at 5 Gbps can be attributed to the initialisation state of the CPON  cell.  During  this  state,  the  control  software  initiates  the  MAC  learning  process  for  the interconnected  C-PON  cards,  which  temporarily  impacts  the  overall  throughput.  However,  as  the system stabilises, the throughput gradually improves. While the decrease in throughput at 25 Gbps is mainly due to high utilisation of the link capacity.

<!-- image -->

The end-to-end average delay test is conducted to evaluate the performance of the full-mesh CPON testbed. The results in Figure 20 reveal that the average end-to-end delay is approximately 78 microseconds,  with  minimum  and  maximum  recorded  delay  values  of  67  microseconds  and  92 microseconds respectively.

Overall, the delay performance of the C-PON cards remains within reasonable bounds for various traffic  loads,  offering  efficient  packet  forwarding  which  is  in  line  with  the  industry  standards.  By maintaining low and consistent delay, the C-PON card ensures smooth and reliable communication between network devices. This is particularly important for real-time applications such as voice and video streaming, and industrial manufacturing.

The  recorded  jitter  testing  results  show  a  similar  trend  to  the  previously  conducted  testing scenarios of the C-PON card DUT and the joint testing of the C-PON card with the OLM. Figure 21 gives an illustration of the obtained results.

Building on the flow control mechanism provided by Xilinx as explained in point 3, section 2.3, the observed decrease in jitter indicates that the C-PON card, OLM, and full-mesh fabric can effectively manage and control the flow of ingress traffic packets. This achievement can be attributed to three main networking features i.e., the enhanced backpressure feature and optimised port forwarding in the C-PON card, minimised match-action flow entries processing, and the reliable physical links of the C-PON backplane. These networking features enable the consistent transmission of packets from a server in rack 1 (i.e., S1) to a server in rack 2 (i.e., S6) through the OLM (i.e., server S3 which acts as the OLM). The reduced variability in delay differences between consecutive packets signifies improved synchronisation and enhanced efficiency in the packet forwarding process.

The ability to achieve reduced jitter, even under high traffic loads, demonstrates the C-PON cell's capability to deliver reliable and stable packet forwarding. This reliability is vital for maintaining a highquality of service during data transmission.
