This test measures the packet loss across the same traffic load ranges (i.e., from 5 Gbps to 25 Gbps).  The  end-to-end  packet  loss  trends  against  the  traffic  loads  are  illustrated  in  Figure  22.  The overall average packet loss recorded is 0.12%. Even though the recorded average value of the packet loss is below the acceptable rate (i.e., 1% to 2.5%), there is still a room for improvement. The behaviour of the traffic load at 10 Gbps is identified as an outlier, as considerably high packet loss is observed under this traffic load.  An investigation should be conducted to analyse the factors that contributed to this anomaly.  Conducting a thorough investigation into the factors contributing to this abnormally high packet loss will provide valuable insights into potential bottlenecks or limitations within the system.

The initial test of backplane and control software takes into consideration the input of the ECOICE industrial partners by developing a C-PON testbed that is suitable for the AR/VR application use cases. The C-PON full mesh testbed is being designed to ensure that minimal latency increment is experienced when AR/VR applications are deployed based on previous discussions with BT. At the same time, the C-PON testbed is being designed and developed to provide high throughput communication which can further enhance the use of AR/VR technologies for event viewing in smart venues and arenas.

We are also considering the 4 generally accepted QoS parameters for AR/VR application during the testing  of  the  C-PON  testbed.  These  parameters  include  network  throughput,  delays,  jitter,  and network packet loss. In addition to enabling energy efficient computation, the results of the tests being conducted on the C-PON testbed have demonstrated that the C-PON testbed can deliver good QoS for AR/VR applications.

text: The C-PON platform is an alternative network topology for conventional edge and cloud computing pods. The ECOICE project aims to demonstrate the advantages of C-PON technology over the use of conventional network for networking connectivity in edge computing pods. To achieve such an aim, it is important to identify the benefits of adopting the C-PON architecture relative to other conventional network architectures such as spine and leaf architecture. Consequently, testbeds are implemented for  both  network  architectures  to  provide  tangible  measurements.  The  progress  made  on  the implementation of the testbed that deploys a spine and leaf network architecture is presented in this report. The progress report gives updates on the implementation of the spine and leaf testbed.
headers: 4 Update on the Progress of the Spine and Leaf setup

The setup of the spine and leaf tested is described in this section. Figure 23 and Figure 24 show the  implementation  of  the  spine  and  leaf  network  architecture  with  actual  hardware.  Table  3, summarises the required components to implement the spine and leaf testbed. Both spine and leaf switches are products from Juniper's QFX Series Switches product family. The hardware implementation of the spine and leaf testbed consists of:

- -Two leaf switches: Juniper QFX5120-48Y switches are selected to perform the functionalities of the leaf switches (highlighted in yellow colour in Figure 23).
- -Two spine switches: Juniper QFX5200-32C are adopted as spine switches (highlighted in red in Figure 23).

- -Network  connectivity: Each  leaf  switch  is  connected  to  each  spine  switch  in  a  full-mesh topology:
- o To match the implementation of the C-PON, each leaf switch is connected to each sever using a 25 Gbps link.
- o Each leaf switch leverages a 100 Gbps link for connection to each spine switch.

In this section we identify the steps required for the spine and leaf testbed implementation.  Table 4 gives a summary of the steps and the corresponding status of each step.

1. Perform initial configurations on the spine switches and leaf switches: The main outcome of this  step  is  to  bring  the  devices  into  an  initial  state  where  further  configurations  can  be performed.

2. Activate the licences of switches: In  this  step, we activated the licences of all the switches. There are three types of the licences, namely the standard licence, the advanced licence, and the premium licence. Only standard and advanced licences are needed to complete the spine and leaf  setup.  All  switches  come  with  a  standard  licence  which provides  basic  and limited features.  The  advanced  licence  unlocks  more  features  such  as  enabling  advanced  routing protocols. Note that the advanced licence is only required for the spine switches.
3. Connect  spine  and  leaf  switches: To  connect  the  spine  and  leaf  switches  four  ports  are configured to provide 100 Gbps. Direct attached cables (DACs) are leveraged to provide the required connectivity.
4. Configure  the  spine  and  leaf  switches'  ports: This  step  comprises  the  configuration  of  IP addresses  of  the  ports  connecting  the  leaf  and  spine  switches.  Note  that  the  same configurations appeared in Figure 23 are used to configure the IP addresses.
5. Configure routing protocol: The routing protocols are especially required to have communication between indirectly connected devices in the topology (such as communication between servers in different racks). Open shortest path first (OSPF) is the main routing protocol that is configured on all the switches.
6. Perform initial  configuration  on  the  servers: This  step  involves  the  setup  of  the  operating systems (OS) in all servers, ensuring that the smart NICs are identified by the OS, and finally configuring the smart NICs to enable communication with the leaf switches.
7. Connect the servers to the leaf switches in the same rack: In this step we connect the servers (i.e., three servers in each rack) to the leaf switches in the same rack. 25 Gbps DAC cables are used to provide such connectivity. This step also implicitly involves IP addresses configurations and setting manual speed of the ports to enable communication between the servers and the leaf switches.

- -Missing virtual chassis fabric (VCF) licence: One of the first challenges we faced is a missing licence of VCF. VCF is a fabric that allows multiple physical switches to operate as a single logical device, providing simplified management. However, VCF is not mandatory to implement a spine and leaf fabric. Therefore, we manually performed the configurations in each switch rather than relying on VCF.
- -Servers are not able to send traffic to the leaf switches: It seems that the default speed of each  port  of  the  leaf  switch  is  10  Gbps,  while  the  servers'  interfaces  speed  are  25  Gbps. Therefore, the communication between the servers and the leaf switch was not established because of the mismatch of the speeds. To solve the encountered problem, we had to manually configure the speed of each interface in the leaf to 25 Gbps to match the server's speed and to enable the communication.

Using the testbeds setup for the ECOICE project, the difference between the power consumption of C-PON based network architecture and state of art spine and leaf-based network architecture is over 50% as shown in Table 7, where the power consumption of C-PON network is 53.9% lower than that of spine and leaf network. However, this savings achieved by C-PON is expected to increase to about 80% in a field deployment. In contrast to the simple spine and leaf testbed considered in this report which adopted basic spine and leaf switches because of budget constraints, the power consumption of the spine and leaf switches adopted for field deployments can be higher by a factor of three or more. Furthermore, the C-PON functionalities used less than a third of the FPGA as shown in Figure 3. Thus, a smaller FPGA can be used. The OLM does not need all the functionalities of a full server. This can lead to a further power consumption saving in C-PON at higher TRLs, thus approaching the estimated 80% power saving.

The estimated network power consumption in Table 7 is complemented by measuring the total power consumption in the C-PON testbed with the aid of power meters. These measurements are collected  when  the  components  in  the  C-PON  cell  are  actively  processing  traffic.  Furthermore, measurements are collected under a range of input traffic loads. Figure 27 shows the maximum power consumption of the C-PON testbed under 5 Gbps, 10 Gbps, 15 Gbps, 20 Gbps and 25 Gbps. The result shows that the power consumption of the C-PON system increases as the traffic load of the system increases.

The disparity between the estimated power consumption and the measured power consumption provides useful insights to optimise the design and development of C-PON components such as the OLM and C-PON. The disparity between the estimated power consumption and the measured power consumption implies that the current implementation of the C-PON platform did not to fully utilise the capabilities of the commercial hardware adopted. For example, since the power consumption of the each  smartNIC  card  in  the  C-PON  testbed  does  not  approach  specified  power  consumption  value provided in the Xilinx datasheet, it can be inferred that the computing capacity available on the Xilinx smart NIC exceeds the computing capacity required to implement a functional C-PON card. Likewise, the total power consumption measured for the C-PON testbed as illustrated in Figure 27 does not reflect  that  the  6  severs  deployed  to  create  the  C-PON  testbed,  as  illustrated  in  Figure  25,  are consuming the power specified in for SR665 Server. Therefore, future development efforts to take the C-PON platform to TRL 9 will focus on designing and implementing hardware that is proportionally sized to match the requirements of each C-PON platform component i.e., OLM and C-PON card. The power measurements were conducted using Multicomp Pro Plug-In Power Meters as shown in Figure 28 .

In the future deliverables of the ECOICE project, the power consumption measured for the C-PON testbed  as  depicted  in  Figure  27  will  be  compared  with  the  power  consumption  of  spine  and  leaf testbed.
